dark:prose-invert dark"><h2 data-start="0" data-end="48" class=""><strong data-start="3" data-end="46">Instance-Based vs. Model-Based Learning</strong></h2>
<p data-start="50" data-end="164" class="">Instance-based and model-based learning are two primary approaches to <strong data-start="120" data-end="143">supervised learning</strong> in machine learning.</p>
<hr data-start="166" data-end="169" class="">
<h2 data-start="171" data-end="230" class=""><strong data-start="174" data-end="228">1. Instance-Based Learning (Memory-Based Learning)</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="232" data-end="253" class=""><strong data-start="236" data-end="251">Definition:</strong></h3>
<p data-start="254" data-end="423" class="">Instance-based learning does <strong data-start="283" data-end="315">not create an explicit model</strong> but instead memorizes training data and makes predictions by comparing new instances with stored instances.</p>
<p data-start="425" data-end="449" class="">✅ <strong data-start="427" data-end="447">Characteristics:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="450" data-end="773">
<li data-start="450" data-end="521" class="">
<p data-start="452" data-end="521" class="">Learns by <strong data-start="462" data-end="482">storing examples</strong> rather than forming a general model.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="522" data-end="620" class="">
<p data-start="524" data-end="620" class="">Predictions are made based on <strong data-start="554" data-end="568">similarity</strong> (e.g., distance metrics like Euclidean distance).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="621" data-end="706" class="">
<p data-start="623" data-end="706" class="">Requires <strong data-start="632" data-end="662">storing the entire dataset</strong>, which can be inefficient for large data.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="707" data-end="773" class="">
<p data-start="709" data-end="773" class="">Performs well on <strong data-start="726" data-end="744">small datasets</strong> but is sensitive to noise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="775" data-end="803" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="778" data-end="801">Example Algorithms:</strong></p>
<ol data-start="804" data-end="1129">
<li data-start="804" data-end="921" class="">
<p data-start="807" data-end="921" class=""><strong data-start="807" data-end="837">k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN)</strong> – Classifies a new instance based on the majority class of its nearest neighbors.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="922" data-end="1034" class="">
<p data-start="925" data-end="1034" class=""><strong data-start="925" data-end="978">Support Vector Machines (SVM) (with kernel trick)</strong> – Some variations of SVM use memory-based techniques.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1035" data-end="1129" class="">
<p data-start="1038" data-end="1129" class=""><strong data-start="1038" data-end="1078">Radial Basis Function (RBF) Networks</strong> – Uses instance-based learning to classify data.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="1131" data-end="1158" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1134" data-end="1156">Example Use Cases:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1159" data-end="1397">
<li data-start="1159" data-end="1241" class="">
<p data-start="1161" data-end="1241" class=""><strong data-start="1161" data-end="1187">Recommendation Systems</strong> (e.g., suggesting products based on similar users).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1242" data-end="1316" class="">
<p data-start="1244" data-end="1316" class=""><strong data-start="1244" data-end="1271">Handwriting Recognition</strong> (e.g., OCR software comparing characters).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1317" data-end="1397" class="">
<p data-start="1319" data-end="1397" class=""><strong data-start="1319" data-end="1337">Spam Detection</strong> (e.g., checking new emails against stored spam examples).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1399" data-end="1419" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1402" data-end="1417">Challenges:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1420" data-end="1633">
<li data-start="1420" data-end="1485" class="">
<p data-start="1422" data-end="1485" class=""><strong data-start="1422" data-end="1447">Slow during inference</strong> (since it must search the dataset).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1486" data-end="1541" class="">
<p data-start="1488" data-end="1541" class=""><strong data-start="1488" data-end="1515">High memory requirement</strong> (stores training data).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1542" data-end="1633" class="">
<p data-start="1544" data-end="1633" class=""><strong data-start="1544" data-end="1580">Sensitive to irrelevant features</strong> (performance depends on proper feature selection).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1635" data-end="1638" class="">
<h2 data-start="1640" data-end="1672" class=""><strong data-start="1643" data-end="1670">2. Model-Based Learning</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="1674" data-end="1695" class=""><strong data-start="1678" data-end="1693">Definition:</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1696" data-end="1902" class="">Model-based learning <strong data-start="1717" data-end="1756">builds a general mathematical model</strong> from training data and uses this model for predictions. Instead of storing instances, it learns a function <strong data-start="1864" data-end="1876">f(x) → y</strong> to map inputs to outputs.</p>
<p data-start="1904" data-end="1928" class="">✅ <strong data-start="1906" data-end="1926">Characteristics:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1929" data-end="2168">
<li data-start="1929" data-end="1979" class="">
<p data-start="1931" data-end="1979" class="">Learns a function or model from training data.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1980" data-end="2033" class="">
<p data-start="1982" data-end="2033" class="">Can generalize well if trained on a good dataset.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2034" data-end="2104" class="">
<p data-start="2036" data-end="2104" class="">Efficient for large datasets since it doesn’t store all instances.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2105" data-end="2168" class="">
<p data-start="2107" data-end="2168" class="">May require <strong data-start="2119" data-end="2144">hyperparameter tuning</strong> for best performance.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2170" data-end="2198" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2173" data-end="2196">Example Algorithms:</strong></p>
<ol data-start="2199" data-end="2601">
<li data-start="2199" data-end="2288" class="">
<p data-start="2202" data-end="2288" class=""><strong data-start="2202" data-end="2223">Linear Regression</strong> – Learns a mathematical relationship between input and output.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2289" data-end="2376" class="">
<p data-start="2292" data-end="2376" class=""><strong data-start="2292" data-end="2315">Logistic Regression</strong> – Used for classification tasks (e.g., spam vs. non-spam).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2377" data-end="2452" class="">
<p data-start="2380" data-end="2452" class=""><strong data-start="2380" data-end="2398">Decision Trees</strong> – Uses learned rules from data to make predictions.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2453" data-end="2536" class="">
<p data-start="2456" data-end="2536" class=""><strong data-start="2456" data-end="2475">Neural Networks</strong> – Uses deep learning models to recognize complex patterns.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2537" data-end="2601" class="">
<p data-start="2540" data-end="2601" class=""><strong data-start="2540" data-end="2555">Naïve Bayes</strong> – Uses probability theory to classify data.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="2603" data-end="2630" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2606" data-end="2628">Example Use Cases:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2631" data-end="2873">
<li data-start="2631" data-end="2714" class="">
<p data-start="2633" data-end="2714" class=""><strong data-start="2633" data-end="2655">Weather Prediction</strong> (e.g., forecasting temperature using regression models).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2715" data-end="2800" class="">
<p data-start="2717" data-end="2800" class=""><strong data-start="2717" data-end="2736">Fraud Detection</strong> (e.g., detecting fraudulent transactions based on past data).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2801" data-end="2873" class="">
<p data-start="2803" data-end="2873" class=""><strong data-start="2803" data-end="2824">Medical Diagnosis</strong> (e.g., predicting diseases based on symptoms).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2875" data-end="2895" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2878" data-end="2893">Challenges:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2896" data-end="3168">
<li data-start="2896" data-end="2979" class="">
<p data-start="2898" data-end="2979" class=""><strong data-start="2898" data-end="2938">Needs a well-defined model structure</strong> (choosing the right model is crucial).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2980" data-end="3069" class="">
<p data-start="2982" data-end="3069" class=""><strong data-start="2982" data-end="3008">Requires training time</strong> (unlike instance-based learning, which needs no training).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3070" data-end="3168" class="">
<p data-start="3072" data-end="3168" class=""><strong data-start="3072" data-end="3115">Model assumptions may limit performance</strong> (e.g., linear models assume linear relationships).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="3170" data-end="3173" class="">
<h2 data-start="3175" data-end="3235" class=""><strong data-start="3178" data-end="3233">Comparison: Instance-Based vs. Model-Based Learning</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="3237" data-end="3880" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="3237" data-end="3297"><tr data-start="3237" data-end="3297"><th data-start="3237" data-end="3247">Feature</th><th data-start="3247" data-end="3273">Instance-Based Learning</th><th data-start="3273" data-end="3297">Model-Based Learning</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="3348" data-end="3880"><tr data-start="3348" data-end="3423"><td><strong data-start="3350" data-end="3362">Approach</strong></td><td>Memorizes training data</td><td>Learns a mathematical function</td></tr><tr data-start="3424" data-end="3509"><td><strong data-start="3426" data-end="3443">Training Time</strong></td><td>Fast (just stores data)</td><td>Can be slow (requires optimization)</td></tr><tr data-start="3510" data-end="3601"><td><strong data-start="3512" data-end="3531">Prediction Time</strong></td><td>Slow (compares with stored instances)</td><td>Fast (uses trained model)</td></tr><tr data-start="3602" data-end="3675"><td><strong data-start="3604" data-end="3620">Memory Usage</strong></td><td>High (stores data)</td><td>Low (stores model parameters)</td></tr><tr data-start="3676" data-end="3769"><td><strong data-start="3678" data-end="3696">Generalization</strong></td><td>May overfit if data is noisy</td><td>Generalizes better with proper tuning</td></tr><tr data-start="3770" data-end="3880"><td><strong data-start="3772" data-end="3784">Examples</strong></td><td>k-NN, SVM (with kernels), RBF networks</td><td>Linear Regression, Decision Trees, Neural Networks</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="3882" data-end="3885" class="">
<h2 data-start="3887" data-end="3919" class=""><strong data-start="3890" data-end="3919">Which One Should You Use?</strong></h2>
<ul data-start="3920" data-end="4199">
<li data-start="3920" data-end="4054" class="">
<p data-start="3922" data-end="4054" class=""><strong data-start="3922" data-end="3953">Use Instance-Based Learning</strong> if you have a <strong data-start="3968" data-end="3985">small dataset</strong> and need flexible, adaptive models (e.g., recommendation systems).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4055" data-end="4199" class="">
<p data-start="4057" data-end="4199" class=""><strong data-start="4057" data-end="4085">Use Model-Based Learning</strong> if you have <strong data-start="4098" data-end="4118">large-scale data</strong> and need efficient, scalable solutions (e.g., deep learning, fraud detection).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4201" data-end="4204" class="">
<p data-start="4206" data-end="4269" class="">Would you like me to dive deeper into any of these concepts? 🚀</p></div></div></div></div><div class="mb-2"></div></div></div></div></div></article><article class="group/turn w-full text-token-text-primary focus-visible:outline-2 focus-visible:outline-offset-[-4px]" dir="auto" data-testid="conversation-turn-24" data-scroll-anchor="false"><h5 class="sr-only">You said:</h5><div class="text-base my-auto mx-auto py-[18px] px-6"><div class="mx-auto flex flex-1 text-base gap-4 md:gap-5 lg:gap-6 md:max-w-3xl lg:max-w-[40rem] xl:max-w-[48rem]"><div class="group/conversation-turn relative flex w-full min-w-0 flex-col @xs/thread:px-0 @sm/thread:px-1.5 @md/thread:px-4"><div class="flex-col gap-1 md:gap-3"><div class="flex max-w-full flex-col flex-grow"><div data-message-author-role="user" data-message-id="5d9d3de4-81b3-4361-8554-f4255cde3541" dir="auto" class="min-h-8 text-message relative flex w-full flex-col items-end gap-2 whitespace-normal break-words text-start [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5"><div class="w-full"><div class="flex w-full flex-col gap-1 empty:hidden items-end rtl:items-start"><div class="relative max-w-[var(--user-chat-width,70%)] rounded-3xl bg-token-message-surface px-5 py-2.5"><div class="whitespace-pre-wrap">What are Tensors In-depth Explanation in Machine Learning.

dark:prose-invert dark"><h2 data-start="0" data-end="58" class=""><strong data-start="3" data-end="56">Tensors: In-Depth Explanation in Machine Learning</strong></h2>
<p data-start="60" data-end="319" class="">Tensors are the fundamental data structure used in <strong data-start="111" data-end="131">machine learning</strong> and <strong data-start="136" data-end="153">deep learning</strong>, especially in frameworks like <strong data-start="185" data-end="199">TensorFlow</strong> and <strong data-start="204" data-end="215">PyTorch</strong>. They are multi-dimensional arrays that generalize scalars, vectors, and matrices to higher dimensions.</p>
<hr data-start="321" data-end="324" class="">
<h2 data-start="326" data-end="355" class=""><strong data-start="329" data-end="353">1. What is a Tensor?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="356" data-end="545" class="">A <strong data-start="358" data-end="368">tensor</strong> is a mathematical object used to represent data in multiple dimensions. It is a <strong data-start="449" data-end="467">generalization</strong> of scalars (0D), vectors (1D), and matrices (2D) to <strong data-start="520" data-end="537">n-dimensional</strong> spaces.</p>
<p data-start="547" data-end="582" class="">✅ <strong data-start="549" data-end="580">Characteristics of Tensors:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="583" data-end="879">
<li data-start="583" data-end="642" class="">
<p data-start="585" data-end="642" class="">Tensors <strong data-start="593" data-end="602">store</strong> data as <strong data-start="611" data-end="639">multi-dimensional arrays</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="643" data-end="726" class="">
<p data-start="645" data-end="726" class="">They support <strong data-start="658" data-end="723">operations like addition, multiplication, and transformations</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="727" data-end="793" class="">
<p data-start="729" data-end="793" class="">Used extensively in <strong data-start="749" data-end="773">deep learning models</strong> for computations.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="794" data-end="879" class="">
<p data-start="796" data-end="879" class="">Tensors can be stored on <strong data-start="821" data-end="845">CPUs, GPUs, and TPUs</strong>, allowing efficient computations.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="881" data-end="884" class="">
<h2 data-start="886" data-end="934" class=""><strong data-start="889" data-end="932">2. Types of Tensors by Dimension (Rank)</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="936" data-end="1325" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="936" data-end="991"><tr data-start="936" data-end="991"><th data-start="936" data-end="950">Tensor Type</th><th data-start="950" data-end="980">Rank (Number of Dimensions)</th><th data-start="980" data-end="991">Example</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="1036" data-end="1325"><tr data-start="1036" data-end="1085"><td><strong data-start="1038" data-end="1048">Scalar</strong> (0D)</td><td>0</td><td><code data-start="1060" data-end="1067">x = 5</code> (Single number)</td></tr><tr data-start="1086" data-end="1141"><td><strong data-start="1088" data-end="1098">Vector</strong> (1D)</td><td>1</td><td><code data-start="1110" data-end="1121">[3, 7, 2]</code> (List of numbers)</td></tr><tr data-start="1142" data-end="1203"><td><strong data-start="1144" data-end="1154">Matrix</strong> (2D)</td><td>2</td><td><code data-start="1166" data-end="1184">[[1, 2], [3, 4]]</code> (Rows &amp; columns)</td></tr><tr data-start="1204" data-end="1254"><td><strong data-start="1206" data-end="1219">3D Tensor</strong></td><td>3</td><td><code data-start="1226" data-end="1252">[[[1], [2]], [[3], [4]]]</code></td></tr><tr data-start="1255" data-end="1325"><td><strong data-start="1257" data-end="1271">n-D Tensor</strong></td><td>n</td><td>High-dimensional data (used in deep learning)</td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<h2 data-start="2523" data-end="2559" class=""><strong data-start="2526" data-end="2557">4. Tensors in Deep Learning</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2560" data-end="2730" class="">Tensors are essential in deep learning frameworks like <strong data-start="2615" data-end="2641">TensorFlow and PyTorch</strong>, which use tensors to represent <strong data-start="2674" data-end="2710">inputs, weights, and activations</strong> in neural networks.</p>
<p data-start="2732" data-end="2775" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2735" data-end="2775">Example: Neural Network Input Tensor</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2776" data-end="2915">
<li data-start="2776" data-end="2841" class="">
<p data-start="2778" data-end="2841" class=""><strong data-start="2778" data-end="2788">Images</strong> → 4D tensor: <code data-start="2802" data-end="2841">[batch_size, height, width, channels]</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="2842" data-end="2915" class="">
<p data-start="2844" data-end="2915" class=""><strong data-start="2844" data-end="2854">Videos</strong> → 5D tensor: <code data-start="2868" data-end="2915">[batch_size, frames, height, width, channels]</code></p>
</li>
</ul>

<hr data-start="3415" data-end="3418" class="">
<h2 data-start="3420" data-end="3475" class=""><strong data-start="3423" data-end="3475">5. Storage and Computational Benefits of Tensors</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3476" data-end="3533" class="">✅ <strong data-start="3478" data-end="3531">Why Use Tensors Instead of Lists or NumPy Arrays?</strong></p>
<ol data-start="3534" data-end="3856">
<li data-start="3534" data-end="3606" class="">
<p data-start="3537" data-end="3606" class=""><strong data-start="3537" data-end="3573">Optimized for Parallel Computing</strong> – Works efficiently with GPUs.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3607" data-end="3681" class="">
<p data-start="3610" data-end="3681" class=""><strong data-start="3610" data-end="3648">Supports Automatic Differentiation</strong> – Essential for deep learning.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3682" data-end="3754" class="">
<p data-start="3685" data-end="3754" class=""><strong data-start="3685" data-end="3706">Optimized Storage</strong> – Better memory allocation than Python lists.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3755" data-end="3856" class="">
<p data-start="3758" data-end="3856" class=""><strong data-start="3758" data-end="3785">Accelerated Computation</strong> – Tensor operations are <strong data-start="3810" data-end="3820">faster</strong> than NumPy due to GPU acceleration.</p>
</li>
</ol>

<hr data-start="4103" data-end="4106" class="">
<h2 data-start="4108" data-end="4142" class=""><strong data-start="4111" data-end="4142">6. Special Types of Tensors</strong></h2>
<ul data-start="4143" data-end="4399">
<li data-start="4143" data-end="4184" class="">
<p data-start="4145" data-end="4184" class=""><strong data-start="4145" data-end="4160">Zero Tensor</strong> → <code data-start="4163" data-end="4182">torch.zeros(3, 3)</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4185" data-end="4225" class="">
<p data-start="4187" data-end="4225" class=""><strong data-start="4187" data-end="4202">Ones Tensor</strong> → <code data-start="4205" data-end="4223">torch.ones(2, 2)</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4226" data-end="4268" class="">
<p data-start="4228" data-end="4268" class=""><strong data-start="4228" data-end="4245">Random Tensor</strong> → <code data-start="4248" data-end="4266">torch.rand(3, 3)</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4269" data-end="4316" class="">
<p data-start="4271" data-end="4316" class=""><strong data-start="4271" data-end="4297">Identity Matrix Tensor</strong> → <code data-start="4300" data-end="4314">torch.eye(3)</code></p>
</li>
<li data-start="4317" data-end="4399" class="">
<p data-start="4319" data-end="4399" class=""><strong data-start="4319" data-end="4344">Tensor with Gradients</strong> → <code data-start="4347" data-end="4367">requires_grad=True</code> (For autograd in deep learning)</p>
</li>
</ul>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h2 data-start="0" data-end="48" class=""><strong data-start="3" data-end="48">Feature Engineering: In-Depth Explanation</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="50" data-end="89" class=""><strong data-start="54" data-end="89">1. What is Feature Engineering?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="90" data-end="419" class="">Feature engineering is the <strong data-start="117" data-end="190">process of selecting, transforming, creating, and optimizing features</strong> from raw data to improve the performance of machine learning models. It involves <strong data-start="272" data-end="355">understanding the dataset, identifying relevant features, and transforming data</strong> into a format that enhances the predictive power of algorithms.</p>
<p data-start="421" data-end="465" class="">✅ <strong data-start="423" data-end="465">Key Objectives of Feature Engineering:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="466" data-end="596">
<li data-start="466" data-end="495" class="">
<p data-start="468" data-end="495" class="">Improve <strong data-start="476" data-end="494">model accuracy</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="496" data-end="523" class="">
<p data-start="498" data-end="523" class="">Reduce <strong data-start="505" data-end="522">training time</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="524" data-end="559" class="">
<p data-start="526" data-end="559" class="">Make <strong data-start="531" data-end="558">data more interpretable</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="560" data-end="596" class="">
<p data-start="562" data-end="596" class="">Help models <strong data-start="574" data-end="595">generalize better</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="598" data-end="601" class="">
<h2 data-start="603" data-end="643" class=""><strong data-start="606" data-end="641">2. Types of Feature Engineering</strong></h2>
<p data-start="645" data-end="776" class="">Feature engineering includes various techniques categorized as <strong data-start="708" data-end="775">feature transformation, feature selection, and feature creation</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="778" data-end="781" class="">
<h3 data-start="783" data-end="862" class=""><strong data-start="787" data-end="862">A. Feature Transformation (Changing Features for Better Representation)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="863" data-end="983" class="">Feature transformation involves modifying the scale, distribution, or form of features to <strong data-start="953" data-end="982">improve model performance</strong>.</p>
<h4 data-start="985" data-end="1028" class=""><strong data-start="990" data-end="1028">1. Normalization (Min-Max Scaling)</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="1029" data-end="1469">
<li data-start="1029" data-end="1109" class="">
<p data-start="1031" data-end="1109" class="">Rescales values between <strong data-start="1055" data-end="1066">0 and 1</strong> to ensure all features contribute equally.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1110" data-end="1177" class="">
<p data-start="1112" data-end="1122" class="">Formula:</p>

<h4 data-start="1835" data-end="1865" class=""><strong data-start="1840" data-end="1865">3. Log Transformation</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="1866" data-end="2033">
<li data-start="1866" data-end="1932" class="">
<p data-start="1868" data-end="1932" class="">Converts <strong data-start="1877" data-end="1901">skewed distributions</strong> into <strong data-start="1907" data-end="1931">normal distributions</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1933" data-end="1974" class="">
<p data-start="1935" data-end="1945" class="">Formula:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x' = \log(x + 1)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
</li>
<li data-start="1975" data-end="2033" class="">
<p data-start="1977" data-end="2033" class="">Used for <strong data-start="1986" data-end="2008">highly skewed data</strong> (e.g., prices, incomes).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h4 data-start="2035" data-end="2066" class=""><strong data-start="2040" data-end="2066">4. Polynomial Features</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="2067" data-end="2441">
<li data-start="2067" data-end="2141" class="">
<p data-start="2069" data-end="2141" class="">Generates <strong data-start="2079" data-end="2105">higher-degree features</strong> to capture nonlinear relationships.</p>

</li>

<h3 data-start="2448" data-end="2515" class=""><strong data-start="2452" data-end="2515">B. Feature Selection (Choosing the Most Important Features)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2516" data-end="2622" class="">Feature selection <strong data-start="2534" data-end="2598">removes irrelevant, redundant, or highly correlated features</strong> to prevent overfitting.</p>
<h4 data-start="2624" data-end="2671" class=""><strong data-start="2629" data-end="2671">5. Removing Highly Correlated Features</strong></h4>
<ul data-start="2672" data-end="2934">
<li data-start="2672" data-end="2738" class="">
<p data-start="2674" data-end="2738" class="">If two features are <strong data-start="2694" data-end="2717">strongly correlated</strong>, one can be removed.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2739" data-end="2934" class="">
<p data-start="2741" data-end="2757" class=""><strong data-start="2741" data-end="2757">Python Code:</strong></p>
<pre class="!overflow-visible" data-start="2760" data-end="2934"><div class="contain-inline-size rounded-md border-[0.5px] border-token-border-medium relative bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary"><div <hr data-start="5561" data-end="5564" class="">
<h2 data-start="5566" data-end="5613" class=""><strong data-start="5569" data-end="5613">4. Best Practices in Feature Engineering</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5614" data-end="5943" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5616" data-end="5639">Understand the data</strong> – Perform <strong data-start="5650" data-end="5685">Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)</strong>.<br data-start="5686" data-end="5689">
✅ <strong data-start="5691" data-end="5715">Use domain knowledge</strong> – Consider industry-specific insights.<br data-start="5754" data-end="5757">
✅ <strong data-start="5759" data-end="5781">Avoid data leakage</strong> – Ensure that <strong data-start="5796" data-end="5838">future data isn’t included in training</strong>.<br data-start="5839" data-end="5842">
✅ <strong data-start="5844" data-end="5884">Experiment with different techniques</strong> – Use <strong data-start="5891" data-end="5911">cross-validation</strong> to evaluate feature importance.</p>
<hr data-start="5945" data-end="5948" class="">

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="42" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="40">Feature Encoding: A Complete Guide</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="44" data-end="81" class=""><strong data-start="47" data-end="79">1. What is Feature Encoding?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="82" data-end="373" class="">Feature encoding is the process of <strong data-start="117" data-end="170">converting categorical data into numerical format</strong> so that machine learning models can process it effectively. Many ML algorithms (such as Linear Regression, SVM, and Neural Networks) work better with <strong data-start="321" data-end="341">numerical inputs</strong> rather than categorical data.</p>
<h3 data-start="375" data-end="419" class=""><strong data-start="379" data-end="417">Why is Feature Encoding Important?</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="420" data-end="650">
<li data-start="420" data-end="488" class="">
<p data-start="422" data-end="488" class="">ML models cannot directly process text or categorical variables.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="489" data-end="562" class="">
<p data-start="491" data-end="562" class="">Encoding allows models to <strong data-start="517" data-end="559">interpret categorical data efficiently</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="563" data-end="650" class="">
<p data-start="565" data-end="650" class="">Helps prevent <strong data-start="579" data-end="589">biases</strong> and ensures the model understands relationships correctly.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="652" data-end="655" class="">
<h2 data-start="657" data-end="694" class=""><strong data-start="660" data-end="692">2. Types of Feature Encoding</strong></h2>
<p data-start="696" data-end="932" class="">Feature encoding is broadly classified into two categories:<br data-start="755" data-end="758">
✅ <strong data-start="760" data-end="780">Nominal Encoding</strong> → For <strong data-start="787" data-end="811">unordered categories</strong> (e.g., "Red", "Blue", "Green").<br data-start="843" data-end="846">
✅ <strong data-start="848" data-end="868">Ordinal Encoding</strong> → For <strong data-start="875" data-end="897">ordered categories</strong> (e.g., "Low", "Medium", "High").</p>
<hr data-start="934" data-end="937" class="">
<h2 data-start="939" data-end="994" class=""><strong data-start="942" data-end="992">A. Nominal Encoding (For Unordered Categories)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="996" data-end="1079" class="">Nominal encoding is used for <strong data-start="1025" data-end="1078">categorical variables where order does not matter</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="1081" data-end="1114" class=""><strong data-start="1085" data-end="1114">1. One-Hot Encoding (OHE)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1115" data-end="1175" class=""><strong data-start="1115" data-end="1128">Best for:</strong> Small, low-cardinality categorical features.</p>
<p data-start="1177" data-end="1194" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1180" data-end="1192">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1195" data-end="1307">
<li data-start="1195" data-end="1265" class="">
<p data-start="1197" data-end="1265" class="">Converts each category into a <strong data-start="1227" data-end="1253">separate binary column</strong> (0 or 1).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1266" data-end="1307" class="">
<p data-start="1268" data-end="1307" class="">No numerical relationship is assumed.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1309" data-end="1326" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1312" data-end="1324">Example:</strong></p>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="1327" data-end="1563" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="1327" data-end="1375"><tr data-start="1327" data-end="1375"><th data-start="1327" data-end="1336">Color</th><th data-start="1336" data-end="1375">One-Hot Encoding (Red, Blue, Green)</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="1423" data-end="1563"><tr data-start="1423" data-end="1469"><td>Red</td><td>(1, 0, 0)</td></tr><tr data-start="1470" data-end="1516"><td>Blue</td><td>(0, 1, 0)</td></tr><tr data-start="1517" data-end="1563"><td>Green</td><td>(0, 0, 1)</td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<p data-start="1757" data-end="1877" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1760" data-end="1775">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="1775" data-end="1778">
✅ Prevents <strong data-start="1789" data-end="1814">ordinal relationships</strong> from being learned.<br data-start="1834" data-end="1837">
✅ Works well for <strong data-start="1854" data-end="1874">small categories</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="1879" data-end="1982" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1882" data-end="1900">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="1900" data-end="1903">
❌ Increases <strong data-start="1915" data-end="1933">dimensionality</strong> for many categories (curse of dimensionality).</p>
<hr data-start="1984" data-end="1987" class="">
<h3 data-start="1989" data-end="2014" class=""><strong data-start="1993" data-end="2014">2. Label Encoding</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2015" data-end="2069" class=""><strong data-start="2015" data-end="2028">Best for:</strong> High-cardinality categorical features.</p>
<p data-start="2071" data-end="2088" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2074" data-end="2086">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2089" data-end="2209">
<li data-start="2089" data-end="2137" class="">
<p data-start="2091" data-end="2137" class="">Converts categories into <strong data-start="2116" data-end="2134">integer values</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2138" data-end="2209" class="">
<p data-start="2140" data-end="2209" class="">Used when there is <strong data-start="2159" data-end="2182">no meaningful order</strong> but fewer unique values.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p data-start="2543" data-end="2673" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2546" data-end="2561">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="2561" data-end="2564">
✅ Requires <strong data-start="2575" data-end="2590">less memory</strong> than One-Hot Encoding.<br data-start="2613" data-end="2616">
✅ Works well for <strong data-start="2633" data-end="2670">decision trees and random forests</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="2675" data-end="2794" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2678" data-end="2696">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="2696" data-end="2699">
❌ Introduces an <strong data-start="2715" data-end="2750">artificial ordinal relationship</strong> (e.g., model may think "Green" &gt; "Blue").</p>
<hr data-start="2796" data-end="2799" class="">
<h3 data-start="2801" data-end="2826" class=""><strong data-start="2805" data-end="2826">3. Dummy Encoding</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2827" data-end="2910" class=""><strong data-start="2827" data-end="2840">Best for:</strong> Handling <strong data-start="2850" data-end="2900">categorical features while avoiding redundancy</strong> in OHE.</p>
<p data-start="2912" data-end="2929" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2915" data-end="2927">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2930" data-end="3074">
<li data-start="2930" data-end="3031" class="">
<p data-start="2932" data-end="3031" class="">Similar to <strong data-start="2943" data-end="2963">One-Hot Encoding</strong>, but removes <strong data-start="2977" data-end="3001">one redundant column</strong> to avoid multicollinearity.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3032" data-end="3074" class="">
<p data-start="3034" data-end="3074" class="">Uses <code data-start="3039" data-end="3044">n-1</code> columns for <code data-start="3057" data-end="3060">n</code> categories.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="3076" data-end="3093" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3079" data-end="3091">Example:</strong></p>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="3094" data-end="3302" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="3094" data-end="3135"><tr data-start="3094" data-end="3135"><th data-start="3094" data-end="3103">Color</th><th data-start="3103" data-end="3135">Dummy Encoding (Blue, Green)</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="3177" data-end="3302"><tr data-start="3177" data-end="3218"><td>Red</td><td>(0, 0)</td></tr><tr data-start="3219" data-end="3260"><td>Blue</td><td>(1, 0)</td></tr><tr data-start="3261" data-end="3302"><td>Green</td><td>(0, 1)</td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<p data-start="3411" data-end="3526" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3414" data-end="3429">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="3429" data-end="3432">
✅ Reduces <strong data-start="3442" data-end="3460">dimensionality</strong> compared to One-Hot Encoding.<br data-start="3490" data-end="3493">
✅ Avoids <strong data-start="3502" data-end="3523">multicollinearity</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="3528" data-end="3622" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3531" data-end="3549">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="3549" data-end="3552">
❌ Information loss can occur if the missing column is <strong data-start="3606" data-end="3619">important</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="3624" data-end="3627" class="">
<h3 data-start="3629" data-end="3666" class=""><strong data-start="3633" data-end="3666">4. Frequency (Count) Encoding</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3667" data-end="3721" class=""><strong data-start="3667" data-end="3680">Best for:</strong> High-cardinality categorical features.</p>
<p data-start="3723" data-end="3740" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3726" data-end="3738">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="3741" data-end="3859">
<li data-start="3741" data-end="3797" class="">
<p data-start="3743" data-end="3797" class="">Replaces categories with <strong data-start="3768" data-end="3794">their frequency counts</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3798" data-end="3859" class="">
<p data-start="3800" data-end="3859" class="">Works well when <strong data-start="3816" data-end="3856">the count of categories is important</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p data-start="4129" data-end="4264" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4132" data-end="4147">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="4147" data-end="4150">
✅ <strong data-start="4152" data-end="4178">Reduces dimensionality</strong> (compared to One-Hot Encoding).<br data-start="4210" data-end="4213">
✅ Works well when <strong data-start="4231" data-end="4261">category frequency matters</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="4266" data-end="4322" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4269" data-end="4287">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="4287" data-end="4290">
❌ Loses <strong data-start="4298" data-end="4319">category identity</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="4324" data-end="4327" class="">
<h2 data-start="4329" data-end="4382" class=""><strong data-start="4332" data-end="4380">B. Ordinal Encoding (For Ordered Categories)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4384" data-end="4433" class="">Used when categories <strong data-start="4405" data-end="4432">have a meaningful order</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="4435" data-end="4462" class=""><strong data-start="4439" data-end="4462">5. Ordinal Encoding</strong></h3>
<p data-start="4463" data-end="4525" class=""><strong data-start="4463" data-end="4476">Best for:</strong> Ordered categories like <strong data-start="4501" data-end="4522">Low, Medium, High</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="4527" data-end="4544" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4530" data-end="4542">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="4545" data-end="4607">
<li data-start="4545" data-end="4607" class="">
<p data-start="4547" data-end="4607" class="">Assigns <strong data-start="4555" data-end="4578">increasing integers</strong> to <strong data-start="4582" data-end="4604">ordered categories</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>

encoder = OrdinalEncoder(categories=[[</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Primary'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Secondary'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Tertiary'</span></span><span>]])

<p data-start="5126" data-end="5191" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5129" data-end="5144">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="5144" data-end="5147">
✅ Maintains <strong data-start="5159" data-end="5168">order</strong> in categorical data.</p>
<p data-start="5193" data-end="5281" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5196" data-end="5214">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="5214" data-end="5217">
❌ Can introduce <strong data-start="5233" data-end="5278">bias if gaps between values are not equal</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="5283" data-end="5286" class="">
<h3 data-start="5288" data-end="5330" class=""><strong data-start="5292" data-end="5330">6. Target Encoding (Mean Encoding)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="5331" data-end="5432" class=""><strong data-start="5331" data-end="5344">Best for:</strong> When there is a <strong data-start="5361" data-end="5429">correlation between categorical features and the target variable</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="5434" data-end="5451" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5437" data-end="5449">Concept:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5452" data-end="5595">
<li data-start="5452" data-end="5538" class="">
<p data-start="5454" data-end="5538" class="">Replaces each category with <strong data-start="5482" data-end="5517">the mean of the target variable</strong> for that category.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5539" data-end="5595" class="">
<p data-start="5541" data-end="5595" class="">Often used in <strong data-start="5555" data-end="5592">high-cardinality categorical data</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="5597" data-end="5614" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5600" data-end="5612">Example:</strong></p>

<p data-start="5985" data-end="6118" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5988" data-end="6003">Advantages:</strong><br data-start="6003" data-end="6006">
✅ Works well with <strong data-start="6024" data-end="6053">high-cardinality features</strong>.<br data-start="6054" data-end="6057">
✅ Maintains some <strong data-start="6074" data-end="6115">information about the target variable</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="6120" data-end="6217" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="6123" data-end="6141">Disadvantages:</strong><br data-start="6141" data-end="6144">
❌ <strong data-start="6146" data-end="6167">Data leakage risk</strong> – must be used carefully with cross-validation.</p>
<hr data-start="6219" data-end="6222" class="">
<h2 data-start="6224" data-end="6273" class=""><strong data-start="6227" data-end="6271">3. Choosing the Right Encoding Technique</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="6275" data-end="6923" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="6275" data-end="6317"><tr data-start="6275" data-end="6317"><th data-start="6275" data-end="6291">Encoding Type</th><th data-start="6291" data-end="6302">Best for</th><th data-start="6302" data-end="6309">Pros</th><th data-start="6309" data-end="6317">Cons</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="6359" data-end="6923"><tr data-start="6359" data-end="6450"><td><strong data-start="6361" data-end="6381">One-Hot Encoding</strong></td><td>Small categories</td><td>No ordering assumptions</td><td>High dimensionality</td></tr><tr data-start="6451" data-end="6533"><td><strong data-start="6453" data-end="6471">Label Encoding</strong></td><td>High-cardinality</td><td>Memory-efficient</td><td>Imposes false order</td></tr><tr data-start="6534" data-end="6617"><td><strong data-start="6536" data-end="6554">Dummy Encoding</strong></td><td>Small categories</td><td>Reduces collinearity</td><td>Information loss</td></tr><tr data-start="6618" data-end="6720"><td><strong data-start="6620" data-end="6642">Frequency Encoding</strong></td><td>Large categories</td><td>Captures category importance</td><td>Loses category identity</td></tr><tr data-start="6721" data-end="6804"><td><strong data-start="6723" data-end="6743">Ordinal Encoding</strong></td><td>Ordered data</td><td>Maintains ranking</td><td>Assumes equal spacing</td></tr><tr data-start="6805" data-end="6923"><td><strong data-start="6807" data-end="6826">Target Encoding</strong></td><td>Categories correlated with target</td><td>Uses information from target</td><td>High risk of data leakage</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="6925" data-end="6928" class="">
<h2 data-start="6930" data-end="6950" class=""><strong data-start="6933" data-end="6950">4. Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p data-start="6951" data-end="7137" class="">Feature encoding is <strong data-start="6971" data-end="6982">crucial</strong> in machine learning. Choosing the <strong data-start="7017" data-end="7042">right encoding method</strong> can <strong data-start="7047" data-end="7074">boost model performance</strong> while the wrong choice may introduce bias or inefficiencies.</p>
<p data-start="7139" data-end="7370" class="">✅ <strong data-start="7141" data-end="7215">If categorical variables have no order → Use One-Hot or Dummy Encoding</strong>.<br data-start="7216" data-end="7219">
✅ <strong data-start="7221" data-end="7283">If categorical variables have order → Use Ordinal Encoding</strong>.<br data-start="7284" data-end="7287">
✅ <strong data-start="7289" data-end="7367">For high-cardinality features → Use Frequency or Target Encoding carefully</strong>.</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="46" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="44">Column Transformer in Machine Learning</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="48" data-end="89" class=""><strong data-start="51" data-end="87">1. What is a Column Transformer?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="90" data-end="376" class="">A <strong data-start="92" data-end="114">Column Transformer</strong> in <strong data-start="118" data-end="134">scikit-learn</strong> allows applying <strong data-start="151" data-end="210">different preprocessing techniques to different columns</strong> in a dataset. This is useful when working with datasets containing <strong data-start="278" data-end="321">both numerical and categorical features</strong>, as they require different types of transformations.</p>
<h3 data-start="378" data-end="417" class=""><strong data-start="382" data-end="415">Why Use a Column Transformer?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="418" data-end="626" class="">✅ <strong data-start="420" data-end="464">Efficiently handles different data types</strong> (e.g., scaling numerical and encoding categorical).<br data-start="516" data-end="519">
✅ <strong data-start="521" data-end="553">Reduces manual preprocessing</strong> steps.<br data-start="560" data-end="563">
✅ <strong data-start="565" data-end="594">Improves code readability</strong> and <strong data-start="599" data-end="623">pipeline integration</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="628" data-end="631" class="">
<h2 data-start="633" data-end="679" class=""><strong data-start="636" data-end="677">2. Basic Syntax of Column Transformer</strong></h2>
<p data-start="681" data-end="786" class="">In <code data-start="684" data-end="701">sklearn.compose</code>, the <code data-start="707" data-end="726">ColumnTransformer</code> applies <strong data-start="735" data-end="783">specific transformations to specific columns</strong>.</p>

</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler, OneHotEncoder
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.impute </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> SimpleImputer

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define transformations</span></span><span>
num_transformer = StandardScaler()
cat_transformer = OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ignore'</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply transformations using ColumnTransformer</span></span><span>
preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(
    transformers=[
        (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'num'</span></span><span>, num_transformer, [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Age'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Salary'</span></span><span>]),  </span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Scaling numerical features</span></span><span>
        (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'cat'</span></span><span>, cat_transformer, [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Gender'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'City'</span></span><span>])  </span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Encoding categorical features</span></span><span>
    ]
)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="1351" data-end="1354" class="">
<h2 data-start="1356" data-end="1414" class=""><strong data-start="1359" data-end="1412">3. Types of Transformations in Column Transformer</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1416" data-end="1480" class="">You can apply various transformations in a Column Transformer:</p>

<li data-start="1528" data-end="1633" class="">
<p data-start="1530" data-end="1633" class=""><strong data-start="1530" data-end="1547">SimpleImputer</strong>: Replaces missing values with a strategy like mean, median, or most frequent value.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<h3 data-start="1731" data-end="1773" class=""><strong data-start="1735" data-end="1773">2. Scaling (Feature Normalization)</strong></h3>

</li>
</ul>

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> pandas </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> pd
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.compose </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> ColumnTransformer
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.pipeline </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> Pipeline
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.impute </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> SimpleImputer
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler, OneHotEncoder
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.ensemble </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> RandomForestClassifier

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Sample dataset</span></span><span>
data = pd.DataFrame({
    </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Age'</span></span><span>: [</span><span><span class="hljs-number">25</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">30</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">35</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-literal">None</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">45</span></span><span>],
    </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Salary'</span></span><span>: [</span><span><span class="hljs-number">50000</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">60000</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">70000</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">80000</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-literal">None</span></span><span>],
    </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Gender'</span></span><span>: [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Male'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Female'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Male'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Female'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Male'</span></span><span>],
    </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'City'</span></span><span>: [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Delhi'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Mumbai'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Noida'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Delhi'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Mumbai'</span></span><span>],
    </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Purchased'</span></span><span>: [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'No'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Yes'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Yes'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'No'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Yes'</span></span><span>]
})

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define target variable</span></span><span>
X = data.drop(columns=[</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Purchased'</span></span><span>])
y = data[</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Purchased'</span></span><span>]

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define preprocessing steps</span></span><span>
num_features = [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Age'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Salary'</span></span><span>]
cat_features = [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Gender'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'City'</span></span><span>]

num_transformer = Pipeline(steps=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'imputer'</span></span><span>, SimpleImputer(strategy=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'mean'</span></span><span>)),
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'scaler'</span></span><span>, StandardScaler())
])

cat_transformer = Pipeline(steps=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'encoder'</span></span><span>, OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ignore'</span></span><span>))
])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Combine transformations using ColumnTransformer</span></span><span>
preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(transformers=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'num'</span></span><span>, num_transformer, num_features),
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'cat'</span></span><span>, cat_transformer, cat_features)
])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Create a pipeline with a model</span></span><span>
model = Pipeline(steps=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'preprocessor'</span></span><span>, preprocessor),
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'classifier'</span></span><span>, RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>))
])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Split data and train the model</span></span><span>

<h2 data-start="47" data-end="95" class=""><strong data-start="50" data-end="93">1. What is a Machine Learning Pipeline?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="96" data-end="361" class="">A <strong data-start="98" data-end="132">Machine Learning (ML) pipeline</strong> is a sequence of <strong data-start="150" data-end="185">automated data processing steps</strong> that transform raw data into a <strong data-start="217" data-end="234">trained model</strong> ready for deployment. It streamlines and automates the <strong data-start="290" data-end="345">preprocessing, training, validation, and deployment</strong> of ML models.</p>
<h3 data-start="363" data-end="394" class=""><strong data-start="367" data-end="392">Why Use ML Pipelines?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="395" data-end="642" class="">✅ <strong data-start="397" data-end="419">Automates workflow</strong> → Reduces manual effort.<br data-start="444" data-end="447">
✅ <strong data-start="449" data-end="476">Ensures reproducibility</strong> → Standardizes the process.<br data-start="504" data-end="507">
✅ <strong data-start="509" data-end="547">Handles large datasets efficiently</strong> → Optimizes performance.<br data-start="572" data-end="575">
✅ <strong data-start="577" data-end="595">Reduces errors</strong> → Minimizes human mistakes in data handling.</p>

class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> Pipeline
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler, OneHotEncoder
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.impute </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> SimpleImputer
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.compose </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> ColumnTransformer
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.ensemble </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> RandomForestClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> pandas </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> pd

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Load dataset</span></span><span>
data = pd.read_csv(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'data.csv'</span></span><span>)
X = data.drop(columns=[</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'target'</span></span><span>])
y = data[</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'target'</span></span><span>]

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Split data</span></span><span>
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define preprocessing</span></span><span>
num_features = [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Age'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Salary'</span></span><span>]
cat_features = [</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Gender'</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'City'</span></span><span>]

preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(transformers=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'num'</span></span><span>, Pipeline([
        (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'imputer'</span></span><span>, SimpleImputer(strategy=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'mean'</span></span><span>)),
        (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'scaler'</span></span><span>, StandardScaler())
    ]), num_features),
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'cat'</span></span><span>, OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ignore'</span></span><span>), cat_features)
])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define the full pipeline</span></span><span>
pipeline = Pipeline(steps=[
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'preprocessor'</span></span><span>, preprocessor),
    (</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'classifier'</span></span><span>, RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>))
])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train model</span></span><span>
pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict and evaluate</span></span><span>
y_pred = pipeline.predict(X_test)
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> accuracy_score
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">f"Model Accuracy: <span class="hljs-subst">{accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)}</span></span></span><span>")
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>

<p data-start="81" data-end="359" class="">In <strong data-start="84" data-end="109">Machine Learning (ML)</strong>, data transformation is a crucial preprocessing step that helps normalize, scale, and reshape data to improve model performance. <hr data-start="361" data-end="364" class="">
<h2 data-start="366" data-end="441" class=""><strong data-start="369" data-end="439">1. FunctionTransformer (sklearn.preprocessing.FunctionTransformer)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="442" data-end="619" class=""><code data-start="442" data-end="463">FunctionTransformer</code> is a <strong data-start="469" data-end="501">flexible transformation tool</strong> in <code data-start="505" data-end="519">scikit-learn</code> that allows applying <strong data-start="541" data-end="567">custom transformations</strong> (log, square root, reciprocal, etc.) to datasets.</p>
<p data-start="621" data-end="657" class="">✅ <strong data-start="623" data-end="655">Why use FunctionTransformer?</strong></p>
<ul data-start="658" data-end="810">
<li data-start="658" data-end="716" class="">
<p data-start="660" data-end="716" class="">Easily <strong data-start="667" data-end="705">apply mathematical transformations</strong> to data.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="717" data-end="758" class="">
<p data-start="719" data-end="758" class="">Helps in <strong data-start="728" data-end="755">normalizing skewed data</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="759" data-end="810" class="">
<p data-start="761" data-end="810" class="">Avoids writing custom transformation functions.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<hr data-start="1228" data-end="1231" class="">
<h2 data-start="1233" data-end="1287" class=""><strong data-start="1236" data-end="1285">2. Log Transformation (Logarithmic Transform)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1288" data-end="1466" class="">The <strong data-start="1292" data-end="1309">log transform</strong> is commonly used for <strong data-start="1331" data-end="1364">normalizing right-skewed data</strong>. It compresses large values and expands small values, making the distribution <strong data-start="1443" data-end="1463">closer to normal</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="1468" data-end="1486" class=""><strong data-start="1472" data-end="1484">Formula:</strong></h3>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \log(X)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="1506" data-end="1510" class="">or</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mn>10</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \log_{10}(X)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="1535" data-end="1539" class="">or</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>for&nbsp;handling&nbsp;zero&nbsp;values</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \ln(X + 1) \quad (\text{for handling zero values})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop">ln</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">for&nbsp;handling&nbsp;zero&nbsp;values</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
<h3 data-start="1603" data-end="1639" class=""><strong data-start="1607" data-end="1637">When to Use Log Transform?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1640" data-end="1840" class="">✔ Data has <strong data-start="1651" data-end="1669">right-skewness</strong> (many small values, few large values).<br data-start="1708" data-end="1711">
✔ When dealing with <strong data-start="1731" data-end="1758">exponential growth data</strong>.<br data-start="1759" data-end="1762">
✔ Works well with <strong data-start="1780" data-end="1837">financial data, population data, and web traffic data</strong>.</p>

<h2 data-start="2070" data-end="2107" class=""><strong data-start="2073" data-end="2105">3. Reciprocal Transformation</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2108" data-end="2242" class="">The <strong data-start="2112" data-end="2141">reciprocal transformation</strong> is used to <strong data-start="2153" data-end="2163">invert</strong> the values in a dataset. It is useful for handling <strong data-start="2215" data-end="2239">skewed distributions</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="2244" data-end="2262" class=""><strong data-start="2248" data-end="2260">Formula:</strong></h3>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>X</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \frac{1}{X}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<h3 data-start="2287" data-end="2330" class=""><strong data-start="2291" data-end="2328">When to Use Reciprocal Transform?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2331" data-end="2505" class="">✔ Data has <strong data-start="2342" data-end="2357">heavy tails</strong> (extreme values).<br data-start="2375" data-end="2378">
✔ When values are large and <strong data-start="2406" data-end="2431">need to be compressed</strong>.<br data-start="2432" data-end="2435">
✔ Works well in <strong data-start="2451" data-end="2478">power-law distributions</strong> (e.g., city population).</p>

<h2 data-start="2680" data-end="2718" class=""><strong data-start="2683" data-end="2716">4. Square Root Transformation</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2719" data-end="2838" class="">The <strong data-start="2723" data-end="2753">square root transformation</strong> reduces the variance of high values while preserving the relationship in the data.</p>
<h3 data-start="2840" data-end="2858" class=""><strong data-start="2844" data-end="2856">Formula:</strong></h3>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mi>X</mi></msqrt></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \sqrt{X}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.04em; vertical-align: -0.0645em;"></span><span class="mord sqrt"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9755em;"><span class="svg-align" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord" style="padding-left: 0.833em;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span><span style="top: -2.9355em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="min-width: 0.853em; height: 1.08em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="1.08em" viewBox="0 0 400000 1080" preserveAspectRatio="xMinYMin slice"><path d="M95,702

<hr data-start="3201" data-end="3204" class="">
<h2 data-start="3206" data-end="3242" class=""><strong data-start="3209" data-end="3240">5. Cube Root Transformation</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3243" data-end="3351" class="">A more flexible version of square root transformation that works on <strong data-start="3311" data-end="3348">both positive and negative values</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="3353" data-end="3371" class=""><strong data-start="3357" data-end="3369">Formula:</strong></h3>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>X</mi><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = X^{\frac{1}{3}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; <h3 data-start="3400" data-end="3442" class=""><strong data-start="3404" data-end="3440">When to Use Cube Root Transform?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3443" data-end="3543" class="">✔ Data is <strong data-start="3453" data-end="3474">moderately skewed</strong>.<br data-start="3475" data-end="3478">

<hr data-start="3693" data-end="3696" class="">
<h2 data-start="3698" data-end="3754" class=""><strong data-start="3701" data-end="3752">6. Power Transformation (Box-Cox &amp; Yeo-Johnson)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3755" data-end="3861" class="">The <strong data-start="3759" data-end="3783">power transformation</strong> is a family of functions that stabilize variance and make data more normal.</p>
<h3 data-start="3863" data-end="3899" class=""><strong data-start="3867" data-end="3897">6.1 Box-Cox Transformation</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3900" data-end="3955" class="">Only works for <strong data-start="3915" data-end="3934">positive values</strong> and is defined as:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mi>λ</mi></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>λ</mi></mfrac><mo separator="true">,</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>if&nbsp;</mtext><mi>λ</mi><mo mathvariant="normal">≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \frac{X^\lambda - 1}{\lambda}, \quad \text{if } \lambda \neq 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2121em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.5261em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em;
