<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>if&nbsp;</mtext><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \log(X), \quad \text{if } \lambda = 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">if&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>

<hr data-start="4281" data-end="4284" class="">
<h3 data-start="4286" data-end="4326" class=""><strong data-start="4290" data-end="4324">6.2 Yeo-Johnson Transformation</strong></h3>
<p data-start="4327" data-end="4395" class="">Works for <strong data-start="4337" data-end="4374">both positive and negative values</strong> and is defined as:</p>

<h2 data-start="5436" data-end="5491" class=""><strong data-start="5439" data-end="5489">9. Logit Transformation (For Probability Data)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5492" data-end="5563" class="">Used when <strong data-start="5502" data-end="5535">data is in probability format</strong> (values between 0 and 1).</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h2 data-start="0" data-end="56" class=""><strong data-start="3" data-end="54">Curse of Dimensionality: A Complete Explanation</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="58" data-end="107" class=""><strong data-start="62" data-end="105">📌 What is the Curse of Dimensionality?</strong></h3>
<p data-start="108" data-end="422" class="">The <strong data-start="112" data-end="139">Curse of Dimensionality</strong> refers to the various problems that arise when working with <strong data-start="200" data-end="225">high-dimensional data</strong> (i.e., data with many features or dimensions). As the number of dimensions increases, the data becomes <strong data-start="329" data-end="339">sparse</strong>, and traditional machine learning algorithms struggle to find meaningful patterns.</p>
<p data-start="424" data-end="442" class="">It mainly affects:</p>
<ul data-start="443" data-end="540">
<li data-start="443" data-end="465" class="">
<p data-start="445" data-end="465" class=""><strong data-start="445" data-end="465">Machine Learning</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="466" data-end="484" class="">
<p data-start="468" data-end="484" class=""><strong data-start="468" data-end="484">Optimization</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="485" data-end="517" class="">
<p data-start="487" data-end="517" class=""><strong data-start="487" data-end="517">Data Storage &amp; Computation</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="518" data-end="540" class="">
<p data-start="520" data-end="540" class=""><strong data-start="520" data-end="540">Distance Metrics</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="542" data-end="545" class="">
<h2 data-start="547" data-end="599" class=""><strong data-start="550" data-end="597">1️⃣ Why is High-Dimensional Data a Problem?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="600" data-end="681" class="">When the number of features (<strong data-start="629" data-end="643">dimensions</strong>) increases, several challenges occur:</p>
<h3 data-start="683" data-end="735" class=""><strong data-start="687" data-end="735">1.1 Increased Sparsity (Data Becomes Sparse)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="736" data-end="935" class="">🔹 As dimensions increase, data points spread far apart in a larger space. This sparsity reduces the effectiveness of algorithms that rely on distance calculations, like <strong data-start="906" data-end="934">KNN, clustering, and SVM</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="937" data-end="954" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="940" data-end="951">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="955" data-end="1155">
<li data-start="955" data-end="999" class="">
<p data-start="957" data-end="999" class="">In <strong data-start="960" data-end="966">2D</strong>, points may be well-clustered.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1000" data-end="1055" class="">
<p data-start="1002" data-end="1055" class="">In <strong data-start="1005" data-end="1012">10D</strong>, the same points are much farther apart.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1056" data-end="1155" class="">
<p data-start="1058" data-end="1155" class="">In <strong data-start="1061" data-end="1070">1000D</strong>, the points are so far apart that every point seems <strong data-start="1123" data-end="1142">equally distant</strong> from others.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1157" data-end="1265" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="1160" data-end="1175">Consequence</strong>: Distance-based models (like KNN) fail to differentiate between close and distant points.</p>
<hr data-start="1267" data-end="1270" class="">
<h3 data-start="1272" data-end="1331" class=""><strong data-start="1276" data-end="1331">1.2 Exponential Increase in Volume (Data Explosion)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1332" data-end="1485" class="">🔹 The <strong data-start="1339" data-end="1373">number of possible data points</strong> grows <strong data-start="1380" data-end="1397">exponentially</strong> as dimensions increase.<br data-start="1421" data-end="1424">
🔹 If each dimension has only <strong data-start="1454" data-end="1476">10 possible values</strong>, then:</p>
<ul data-start="1488" data-end="1691">
<li data-start="1488" data-end="1542" class="">
<p data-start="1490" data-end="1542" class="">In <strong data-start="1493" data-end="1499">2D</strong>, there are <strong data-start="1511" data-end="1518">100</strong> possible data points.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1545" data-end="1602" class="">
<p data-start="1547" data-end="1602" class="">In <strong data-start="1550" data-end="1557">10D</strong>, there are <strong data-start="1569" data-end="1583">10 billion</strong> possible points.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1605" data-end="1691" class="">
<p data-start="1607" data-end="1691" class="">In <strong data-start="1610" data-end="1618">100D</strong>, the number is so large that it becomes <strong data-start="1659" data-end="1690">impossible to store/process</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1693" data-end="1760" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="1696" data-end="1711">Consequence</strong>: Computational complexity increases drastically.</p>
<hr data-start="1762" data-end="1765" class="">
<h3 data-start="1767" data-end="1808" class=""><strong data-start="1771" data-end="1808">1.3 Distance Metrics Lose Meaning</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1809" data-end="2066" class="">🔹 Most ML models rely on <strong data-start="1835" data-end="1860">distance calculations</strong> (e.g., Euclidean distance, Manhattan distance).<br data-start="1908" data-end="1911">
🔹 In high dimensions, <strong data-start="1934" data-end="1971">all points appear equally distant</strong> from each other.<br data-start="1988" data-end="1991">
🔹 This makes clustering, nearest neighbors, and kernel methods unreliable.</p>
<p data-start="2068" data-end="2135" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="2071" data-end="2086">Consequence</strong>: Distance-based models stop working efficiently.</p>
<p data-start="2137" data-end="2152" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2140" data-end="2151">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="2153" data-end="2355">
<li data-start="2153" data-end="2250" class="">
<p data-start="2155" data-end="2250" class="">In <strong data-start="2158" data-end="2176">low dimensions</strong>, the nearest neighbor is significantly closer than the farthest neighbor.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2251" data-end="2355" class="">
<p data-start="2253" data-end="2355" class="">In <strong data-start="2256" data-end="2275">high dimensions</strong>, the difference between the closest and farthest neighbors approaches <strong data-start="2346" data-end="2354">zero</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2357" data-end="2360" class="">
<h3 data-start="2362" data-end="2412" class=""><strong data-start="2366" data-end="2412">1.4 Overfitting in Machine Learning Models</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2413" data-end="2684" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2416" data-end="2454">More dimensions mean more features</strong>, and more features <strong data-start="2474" data-end="2497">increase complexity</strong>.<br data-start="2498" data-end="2501">
🔹 Models may start memorizing the data instead of learning useful patterns.<br data-start="2577" data-end="2580">
🔹 This leads to <strong data-start="2597" data-end="2612">overfitting</strong>, where the model performs well on training data but poorly on new data.</p>
<p data-start="2686" data-end="2773" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="2689" data-end="2704">Consequence</strong>: Poor generalization, high variance, and low model interpretability.</p>
<hr data-start="2775" data-end="2778" class="">
<h3 data-start="2780" data-end="2826" class=""><strong data-start="2784" data-end="2826">1.5 Increased Computational Complexity</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2827" data-end="3055" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2830" data-end="2869">More dimensions = More computations</strong> for ML models.<br data-start="2884" data-end="2887">
🔹 Complex models like <strong data-start="2910" data-end="2955">Random Forest, XGBoost, and Deep Learning</strong> take longer to train.<br data-start="2977" data-end="2980">
🔹 Some algorithms <strong data-start="2999" data-end="3016">fail to scale</strong> beyond a certain number of dimensions.</p>
<p data-start="3057" data-end="3131" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="3060" data-end="3075">Consequence</strong>: Training time and memory usage increase significantly.</p>
<hr data-start="3133" data-end="3136" class="">
<h2 data-start="3138" data-end="3181" class=""><strong data-start="3141" data-end="3181">2️⃣ Types of Curse of Dimensionality</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3182" data-end="3281" class="">The curse of dimensionality manifests in different ways across ML, data analysis, and optimization.</p>
<h3 data-start="3283" data-end="3308" class=""><strong data-start="3287" data-end="3308">2.1 Data Sparsity</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3309" data-end="3478" class="">🔹 When data points spread too thinly in high dimensions, models struggle to find patterns.<br data-start="3400" data-end="3403">
🔹 Density-based methods (like <strong data-start="3434" data-end="3455">DBSCAN clustering</strong>) fail due to sparsity.</p>
<p data-start="3480" data-end="3619" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3483" data-end="3494">Example</strong>: In <strong data-start="3499" data-end="3505">2D</strong>, you can easily group similar customers. In <strong data-start="3550" data-end="3558">100D</strong>, every customer seems unique, making segmentation difficult.</p>
<hr data-start="3621" data-end="3624" class="">
<h3 data-start="3626" data-end="3660" class=""><strong data-start="3630" data-end="3660">2.2 Distance Concentration</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3661" data-end="3845" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3664" data-end="3717">In high dimensions, distances become almost equal</strong> for all points.<br data-start="3733" data-end="3736">
🔹 This affects algorithms relying on <strong data-start="3774" data-end="3795">nearest neighbors</strong>, such as <strong data-start="3805" data-end="3844">KNN, clustering, and kernel methods</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="3847" data-end="3862" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="3850" data-end="3861">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="3863" data-end="3993">
<li data-start="3863" data-end="3915" class="">
<p data-start="3865" data-end="3915" class="">In <strong data-start="3868" data-end="3874">2D</strong>, nearest neighbors are clearly distinct.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3916" data-end="3993" class="">
<p data-start="3918" data-end="3993" class="">In <strong data-start="3921" data-end="3929">100D</strong>, the farthest and closest points have almost the same distance.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="3995" data-end="3998" class="">
<h3 data-start="4000" data-end="4030" class=""><strong data-start="4004" data-end="4030">2.3 Feature Redundancy</strong></h3>
<p data-start="4031" data-end="4178" class="">🔹 Many features may <strong data-start="4052" data-end="4082">not add useful information</strong> but still increase dimensionality.<br data-start="4117" data-end="4120">
🔹 This happens due to <strong data-start="4143" data-end="4175">correlation between features</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="4180" data-end="4197" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4183" data-end="4194">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="4198" data-end="4333">
<li data-start="4198" data-end="4258" class="">
<p data-start="4200" data-end="4258" class="">Height in <strong data-start="4210" data-end="4216">cm</strong> and height in <strong data-start="4231" data-end="4241">inches</strong> are redundant.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4259" data-end="4333" class="">
<p data-start="4261" data-end="4333" class="">Too many features can <strong data-start="4283" data-end="4301">increase noise</strong> instead of improving the model.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4335" data-end="4338" class="">
<h3 data-start="4340" data-end="4369" class=""><strong data-start="4344" data-end="4369">2.4 Model Overfitting</strong></h3>
<p data-start="4370" data-end="4596" class="">🔹 High-dimensional data makes models too complex.<br data-start="4420" data-end="4423">
🔹 The model memorizes training data instead of learning useful patterns.<br data-start="4496" data-end="4499">
🔹 This causes <strong data-start="4514" data-end="4529">overfitting</strong>, where the model performs well on training but fails on test data.</p>
<p data-start="4598" data-end="4615" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4601" data-end="4612">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="4616" data-end="4684">
<li data-start="4616" data-end="4684" class="">
<p data-start="4618" data-end="4684" class="">A neural network with <strong data-start="4640" data-end="4659">too many layers</strong> overfits small datasets.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4686" data-end="4689" class="">
<h2 data-start="4691" data-end="4746" class=""><strong data-start="4694" data-end="4746">3️⃣ How to Overcome the Curse of Dimensionality?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4747" data-end="4838" class="">There are several techniques to <strong data-start="4779" data-end="4804">reduce dimensionality</strong> and improve ML model performance.</p>
<h3 data-start="4840" data-end="4899" class=""><strong data-start="4844" data-end="4899">3.1 Feature Selection (Choosing Important Features)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="4900" data-end="4995" class="">🔹 Remove <strong data-start="4910" data-end="4946">irrelevant or redundant features</strong> to reduce dimensionality.<br data-start="4972" data-end="4975">
🔹 Common methods:</p>
<ul data-start="4998" data-end="5188">
<li data-start="4998" data-end="5056" class="">
<p data-start="5000" data-end="5056" class=""><strong data-start="5000" data-end="5022">Variance Threshold</strong> (removes low-variance features)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5059" data-end="5124" class="">
<p data-start="5061" data-end="5124" class=""><strong data-start="5061" data-end="5085">Correlation Analysis</strong> (removes highly correlated features)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5127" data-end="5188" class="">
<p data-start="5129" data-end="5188" class=""><strong data-start="5129" data-end="5186">Chi-Square Test, Mutual Information, Lasso Regression</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>

<hr data-start="5397" data-end="5400" class="">
<h3 data-start="5402" data-end="5474" class=""><strong data-start="5406" data-end="5474">3.2 Feature Extraction (Creating New Lower-Dimensional Features)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="5475" data-end="5544" class="">Instead of removing features, <strong data-start="5505" data-end="5543">transform them into fewer features</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="5546" data-end="5588" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5548" data-end="5586">Principal Component Analysis (PCA)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5589" data-end="5730">
<li data-start="5589" data-end="5664" class="">
<p data-start="5591" data-end="5664" class="">Converts <strong data-start="5600" data-end="5631">n features → fewer features</strong> while retaining most variance.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5665" data-end="5730" class="">
<p data-start="5667" data-end="5730" class="">Used in <strong data-start="5675" data-end="5727">image compression, text analysis, bioinformatics</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p data-start="5897" data-end="5958" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5899" data-end="5956">Autoencoders (Neural Network-Based Feature Reduction)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5959" data-end="6025">
<li data-start="5959" data-end="6025" class="">
<p data-start="5961" data-end="6025" class="">Uses a <strong data-start="5968" data-end="5997">compressed representation</strong> of data in neural networks.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="6027" data-end="6030" class="">
<h3 data-start="6032" data-end="6075" class=""><strong data-start="6036" data-end="6075">3.3 Dimensionality-Aware Algorithms</strong></h3>
<p data-start="6076" data-end="6302" class="">Some algorithms <strong data-start="6092" data-end="6125">handle high dimensions better</strong>:
✔ <strong data-start="6129" data-end="6146">Random Forest</strong> (less sensitive to irrelevant features)<br data-start="6186" data-end="6189">
✔ <strong data-start="6191" data-end="6232">Gradient Boosting (XGBoost, LightGBM)</strong><br data-start="6232" data-end="6235">
✔ <strong data-start="6237" data-end="6300">Deep Learning (CNNs work well with high-dimensional images)</strong></p>
<hr data-start="6304" data-end="6307" class="">
<h3 data-start="6309" data-end="6374" class=""><strong data-start="6313" data-end="6374">3.4 Regularization (Avoid Overfitting in High Dimensions)</strong></h3>
<p data-start="6375" data-end="6442" class="">Regularization <strong data-start="6390" data-end="6418">reduces model complexity</strong> to prevent overfitting.</p>
<p data-start="6444" data-end="6488" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6446" data-end="6486">Lasso Regression (L1 Regularization)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="6489" data-end="6571">
<li data-start="6489" data-end="6571" class="">
<p data-start="6491" data-end="6571" class="">Shrinks unimportant feature coefficients to <strong data-start="6535" data-end="6543">zero</strong>, effectively removing them.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="6573" data-end="6617" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6575" data-end="6615">Ridge Regression (L2 Regularization)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="6618" data-end="6678">
<li data-start="6618" data-end="6678" class="">
<p data-start="6620" data-end="6678" class="">Penalizes large weights, helping models generalize better.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<hr data-start="6819" data-end="6822" class="">
<h3 data-start="6824" data-end="6874" class=""><strong data-start="6828" data-end="6874">3.5 Kernel Trick for High-Dimensional Data</strong></h3>
<p data-start="6875" data-end="7044" class="">✔ <strong data-start="6877" data-end="6902">SVM with Kernel Trick</strong>: Works in <strong data-start="6913" data-end="6936">infinite dimensions</strong> using <strong data-start="6943" data-end="6957">RBF kernel</strong>.<br data-start="6958" data-end="6961">
✔ <strong data-start="6963" data-end="6979">T-SNE &amp; UMAP</strong>: Reduce high-dimensional data to <strong data-start="7013" data-end="7043">2D or 3D for visualization</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="7046" data-end="7049" class="">
<h2 data-start="7051" data-end="7069" class=""><strong data-start="7054" data-end="7069">4️⃣ Summary</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="7070" data-end="7510" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="7070" data-end="7113"><tr data-start="7070" data-end="7113"><th data-start="7070" data-end="7084"><strong data-start="7072" data-end="7083">Problem</strong></th><th data-start="7084" data-end="7097"><strong data-start="7086" data-end="7096">Impact</strong></th><th data-start="7097" data-end="7113"><strong data-start="7099" data-end="7111">Solution</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="7155" data-end="7510"><tr data-start="7155" data-end="7234"><td><strong data-start="7157" data-end="7169">Sparsity</strong></td><td>Distance-based models fail</td><td>Use <strong data-start="7205" data-end="7232">Feature Selection &amp; PCA</strong></td></tr><tr data-start="7235" data-end="7344"><td><strong data-start="7237" data-end="7263">Distance Concentration</strong></td><td>All distances become equal</td><td>Use <strong data-start="7299" data-end="7342">Alternative Metrics (cosine similarity)</strong></td></tr><tr data-start="7345" data-end="7426"><td><strong data-start="7347" data-end="7362">Overfitting</strong></td><td>Poor generalization</td><td>Use <strong data-start="7391" data-end="7424">Regularization (Lasso, Ridge)</strong></td></tr><tr data-start="7427" data-end="7510"><td><strong data-start="7429" data-end="7457">Computational Complexity</strong></td><td>Slow training</td><td>Use <strong data-start="7480" data-end="7508">Dimensionality Reduction</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="66" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="64">Principal Component Analysis (PCA): A Complete Explanation</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="68" data-end="90" class=""><strong data-start="71" data-end="90">📌 What is PCA?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="91" data-end="301" class=""><strong data-start="91" data-end="129">Principal Component Analysis (PCA)</strong> is a <strong data-start="135" data-end="163">dimensionality reduction</strong> technique that transforms high-dimensional data into fewer dimensions while retaining most of the <strong data-start="262" data-end="284">important variance</strong> (information).</p>
<p data-start="303" data-end="484" class="">PCA is widely used in:<br data-start="325" data-end="328">
✅ <strong data-start="330" data-end="350">Machine Learning</strong> (for handling high-dimensional data)<br data-start="387" data-end="390">
✅ <strong data-start="392" data-end="413">Image Compression</strong><br data-start="413" data-end="416">
✅ <strong data-start="418" data-end="455">Visualization (reducing to 2D/3D)</strong><br data-start="455" data-end="458">
✅ <strong data-start="460" data-end="482">Feature Extraction</strong></p>
<hr data-start="486" data-end="489" class="">
<h2 data-start="491" data-end="521" class=""><strong data-start="494" data-end="521">1️⃣ Why Do We Need PCA?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="522" data-end="955" class="">When dealing with <strong data-start="540" data-end="565">high-dimensional data</strong>, several issues arise:<br data-start="588" data-end="591">
🔹 <strong data-start="594" data-end="622">Computational Complexity</strong>: Training models on large datasets becomes slow.<br data-start="671" data-end="674">
🔹 <strong data-start="677" data-end="704">Curse of Dimensionality</strong>: Too many features make distance-based algorithms unreliable.<br data-start="766" data-end="769">
🔹 <strong data-start="772" data-end="794">Redundant Features</strong>: Some features might be <strong data-start="819" data-end="833">correlated</strong> and unnecessary.<br data-start="850" data-end="853">
🔹 <strong data-start="856" data-end="871">Overfitting</strong>: More dimensions can lead to models memorizing data instead of learning patterns.</p>
<p data-start="957" data-end="1060" class="">👉 <strong data-start="960" data-end="987">PCA solves these issues</strong> by reducing dimensionality while keeping the most important information.</p>
<hr data-start="1062" data-end="1065" class="">
<h2 data-start="1067" data-end="1092" class=""><strong data-start="1070" data-end="1092">2️⃣ How PCA Works?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1093" data-end="1243" class="">PCA <strong data-start="1097" data-end="1111">transforms</strong> the original features into a new set of <strong data-start="1152" data-end="1200">orthogonal components (principal components)</strong> ordered by how much variance they capture.</p>
<h3 data-start="1245" data-end="1283" class=""><strong data-start="1249" data-end="1283">🔹 Step-by-Step Process of PCA</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1284" data-end="1314" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1288" data-end="1312">Standardize the Data</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1318" data-end="1455">
<li data-start="1318" data-end="1391" class="">
<p data-start="1320" data-end="1391" class="">Since PCA is affected by different feature scales, we normalize data.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1395" data-end="1455" class="">
<p data-start="1397" data-end="1455" class="">We subtract the mean and divide by the standard deviation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1457" data-end="1496" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1461" data-end="1494">Compute the Covariance Matrix</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1500" data-end="1642">
<li data-start="1500" data-end="1563" class="">
<p data-start="1502" data-end="1563" class="">The covariance matrix shows relationships between features.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1567" data-end="1642" class="">
<p data-start="1569" data-end="1642" class="">A high covariance means features are correlated (which we aim to remove).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1644" data-end="1690" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1648" data-end="1688">Compute Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1694" data-end="1819">
<li data-start="1694" data-end="1750" class="">
<p data-start="1696" data-end="1750" class="">Eigenvectors represent new <strong data-start="1723" data-end="1747">principal components</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1754" data-end="1819" class="">
<p data-start="1756" data-end="1819" class="">Eigenvalues show how much <strong data-start="1782" data-end="1794">variance</strong> each component captures.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1821" data-end="1864" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1825" data-end="1862">Select Top k Principal Components</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1868" data-end="1995">
<li data-start="1868" data-end="1919" class="">
<p data-start="1870" data-end="1919" class="">We choose components that retain most variance.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1923" data-end="1995" class="">
<p data-start="1925" data-end="1995" class="">The cumulative variance plot helps decide how many components to keep.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1997" data-end="2044" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="2001" data-end="2042">Transform Data into New Feature Space</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2048" data-end="2120">
<li data-start="2048" data-end="2120" class="">
<p data-start="2050" data-end="2120" class="">The original data is projected onto the selected principal components.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2122" data-end="2125" class="">
<h2 data-start="2127" data-end="2168" class=""><strong data-start="2130" data-end="2166">3️⃣ PCA Formulas and Mathematics</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="2170" data-end="2213" class=""><strong data-start="2174" data-end="2211">🔹 Step 1: Standardizing the Data</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2214" data-end="2259" class="">Each feature <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is standardized using:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>X</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mi>σ</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X' = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8019em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8019em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; <p data-start="2294" data-end="2302" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="2303" data-end="2372">
<li data-start="2303" data-end="2334" class="">
<p data-start="2305" data-end="2334" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span></span></span></span> = Mean of feature</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2335" data-end="2372" class="">
<p data-start="2337" data-end="2372" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>σ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sigma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">σ</span></span></span></span> = Standard deviation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2374" data-end="2377" class="">
<h3 data-start="2379" data-end="2425" class=""><strong data-start="2383" data-end="2423">🔹 Step 2: Compute Covariance Matrix</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2426" data-end="2495" class="">The <strong data-start="2430" data-end="2451">covariance matrix</strong> measures the relationship between features:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>n</mi></mfrac><mo>∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>X</mi><mo>ˉ</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>X</mi><mo>ˉ</mo></mover><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>T</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C = \frac{1}{n} \sum (X - \bar{X})(X - \bar{X})^T</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8201em;"><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span><span style="top: -3.2523em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">ˉ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8913em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; <p data-start="2554" data-end="2562" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="2563" data-end="2726">
<li data-start="2563" data-end="2627" class="">
<p data-start="2565" data-end="2627" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span> is the <strong data-start="2580" data-end="2607">d × d covariance matrix</strong> (for d features).</p>

<li data-start="2628" data-end="2726" class="">
<p data-start="2630" data-end="2726" class="">Each value <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C_{ij}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9694em; </li>

<hr data-start="2728" data-end="2731" class="">
<h3 data-start="2733" data-end="2788" class=""><strong data-start="2737" data-end="2786">🔹 Step 3: Compute Eigenvalues &amp; Eigenvectors</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2789" data-end="2884" class="">PCA finds the <strong data-start="2803" data-end="2819">eigenvectors</strong> (principal components) and <strong data-start="2847" data-end="2862">eigenvalues</strong> (variance explained):</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>λ</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C v = \lambda v</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="2909" data-end="2917" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="2918" data-end="3060">
<li data-start="2918" data-end="2949" class="">
<p data-start="2920" data-end="2949" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span> = Covariance matrix</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2950" data-end="2997" class="">
<p data-start="2952" data-end="2997" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">v</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span></span></span></span> = Eigenvector (principal component)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2998" data-end="3060" class="">
<p data-start="3000" data-end="3060" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span></span></span></span> = Eigenvalue (variance explained by component)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="3062" data-end="3065" class="">
<h3 data-start="3067" data-end="3121" class=""><strong data-start="3071" data-end="3119">🔹 Step 4: Select Top k Principal Components</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3122" data-end="3186" class="">To retain <strong data-start="3132" data-end="3148">k components</strong> that explain <strong data-start="3162" data-end="3177">X% variance</strong>, we use:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>k</mi></munderover><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>d</mi></munderover><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{k} \lambda_i}{\sum_{j=1}^{d} \lambda_j} \times 100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.9935em; vertical-align: -1.3148em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.6787em;"><span style="top: -2.121em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop"><span class="mop op-symbol small-op" style="position: relative; top: 0em;">∑</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.989em;"><span style="top: -2.4003em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05724em;">j</span><span class="mrel mtight">=</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4358em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05724em;">j</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.6897em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop"><span class="mop op-symbol small-op" style="position: relative; top: 0em;">∑</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.989em;"><span style="top: -2.4003em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span><span class="mrel mtight">=</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2997em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3148em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="3264" data-end="3272" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="3273" data-end="3370">
<li data-start="3273" data-end="3329" class="">
<p data-start="3275" data-end="3329" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> = Eigenvalues of selected components</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3330" data-end="3370" class="">
<p data-start="3332" data-end="3370" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span> = Total number of dimensions</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="3372" data-end="3449" class="">👉 If we set <strong data-start="3385" data-end="3394">k = 2</strong>, we can <strong data-start="3403" data-end="3416">visualize</strong> high-dimensional data in <strong data-start="3442" data-end="3448">2D</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="3451" data-end="3454" class="">
<h3 data-start="3456" data-end="3493" class=""><strong data-start="3460" data-end="3493">🔹 Step 5: Transform the Data</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3494" data-end="3557" class="">We project the data onto the selected <strong data-start="3532" data-end="3556">principal components</strong>:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>X</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>w</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X_{new} = X \cdot V_k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="3588" data-end="3596" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="3597" data-end="3733">
<li data-start="3597" data-end="3624" class="">
<p data-start="3599" data-end="3624" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span> = Original data</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3625" data-end="3678" class="">
<p data-start="3627" data-end="3678" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V_k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> = Matrix of selected <strong data-start="3658" data-end="3663">k</strong> eigenvectors</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3679" data-end="3733" class="">
<p data-start="3681" data-end="3733" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>X</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>w</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X_{new}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">e</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> = Transformed lower-dimensional data</p>
</li>
</ul>

class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> np
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> matplotlib.pyplot </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> plt
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.decomposition </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> PCA
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Generate sample data (5 features)</span></span><span>
np.random.seed(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
X = np.random.rand(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>)  </span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># 100 samples, 5 features</span></span><span>

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Standardize data</span></span><span>
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply PCA (reduce to 2 components)</span></span><span>
pca = PCA(n_components=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">2</span></span><span>)
X_pca = pca.fit_transform(X_scaled)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Explained variance</span></span><span>
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Explained Variance:"</span></span><span>, pca.explained_variance_ratio_)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Scatter plot of reduced dimensions</span></span><span>
plt.scatter(X_pca[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>], X_pca[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>], c=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'blue'</span></span><span>, alpha=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.5</span></span><span>)
plt.xlabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Principal Component 1"</span></span><span>)
plt.ylabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Principal Component 2"</span></span><span>)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"PCA - Reduced Data"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="4563" data-end="4578" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4565" data-end="4576">Output:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="4579" data-end="4727">
<li data-start="4579" data-end="4666" class="">
<p data-start="4581" data-end="4666" class="">The <strong data-start="4585" data-end="4613">explained variance ratio</strong> tells how much information each component retains.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4667" data-end="4727" class="">
<p data-start="4669" data-end="4727" class="">The <strong data-start="4673" data-end="4689">scatter plot</strong> shows the transformed data in <strong data-start="4720" data-end="4726">2D</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4729" data-end="4732" class="">
<h2 data-start="4734" data-end="4801" class=""><strong data-start="4737" data-end="4801">5️⃣ Choosing the Number of Principal Components (Scree Plot)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4802" data-end="4873" class="">To decide how many components to keep, we plot <strong data-start="4849" data-end="4872">cumulative variance</strong>:</p>

class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> np
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> matplotlib.pyplot </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> plt
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.decomposition </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> PCA
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Standardize data</span></span><span>
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply PCA</span></span><span>
pca = PCA()
X_pca = pca.fit_transform(X_scaled)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot cumulative explained variance</span></span><span>
plt.plot(np.cumsum(pca.explained_variance_ratio_))
plt.xlabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Number of Components"</span></span><span>)
plt.ylabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Cumulative Explained Variance"</span></span><span>)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Scree Plot"</span></span><span>)
plt.grid()
plt.show()
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="5384" data-end="5407" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5386" data-end="5405">Interpretation:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5408" data-end="5557">
<li data-start="5408" data-end="5485" class="">
<p data-start="5410" data-end="5485" class="">If <strong data-start="5413" data-end="5429">95% variance</strong> is explained with <strong data-start="5448" data-end="5464">3 components</strong>, we use <strong data-start="5473" data-end="5482">k = 3</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5486" data-end="5557" class="">
<p data-start="5488" data-end="5557" class="">If a <strong data-start="5493" data-end="5515">sharp drop (elbow)</strong> occurs at <strong data-start="5526" data-end="5535">k = 2</strong>, we select <strong data-start="5547" data-end="5556">k = 2</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="5559" data-end="5562" class="">
<h2 data-start="5564" data-end="5599" class=""><strong data-start="5567" data-end="5599">6️⃣ PCA vs Feature Selection</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5600" data-end="5980" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5600" data-end="5656"><tr data-start="5600" data-end="5656"><th data-start="5600" data-end="5624"><strong data-start="5602" data-end="5623">Feature Selection</strong></th><th data-start="5624" data-end="5656"><strong data-start="5626" data-end="5654">PCA (Feature Extraction)</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5697" data-end="5980"><tr data-start="5697" data-end="5774"><td>Removes irrelevant features</td><td>Creates new features (principal components)</td></tr><tr data-start="5775" data-end="5834"><td>Keeps original meanings</td><td>Transforms data into new axes</td></tr><tr data-start="5835" data-end="5919"><td>Works well when features are redundant</td><td>Works well when features are correlated</td></tr><tr data-start="5920" data-end="5980"><td>Example: Lasso, Mutual Info</td><td>Example: PCA, Autoencoders</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p data-start="5982" data-end="6088" class="">👉 Use <strong data-start="5989" data-end="6010">Feature Selection</strong> when features are independent.<br data-start="6041" data-end="6044">
👉 Use <strong data-start="6051" data-end="6058">PCA</strong> when features are correlated.</p>
<hr data-start="6090" data-end="6093" class="">
<h2 data-start="6095" data-end="6125" class=""><strong data-start="6098" data-end="6125">7️⃣ Applications of PCA</strong></h2>
<p data-start="6126" data-end="6504" class="">✔ <strong data-start="6128" data-end="6156">Dimensionality Reduction</strong> → Speed up ML models.<br data-start="6178" data-end="6181">
✔ <strong data-start="6183" data-end="6204">Image Compression</strong> → Reduce image storage without losing quality.<br data-start="6251" data-end="6254">
✔ <strong data-start="6256" data-end="6273">Visualization</strong> → Convert high-dimensional data into <strong data-start="6311" data-end="6320">2D/3D</strong> for easy interpretation.<br data-start="6345" data-end="6348">
✔ <strong data-start="6350" data-end="6369">Noise Filtering</strong> → Remove noise by keeping only important components.<br data-start="6422" data-end="6425">
✔ <strong data-start="6427" data-end="6448">Anomaly Detection</strong> → Reduce features and find patterns in fraud detection.</p>
<hr data-start="6506" data-end="6509" class="">
<h2 data-start="6511" data-end="6557" class=""><strong data-start="6514" data-end="6557">8️⃣ Advantages and Disadvantages of PCA</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="6558" data-end="6578" class=""><strong data-start="6562" data-end="6578">✅ Advantages</strong></h3>
<p data-start="6579" data-end="6831" class="">✔ <strong data-start="6581" data-end="6607">Reduces dimensionality</strong>, improving efficiency.<br data-start="6630" data-end="6633">
✔ <strong data-start="6635" data-end="6664">Removes multicollinearity</strong>, improving model stability.<br data-start="6692" data-end="6695">
✔ <strong data-start="6697" data-end="6720">Speeds up ML models</strong> by reducing computation time.<br data-start="6750" data-end="6753">
✔ <strong data-start="6755" data-end="6781">Improves visualization</strong> by converting high-dimensional data to <strong data-start="6821" data-end="6830">2D/3D</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="6833" data-end="6856" class=""><strong data-start="6837" data-end="6856">❌ Disadvantages</strong></h3>
<p data-start="6857" data-end="7195" class="">❌ <strong data-start="6859" data-end="6887">Loss of Interpretability</strong> → New features (principal components) don’t have direct meaning.<br data-start="6952" data-end="6955">
❌ <strong data-start="6957" data-end="6981">Sensitive to Scaling</strong> → Must standardize features before applying PCA.<br data-start="7030" data-end="7033">
❌ <strong data-start="7035" data-end="7056">Linear Assumption</strong> → PCA assumes features have <strong data-start="7085" data-end="7109">linear relationships</strong>.<br data-start="7110" data-end="7113">
❌ <strong data-start="7115" data-end="7157">Doesn't Work Well for Categorical Data</strong> → PCA works best with numerical data.</p>
<hr data-start="7197" data-end="7200" class="">
<h2 data-start="7202" data-end="7222" class=""><strong data-start="7205" data-end="7222">🔹 Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p data-start="7223" data-end="7440" class="">PCA is a powerful technique for <strong data-start="7255" data-end="7283">dimensionality reduction</strong>, <strong data-start="7285" data-end="7302">visualization</strong>, and <strong data-start="7308" data-end="7330">feature extraction</strong>. It finds <strong data-start="7341" data-end="7370">new uncorrelated features</strong> (principal components) while preserving as much variance as possible.</p>
<p data-start="7442" data-end="7460" class=""><strong data-start="7442" data-end="7460">Key Takeaways:</strong></p>
<ul data-start="7461" data-end="7647">
<li data-start="7461" data-end="7506" class="">
<p data-start="7463" data-end="7506" class="">PCA helps handle <strong data-start="7480" data-end="7505">high-dimensional data</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="7507" data-end="7574" class="">
<p data-start="7509" data-end="7574" class="">It finds <strong data-start="7518" data-end="7542">principal components</strong> that explain most <strong data-start="7561" data-end="7573">variance</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="7575" data-end="7647" class="">
<p data-start="7577" data-end="7647" class="">PCA is useful in <strong data-start="7594" data-end="7646">data compression, visualization, and ML speed-up</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="7649" data-end="7723" class="">👉 <strong data-start="7652" data-end="7720">Use PCA when dealing with high-dimensional, correlated features!</strong> 🚀</p></div></div></div></div><div dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="69" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="67">Voting Ensemble Classification &amp; Regression: A Complete Guide</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="71" data-end="109" class=""><strong data-start="74" data-end="107">📌 What is a Voting Ensemble?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="110" data-end="376" class="">A <strong data-start="112" data-end="131">Voting Ensemble</strong> is a technique that combines multiple machine learning models to improve overall accuracy and generalization. Instead of relying on a single model, voting ensembles <strong data-start="297" data-end="322">aggregate predictions</strong> from multiple base models to make the final decision.</p>
<h3 data-start="378" data-end="413" class=""><strong data-start="382" data-end="413">✅ Why Use Voting Ensembles?</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="414" data-end="697">
<li data-start="414" data-end="484" class="">
<p data-start="416" data-end="484" class=""><strong data-start="416" data-end="439">Reduces overfitting</strong>: A combination of models generalizes better.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="485" data-end="556" class="">
<p data-start="487" data-end="556" class=""><strong data-start="487" data-end="508">Improves accuracy</strong>: Multiple models correct each other’s mistakes.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="557" data-end="645" class="">
<p data-start="559" data-end="645" class=""><strong data-start="559" data-end="587">Handles diverse patterns</strong>: Different models capture different data characteristics.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="646" data-end="697" class="">
<p data-start="648" data-end="697" class=""><strong data-start="648" data-end="696">Works for both classification and regression</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="699" data-end="702" class="">
<h1 data-start="704" data-end="739" class=""><strong data-start="706" data-end="739">1️⃣ Types of Voting Ensembles</strong></h1>
<p data-start="740" data-end="791" class="">There are <strong data-start="750" data-end="768">two main types</strong> of voting ensembles:</p>
<ol data-start="792" data-end="929">
<li data-start="792" data-end="833" class="">
<p data-start="795" data-end="833" class=""><strong data-start="795" data-end="810">Hard Voting</strong> (for classification)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="834" data-end="875" class="">
<p data-start="837" data-end="875" class=""><strong data-start="837" data-end="852">Soft Voting</strong> (for classification)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="876" data-end="929" class="">
<p data-start="879" data-end="929" class=""><strong data-start="879" data-end="912">Averaging and Weighted Voting</strong> (for regression)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<hr data-start="931" data-end="934" class="">
<h1 data-start="936" data-end="980" class=""><strong data-start="938" data-end="980">2️⃣ Voting Ensemble for Classification</strong></h1>
<p data-start="981" data-end="1103" class="">In classification problems, voting ensembles combine predictions from multiple classifiers and determine the final output.</p>
<h3 data-start="1105" data-end="1149" class=""><strong data-start="1109" data-end="1149">🔹 (A) Hard Voting (Majority Voting)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="1150" data-end="1264">
<li data-start="1150" data-end="1195" class="">
<p data-start="1152" data-end="1195" class="">Each base classifier <strong data-start="1173" data-end="1182">votes</strong> for a class.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1196" data-end="1264" class="">
<p data-start="1198" data-end="1264" class="">The class that gets the <strong data-start="1222" data-end="1239">majority vote</strong> is the final prediction.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h4 data-start="1266" data-end="1283" class=""><strong data-start="1271" data-end="1283">Formula:</strong></h4>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mtext>mode</mtext><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\hat{y} = \text{mode} \left( y_1, y_2, ..., y_n \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">...</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="1346" data-end="1352" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="1353" data-end="1424">
<li data-start="1353" data-end="1424" class="">
<p data-start="1355" data-end="1424" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y_1, y_2, ..., y_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">...</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> are predictions from individual classifiers.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h4 data-start="1426" data-end="1443" class=""><strong data-start="1431" data-end="1443">Example:</strong></h4>
<p data-start="1444" data-end="1526" class="">If we have three models (<strong data-start="1469" data-end="1500">Decision Tree, SVM, and KNN</strong>) predicting for an input:</p>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="1528" data-end="1650" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="1528" data-end="1550"><tr data-start="1528" data-end="1550"><th data-start="1528" data-end="1536">Model</th><th data-start="1536" data-end="1550">Prediction</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="1575" data-end="1650"><tr data-start="1575" data-end="1606"><td>Decision Tree</td><td><strong data-start="1593" data-end="1604">Class A</strong></td></tr><tr data-start="1607" data-end="1628"><td>SVM</td><td><strong data-start="1615" data-end="1626">Class B</strong></td></tr><tr data-start="1629" data-end="1650"><td>KNN</td><td><strong data-start="1637" data-end="1648">Class A</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p data-start="1652" data-end="1716" class="">✅ The majority class is <strong data-start="1676" data-end="1681">A</strong>, so the final prediction is <strong data-start="1710" data-end="1715">A</strong>.</p>
