class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> RandomForestClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> load_iris
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> pandas </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> pd

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Load dataset</span></span><span>
iris = load_iris()
X, y = iris.data, iris.target
feature_names = iris.feature_names

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train a Random Forest model</span></span><span>
rf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
rf.fit(X, y)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Get feature importances</span></span><span>
feature_importance = pd.DataFrame({</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Feature'</span></span><span>: feature_names, </span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Importance'</span></span><span>: rf.feature_importances_})
feature_importance = feature_importance.sort_values(by=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'Importance'</span></span><span>, ascending=</span><span><span class="hljs-literal">False</span></span><span>)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(feature_importance)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="2632" data-end="2708" class="">✅ <strong data-start="2634" data-end="2648">Key Point:</strong> Random Forest averages feature importance across all trees.</p>
<hr data-start="2710" data-end="2713" class="">
<h2 data-start="2715" data-end="2773" class=""><strong data-start="2718" data-end="2773">2️⃣ Gradient Boosting (XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2774" data-end="3043" class="">Gradient boosting models compute <strong data-start="2807" data-end="2829">feature importance</strong> using three metrics:<br data-start="2850" data-end="2853">
1️⃣ <strong data-start="2857" data-end="2865">Gain</strong> → Reduction in loss when using the feature.<br data-start="2909" data-end="2912">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="2916" data-end="2925">Cover</strong> → Number of samples affected by the feature split.<br data-start="2976" data-end="2979">
3️⃣ <strong data-start="2983" data-end="2996">Frequency</strong> → How often the feature is used for splitting.</p>
<p data-start="3045" data-end="3092" class="">📌 <strong data-start="3048" data-end="3090">Formula for Gain Importance in XGBoost</strong></p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>S</mi></mfrac><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>S</mi></munderover><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Gain(f) = \frac{1}{S} \sum_{s=1}^{S} \Delta Loss(f, s)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">G</span><span class="mord mathnormal">ain</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 3.0954em; vertical-align: -1.2671em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mop op-limits"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.8283em;"><span style="top: -1.8829em; margin-left: 0em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.05em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">s</span><span class="mrel mtight">=</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.05em;"></span><span><span class="mop op-symbol large-op">∑</span></span></span><span style="top: -4.3em; margin-left: 0em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3.05em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.2671em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mord mathnormal">oss</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="3154" data-end="3162" class="">Where:</p>
<ul data-start="3163" data-end="3284">
<li data-start="3163" data-end="3216" class="">
<p data-start="3165" data-end="3216" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span> = Number of splits using feature <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3217" data-end="3284" class="">
<p data-start="3219" data-end="3284" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Delta Loss(f, s)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mord mathnormal">oss</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> = Reduction in loss due to split <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<hr data-start="3785" data-end="3788" class="">
<h2 data-start="3790" data-end="3853" class=""><strong data-start="3793" data-end="3853">3️⃣ Linear &amp; Logistic Regression (Coefficient Magnitude)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3854" data-end="3944" class="">Linear models determine feature importance using the <strong data-start="3907" data-end="3941">absolute value of coefficients</strong>.</p>
<ul data-start="3945" data-end="4124">
<li data-start="3945" data-end="4012" class="">
<p data-start="3947" data-end="4012" class=""><strong data-start="3947" data-end="3972">Positive coefficients</strong> → Feature increases the target value.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4013" data-end="4080" class="">
<p data-start="4015" data-end="4080" class=""><strong data-start="4015" data-end="4040">Negative coefficients</strong> → Feature decreases the target value.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4081" data-end="4124" class="">
<p data-start="4083" data-end="4124" class=""><strong data-start="4083" data-end="4103">Larger magnitude</strong> → Higher importance.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="4126" data-end="4184" class="">📌 <strong data-start="4129" data-end="4184">Formula for Feature Importance in Linear Regression</strong></p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">FI(f) = | w_f |</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0269em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">∣</span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="4207" data-end="4261" class="">Where <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">w_f</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7167em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0269em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the coefficient of feature <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span>.</p>

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train logistic regression</span></span><span>

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Get feature importance</span></span><span>
importance = np.</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">abs</span></span><span>(model.coef_[</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>])
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Feature Importance:"</span></span><span>, importance)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>

<h1 data-start="6364" data-end="6413" class=""><strong data-start="6366" data-end="6413">📌 Comparison of Feature Importance Methods</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="6414" data-end="6943" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="6414" data-end="6450"><tr data-start="6414" data-end="6450"><th data-start="6414" data-end="6427"><strong data-start="6416" data-end="6426">Method</strong></th><th data-start="6427" data-end="6438"><strong data-start="6429" data-end="6437">Pros</strong></th><th data-start="6438" data-end="6450"><strong data-start="6440" data-end="6448">Cons</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="6487" data-end="6943"><tr data-start="6487" data-end="6573"><td><strong data-start="6489" data-end="6516">Gini Importance (Trees)</strong></td><td>Fast, built-in</td><td>Biased to high-cardinality features</td></tr><tr data-start="6574" data-end="6647"><td><strong data-start="6576" data-end="6602">Gradient Boosting Gain</strong></td><td>More informative than Gini</td><td>Can overfit</td></tr><tr data-start="6648" data-end="6729"><td><strong data-start="6650" data-end="6684">Linear Regression Coefficients</strong></td><td>Simple, interpretable</td><td>Requires scaling</td></tr><tr data-start="6730" data-end="6805"><td><strong data-start="6732" data-end="6758">Permutation Importance</strong></td><td>Model-agnostic</td><td>Computationally expensive</td></tr><tr data-start="6806" data-end="6875"><td><strong data-start="6808" data-end="6823">SHAP Values</strong></td><td>Theoretically optimal</td><td>Slow for large datasets</td></tr><tr data-start="6876" data-end="6943"><td><strong data-start="6878" data-end="6886">LIME</strong></td><td>Great for local explanations</td><td>Not always consistent</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="6945" data-end="6948" class="">
<h1 data-start="6950" data-end="6969" class=""><strong data-start="6952" data-end="6969">📌 Conclusion</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6970" data-end="7151" class="">Feature Importance is essential for <strong data-start="7006" data-end="7079">understanding models, improving performance, and avoiding overfitting</strong>. The <strong data-start="7085" data-end="7100">best method</strong> depends on the <strong data-start="7116" data-end="7129">algorithm</strong> and <strong data-start="7134" data-end="7150">problem type</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="7153" data-end="7328" class="">✅ <strong data-start="7155" data-end="7193">For Tree-based models → Gini, Gain</strong><br data-start="7193" data-end="7196">
✅ <strong data-start="7198" data-end="7234">For Linear models → Coefficients</strong><br data-start="7234" data-end="7237">
✅ <strong data-start="7239" data-end="7276">For Black-box models → SHAP, LIME</strong><br data-start="7276" data-end="7279">
✅ <strong data-start="7281" data-end="7328">For Model-agnostic → Permutation Importance</strong></p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="56" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="54">📌 AdaBoost (Adaptive Boosting) - Complete Guide</strong></h1>
<p data-start="58" data-end="261" class="">Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost) is one of the most <strong data-start="106" data-end="137">popular boosting algorithms</strong> in machine learning. It <strong data-start="162" data-end="197">combines multiple weak learners</strong> (typically decision trees) to create a <strong data-start="237" data-end="258">strong classifier</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="263" data-end="266" class="">
<h2 data-start="267" data-end="294" class=""><strong data-start="270" data-end="294">🔹 What is AdaBoost?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="295" data-end="647" class="">📌 <strong data-start="298" data-end="330">AdaBoost (Adaptive Boosting)</strong> is an <strong data-start="337" data-end="358">ensemble learning</strong> technique that:<br data-start="374" data-end="377">
✅ <strong data-start="379" data-end="419">Sequentially trains weak classifiers</strong>, each correcting the errors of the previous one.<br data-start="468" data-end="471">
✅ <strong data-start="473" data-end="524">Assigns higher weights to misclassified samples</strong> so that future classifiers focus on them.<br data-start="566" data-end="569">
✅ <strong data-start="571" data-end="620">Combines weak models into a strong classifier</strong> through weighted voting.</p>
<p data-start="649" data-end="815" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="652" data-end="667">Invented by</strong>: Yoav Freund &amp; Robert Schapire (1995)<br data-start="705" data-end="708">
🔹 <strong data-start="711" data-end="725">Base Model</strong>: Decision Stumps (single-level decision trees)<br data-start="772" data-end="775">
🔹 <strong data-start="778" data-end="795">Loss Function</strong>: Exponential Loss</p>
<p data-start="817" data-end="954" class="">💡 <strong data-start="820" data-end="833">Key Idea:</strong><br data-start="833" data-end="836">
Boosting <strong data-start="845" data-end="870">sequentially improves</strong> weak models, unlike bagging (e.g., Random Forest), which runs models in parallel.</p>
<hr data-start="956" data-end="959" class="">
<h1 data-start="961" data-end="989" class=""><strong data-start="963" data-end="989">📌 How AdaBoost Works?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="990" data-end="1068" class="">AdaBoost builds a strong classifier by <strong data-start="1029" data-end="1065">training weak models iteratively</strong>.</p>
<h3 data-start="1070" data-end="1113" class=""><strong data-start="1074" data-end="1113">🔹 Step-by-Step Process of AdaBoost</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1114" data-end="1143" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1118" data-end="1140">Initialize Weights</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1147" data-end="1220">
<li data-start="1147" data-end="1220" class="">

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.ensemble </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> AdaBoostClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.tree </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> DecisionTreeClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_classification
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> accuracy_score

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Create dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>, n_features=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">20</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Initialize base weak learner</span></span><span>
weak_learner = DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train AdaBoost classifier</span></span><span>
ada_model = AdaBoostClassifier(base_estimator=weak_learner, n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">50</span></span><span>, learning_rate=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1.0</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
ada_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict &amp; Evaluate</span></span><span>
y_pred = ada_model.predict(X_test)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Accuracy:"</span></span><span>, accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred))
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="3895" data-end="3942" class="">✅ <strong data-start="3897" data-end="3939">Key Parameters in <code data-start="3917" data-end="3937">AdaBoostClassifier</code></strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="3943" data-end="4197">
<li data-start="3943" data-end="4027" class="">
<p data-start="3945" data-end="4027" class=""><code data-start="3945" data-end="3961">base_estimator</code>: Weak learner (default = <code data-start="3987" data-end="4024">DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=1)</code>)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4028" data-end="4069" class="">
<p data-start="4030" data-end="4069" class=""><code data-start="4030" data-end="4044">n_estimators</code>: Number of weak models</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4070" data-end="4127" class="">
<p data-start="4072" data-end="4127" class=""><code data-start="4072" data-end="4087">learning_rate</code>: Controls contribution of weak models</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4128" data-end="4197" class="">
<p data-start="4130" data-end="4197" class=""><code data-start="4130" data-end="4141">algorithm</code>: <code data-start="4143" data-end="4152">'SAMME'</code> (multi-class), <code data-start="4168" data-end="4179">'SAMME.R'</code> (real boosting)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4199" data-end="4202" class="">
<h1 data-start="4204" data-end="4235" class=""><strong data-start="4206" data-end="4235">📌 Advantages of AdaBoost</strong></h1>
<p data-start="4236" data-end="4461" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4238" data-end="4265">Reduces bias &amp; variance</strong> by combining weak models.<br data-start="4291" data-end="4294">
✅ <strong data-start="4296" data-end="4326">Works well with noisy data</strong> and avoids overfitting.<br data-start="4350" data-end="4353">
✅ <strong data-start="4355" data-end="4390">Doesn’t require feature scaling</strong> (like SVM).<br data-start="4402" data-end="4405">
✅ <strong data-start="4407" data-end="4446">Focuses on hard-to-classify samples</strong> dynamically.</p>
<hr data-start="4463" data-end="4466" class="">
<h1 data-start="4468" data-end="4502" class=""><strong data-start="4470" data-end="4502">📌 Disadvantages of AdaBoost</strong></h1>
<p data-start="4503" data-end="4717" class="">❌ <strong data-start="4505" data-end="4530">Sensitive to outliers</strong> (because weights increase exponentially).<br data-start="4572" data-end="4575">
❌ <strong data-start="4577" data-end="4606">Computationally expensive</strong> (as it trains models sequentially).<br data-start="4642" data-end="4645">
❌ <strong data-start="4647" data-end="4687">Not suitable for very large datasets</strong> (due to sequential nature).</p>
<hr data-start="4719" data-end="4722" class="">
<h1 data-start="4724" data-end="4753" class=""><strong data-start="4726" data-end="4753">📌 Variants of AdaBoost</strong></h1>
<p data-start="4754" data-end="4987" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4757" data-end="4784">Real AdaBoost (SAMME.R)</strong> → Uses real-valued probabilities instead of discrete votes.<br data-start="4844" data-end="4847">
🔹 <strong data-start="4850" data-end="4879">Discrete AdaBoost (SAMME)</strong> → Traditional AdaBoost for classification.<br data-start="4922" data-end="4925">
🔹 <strong data-start="4928" data-end="4949">AdaBoostRegressor</strong> → Boosting for regression problems.</p>
<p data-start="4989" data-end="5026" class="">📌 <strong data-start="4992" data-end="5026">Implementation for Regression:</strong></p>

</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Regression Score:"</span></span><span>, ada_regressor.score(X_test, y_test))

<hr data-start="5445" data-end="5448" class="">
<h1 data-start="5450" data-end="5508" class=""><strong data-start="5452" data-end="5508">📌 Comparison: AdaBoost vs Other Boosting Algorithms</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5509" data-end="6130" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5509" data-end="5601"><tr data-start="5509" data-end="5601"><th data-start="5509" data-end="5523">Algorithm</th><th data-start="5523" data-end="5538">Weak Learner</th><th data-start="5538" data-end="5557">Weighting Method</th><th data-start="5557" data-end="5580">Handles Overfitting?</th><th data-start="5580" data-end="5601">Handles Outliers?</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5694" data-end="6130"><tr data-start="5694" data-end="5790"><td><strong data-start="5696" data-end="5708">AdaBoost</strong></td><td>Decision Stump</td><td>Exponential Weighting</td><td>Yes (up to a limit)</td><td>No (sensitive)</td></tr><tr data-start="5791" data-end="5900"><td><strong data-start="5793" data-end="5814">Gradient Boosting</strong></td><td>Any Model</td><td>Gradient-based</td><td>Yes (better than AdaBoost)</td><td>Handles Outliers Better</td></tr><tr data-start="5901" data-end="6020"><td><strong data-start="5903" data-end="5914">XGBoost</strong></td><td>Any Model</td><td>Tree-based Gradient Boosting</td><td>Yes (better regularization)</td><td>Yes (handles missing values)</td></tr><tr data-start="6021" data-end="6130"><td><strong data-start="6023" data-end="6035">LightGBM</strong></td><td>Decision Trees</td><td>Histogram-based boosting</td><td>Yes (faster training)</td><td>Handles Large Datasets</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p data-start="6132" data-end="6346" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6134" data-end="6201">AdaBoost is best when using shallow models like decision stumps</strong>.<br data-start="6202" data-end="6205">
✅ <strong data-start="6207" data-end="6277">Gradient Boosting is more robust &amp; widely used for structured data</strong>.<br data-start="6278" data-end="6281">
✅ <strong data-start="6283" data-end="6343">XGBoost &amp; LightGBM are optimized for speed &amp; scalability</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="6348" data-end="6351" class="">
<h1 data-start="6353" data-end="6372" class=""><strong data-start="6355" data-end="6372">📌 Conclusion</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6373" data-end="6760" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6375" data-end="6471">AdaBoost is a powerful ensemble learning algorithm that sequentially improves weak learners.</strong><br data-start="6471" data-end="6474">
✅ <strong data-start="6476" data-end="6569">It assigns higher weights to misclassified instances, forcing the model to focus on them.</strong><br data-start="6569" data-end="6572">
✅ <strong data-start="6574" data-end="6665">Despite its sensitivity to noise, AdaBoost remains a strong choice for boosting models.</strong><br data-start="6665" data-end="6668">
✅ <strong data-start="6670" data-end="6758">For large datasets, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost, or LightGBM might be better options.</strong></p>
<p data-start="6762" data-end="6835" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="6765" data-end="6835" data-is-last-node="">Would you like a deep dive into Gradient Boosting or XGBoost dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="51" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="49">📌 Gradient Boosting - Complete Explanation</strong></h1>
<p data-start="53" data-end="285" class="">Gradient Boosting is a <strong data-start="76" data-end="116">powerful ensemble learning technique</strong> used for both <strong data-start="131" data-end="164">classification and regression</strong>. It is an improvement over AdaBoost, making it <strong data-start="212" data-end="240">more robust and accurate</strong> by reducing bias and variance effectively.</p>
<hr data-start="287" data-end="290" class="">
<h2 data-start="292" data-end="328" class=""><strong data-start="295" data-end="328">🔹 What is Gradient Boosting?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="329" data-end="649" class="">📌 <strong data-start="332" data-end="358">Gradient Boosting (GB)</strong> is a boosting algorithm that:<br data-start="388" data-end="391">
✅ <strong data-start="393" data-end="423">Builds models sequentially</strong>, with each new model reducing the error of the previous model.<br data-start="486" data-end="489">
✅ <strong data-start="491" data-end="533">Uses gradient descent to minimize loss</strong> and improve predictions.<br data-start="558" data-end="561">
✅ <strong data-start="563" data-end="646">Combines multiple weak learners (decision trees) into a strong predictive model</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="651" data-end="928" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="654" data-end="670">Developed by</strong>: Jerome H. Friedman (1999)<br data-start="697" data-end="700">
🔹 <strong data-start="703" data-end="717">Base Model</strong>: Decision Trees (usually CART – Classification and Regression Trees)<br data-start="786" data-end="789">
🔹 <strong data-start="792" data-end="815">Optimization Method</strong>: Gradient Descent<br data-start="833" data-end="836">
🔹 <strong data-start="839" data-end="856">Loss Function</strong>: Mean Squared Error (MSE) for regression, Log Loss for classification</p>
<p data-start="930" data-end="1092" class="">💡 <strong data-start="933" data-end="946">Key Idea:</strong><br data-start="946" data-end="949">
Unlike AdaBoost, which adjusts weights of misclassified samples, <strong data-start="1014" data-end="1066">Gradient Boosting optimizes loss using gradients</strong> (like neural networks).</p>
<hr data-start="1094" data-end="1097" class="">
<h1 data-start="1099" data-end="1136" class=""><strong data-start="1101" data-end="1136">📌 How Gradient Boosting Works?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="1137" data-end="1253" class="">Gradient Boosting builds a <strong data-start="1164" data-end="1180">strong model</strong> by <strong data-start="1184" data-end="1219">sequentially adding weak models</strong> and minimizing residual errors.</p>
<h3 data-start="1255" data-end="1307" class=""><strong data-start="1259" data-end="1307">🔹 Step-by-Step Process of Gradient Boosting</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1308" data-end="1335" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1312" data-end="1332">Initialize Model</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1339" data-end="1545">
<li data-start="1339" data-end="1484" class="">
<p data-start="1341" data-end="1484" class="">Start with a simple model, often a single tree that predicts the <strong data-start="1406" data-end="1431">mean of target values</strong> for regression or <strong data-start="1450" data-end="1481">log odds for classification</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1488" data-end="1545" class="">
<p data-start="1490" data-end="1500" class="">Example:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mtext>Mean</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F_0(x) = \text{Mean}(y)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Mean</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1547" data-end="1584" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1551" data-end="1581">Compute Residuals (Errors)</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1588" data-end="1755">
<li data-start="1588" data-end="1695" class="">
<p data-start="1590" data-end="1655" class="">Calculate the difference between actual values and predictions:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">r_i = y_i - F(x_i)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
</li>
<li data-start="1699" data-end="1755" class="">
<p data-start="1701" data-end="1755" class="">These residuals act as new targets for the next model.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1757" data-end="1799" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1761" data-end="1796">Train a Weak Model on Residuals</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1803" data-end="1895">
<li data-start="1803" data-end="1895" class="">
<p data-start="1805" data-end="1895" class="">Fit a small decision tree (usually <strong data-start="1840" data-end="1868">shallow, 3-5 levels deep</strong>) to predict the residuals.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1897" data-end="1955" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1901" data-end="1952">Scale Predictions Using Learning Rate <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span></strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1959" data-end="2173">
<li data-start="1959" data-end="2110" class="">
<p data-start="1961" data-end="2048" class="">Multiply the tree’s predictions by a <strong data-start="1998" data-end="2015">learning rate</strong> <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span> (0 &lt; <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span> ≤ 1).</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>ν</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F_{m}(x) = F_{m-1}(x) + \nu \cdot h_m(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span><span class="mbin mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2083em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
</li>
<li data-start="2114" data-end="2173" class="">
<p data-start="2116" data-end="2173" class="">This prevents overfitting and ensures smooth convergence.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2175" data-end="2219" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="2179" data-end="2216">Update Model with New Predictions</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="2223" data-end="2293">
<li data-start="2223" data-end="2293" class="">
<p data-start="2225" data-end="2293" class="">Add the new model’s weighted contribution to previous predictions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2295" data-end="2340" class="">6️⃣ <strong data-start="2299" data-end="2319">Repeat Steps 2-5</strong> Until Convergence:</p>
<ul data-start="2344" data-end="2479">
<li data-start="2344" data-end="2422" class="">
<p data-start="2346" data-end="2422" class="">Continue <strong data-start="2355" data-end="2389">iteratively reducing residuals</strong> by training additional models.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2426" data-end="2479" class="">
<p data-start="2428" data-end="2479" class="">Each tree corrects the previous model’s mistakes.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2481" data-end="2508" class="">7️⃣ <strong data-start="2485" data-end="2505">Final Prediction</strong>:</p>

<p data-start="2647" data-end="2743" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2650" data-end="2665">Key Benefit</strong>: Focuses on <strong data-start="2678" data-end="2705">hard-to-predict samples</strong>, improving performance iteratively.</p>
<hr data-start="2745" data-end="2748" class="">
<h1 data-start="2750" data-end="2787" class=""><strong data-start="2752" data-end="2787">📌 Formula of Gradient Boosting</strong></h1>
<p data-start="2788" data-end="2852" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2791" data-end="2813">Objective Function</strong> = <strong data-start="2816" data-end="2850">Loss Function + Regularization</strong></p>

<ul data-start="2907" data-end="3106">
<li data-start="2907" data-end="2949" class="">
<p data-start="2909" data-end="2949" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F_m(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> → New prediction function</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2950" data-end="3000" class="">
<p data-start="2952" data-end="3000" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F_{m-1}(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span><span class="mbin mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2083em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> → Previous model’s prediction</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3001" data-end="3055" class="">
<p data-start="3003" data-end="3055" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h_m(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> → New weak model predicting residuals</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3056" data-end="3106" class="">
<p data-start="3058" data-end="3106" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span> → Learning rate (controls step size)</p>
</li>
</ul>

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.ensemble </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> GradientBoostingClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_classification
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> accuracy_score

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Create dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>, n_features=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">20</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train Gradient Boosting classifier</span></span><span>
gb_model = GradientBoostingClassifier(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, learning_rate=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.1</span></span><span>, max_depth=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">3</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
gb_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict &amp; Evaluate</span></span><span>
y_pred = gb_model.predict(X_test)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Accuracy:"</span></span><span>, accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred))
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="4409" data-end="4464" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4411" data-end="4461">Key Parameters in <code data-start="4431" data-end="4459">GradientBoostingClassifier</code></strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="4465" data-end="4705">
<li data-start="4465" data-end="4517" class="">
<p data-start="4467" data-end="4517" class=""><code data-start="4467" data-end="4481">n_estimators</code>: Number of trees (weak learners).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4518" data-end="4574" class="">
<p data-start="4520" data-end="4574" class=""><code data-start="4520" data-end="4535">learning_rate</code>: Controls contribution of each tree.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4575" data-end="4634" class="">
<p data-start="4577" data-end="4634" class=""><code data-start="4577" data-end="4588">max_depth</code>: Depth of each tree (prevents overfitting).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4635" data-end="4705" class="">
<p data-start="4637" data-end="4705" class=""><code data-start="4637" data-end="4648">subsample</code>: Fraction of samples used per tree (reduces variance).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4707" data-end="4710" class="">
<h1 data-start="4712" data-end="4752" class=""><strong data-start="4714" data-end="4752">📌 Advantages of Gradient Boosting</strong></h1>
<p data-start="4753" data-end="4991" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4755" data-end="4786">More accurate than AdaBoost</strong> (handles noise better).<br data-start="4810" data-end="4813">
✅ <strong data-start="4815" data-end="4864">Can optimize any differentiable loss function</strong> (custom loss possible).<br data-start="4888" data-end="4891">
✅ <strong data-start="4893" data-end="4930">Feature importance interpretation</strong> (like Random Forest).<br data-start="4952" data-end="4955">
✅ <strong data-start="4957" data-end="4988">Handles missing values well</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="4993" data-end="4996" class="">
<h1 data-start="4998" data-end="5041" class=""><strong data-start="5000" data-end="5041">📌 Disadvantages of Gradient Boosting</strong></h1>
<p data-start="5042" data-end="5241" class="">❌ <strong data-start="5044" data-end="5073">Computationally expensive</strong> (since trees are trained sequentially).<br data-start="5113" data-end="5116">
❌ <strong data-start="5118" data-end="5150">Sensitive to hyperparameters</strong> (learning rate, depth, etc.).<br data-start="5180" data-end="5183">
❌ <strong data-start="5185" data-end="5209">Prone to overfitting</strong> (if too many trees are used).</p>
<hr data-start="5243" data-end="5246" class="">
<h1 data-start="5248" data-end="5286" class=""><strong data-start="5250" data-end="5286">📌 Variants of Gradient Boosting</strong></h1>
<p data-start="5287" data-end="5330" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5289" data-end="5328">XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5334" data-end="5438">
<li data-start="5334" data-end="5360" class="">
<p data-start="5336" data-end="5360" class="">Faster than regular GB</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5364" data-end="5401" class="">
<p data-start="5366" data-end="5401" class="">Built-in regularization (L1 &amp; L2)</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5405" data-end="5438" class="">
<p data-start="5407" data-end="5438" class="">Handles missing values better</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="5440" data-end="5490" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5442" data-end="5488">LightGBM (Light Gradient Boosting Machine)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5494" data-end="5587">
<li data-start="5494" data-end="5528" class="">
<p data-start="5496" data-end="5528" class="">Works well with large datasets</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5532" data-end="5587" class="">
<p data-start="5534" data-end="5587" class="">Uses <strong data-start="5539" data-end="5567">histogram-based learning</strong> (faster training)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="5589" data-end="5628" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5591" data-end="5626">CatBoost (Categorical Boosting)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="5632" data-end="5720">
<li data-start="5632" data-end="5680" class="">
<p data-start="5634" data-end="5680" class="">Specially optimized for categorical features</p>
</li>
<li data-start="5684" data-end="5720" class="">
<p data-start="5686" data-end="5720" class="">Performs well on structured data</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="5722" data-end="5725" class="">
<h1 data-start="5727" data-end="5783" class=""><strong data-start="5729" data-end="5783">📌 Gradient Boosting vs. Other Boosting Algorithms</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5784" data-end="6275" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5784" data-end="5864"><tr data-start="5784" data-end="5864"><th data-start="5784" data-end="5798">Algorithm</th><th data-start="5798" data-end="5813">Optimization</th><th data-start="5813" data-end="5830">Regularization</th><th data-start="5830" data-end="5838">Speed</th><th data-start="5838" data-end="5864">Handles Large Datasets</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5941" data-end="6275"><tr data-start="5941" data-end="5998"><td><strong data-start="5943" data-end="5955">AdaBoost</strong></td><td>Weighted Re-weighting</td><td>No</td><td>Slow</td><td>No</td></tr><tr data-start="5999" data-end="6065"><td><strong data-start="6001" data-end="6022">Gradient Boosting</strong></td><td>Gradient Descent</td><td>Partial</td><td>Slow</td><td>No</td></tr><tr data-start="6066" data-end="6148"><td><strong data-start="6068" data-end="6079">XGBoost</strong></td><td>Gradient Boosting + Optimized Trees</td><td>Yes (L1 &amp; L2)</td><td>Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="6149" data-end="6216"><td><strong data-start="6151" data-end="6163">LightGBM</strong></td><td>Histogram-based Learning</td><td>Yes</td><td>Very Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="6217" data-end="6275"><td><strong data-start="6219" data-end="6231">CatBoost</strong></td><td>Categorical Boosting</td><td>Yes</td><td>Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p data-start="6277" data-end="6438" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6279" data-end="6360">Use Gradient Boosting when you need interpretability and moderate-sized data.</strong><br data-start="6360" data-end="6363">
✅ <strong data-start="6365" data-end="6436">Use XGBoost or LightGBM for faster training and better performance.</strong></p>
<hr data-start="6440" data-end="6443" class="">
<h1 data-start="6445" data-end="6464" class=""><strong data-start="6447" data-end="6464">📌 Conclusion</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6465" data-end="6760" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6467" data-end="6538">Gradient Boosting is a powerful and widely used boosting technique.</strong><br data-start="6538" data-end="6541">
✅ <strong data-start="6543" data-end="6607">It sequentially improves weak models using gradient descent.</strong><br data-start="6607" data-end="6610">
✅ <strong data-start="6612" data-end="6675">More robust than AdaBoost and can handle noisy data better.</strong><br data-start="6675" data-end="6678">
✅ <strong data-start="6680" data-end="6758">XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost are optimized versions for large datasets.</strong></p>
<p data-start="6762" data-end="6826" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="6765" data-end="6826" data-is-last-node="">Would you like a deep dive into XGBoost or LightGBM next?</strong></p></div></div></div></div><div class="mb-2"></div></div></div></div></div></article><article class="group/turn w-full text-token-text-primary focus-visible:outline-2 focus-visible:outline-offset-[-4px]" dir="auto" data-testid="conversation-turn-54" data-scroll-anchor="false"><h5 class="sr-only">You said:</h5><div class="text-base my-auto mx-auto py-[18px] px-6"><div class="mx-auto flex flex-1 text-base gap-4 md:gap-5 lg:gap-6 md:max-w-3xl lg:max-w-[40rem] xl:max-w-[48rem]"><div class="group/conversation-turn relative flex w-full min-w-0 flex-col @xs/thread:px-0 @sm/thread:px-1.5 @md/thread:px-4"><div class="flex-col gap-1 md:gap-3"><div class="flex max-w-full flex-col flex-grow"><div data-message-author-role="user" data-message-id="66b59631-614f-4f73-ad74-769ee381b441" dir="auto" class="min-h-8 text-message relative flex w-full flex-col items-end gap-2 whitespace-normal break-words text-start [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5"><div class="w-full"><div class="flex w-full flex-col gap-1 empty:hidden items-end rtl:items-start"><div class="relative max-w-[var(--user-chat-width,70%)] rounded-3xl bg-token-message-surface px-5 py-2.5"><div class="whitespace-pre-wrap">Introduction to XGBOOST? dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="60" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="60">📌 Introduction to XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting)</strong></h1>
<p data-start="61" data-end="321" class="">XGBoost (<strong data-start="70" data-end="99">eXtreme Gradient Boosting</strong>) is an <strong data-start="107" data-end="149">optimized version of Gradient Boosting</strong> designed for <strong data-start="163" data-end="188">speed and performance</strong>. It is widely used in Machine Learning competitions (like Kaggle) and in real-world applications due to its efficiency and accuracy.</p>
<p data-start="323" data-end="633" class="">📌 <strong data-start="326" data-end="354">Key Features of XGBoost:</strong>
✅ <strong data-start="357" data-end="399">Faster than standard Gradient Boosting</strong><br data-start="399" data-end="402">
✅ <strong data-start="404" data-end="437">Highly efficient memory usage</strong><br data-start="437" data-end="440">
✅ <strong data-start="442" data-end="492">Regularization (L1 &amp; L2) to reduce overfitting</strong><br data-start="492" data-end="495">
✅ <strong data-start="497" data-end="537">Handles missing values automatically</strong><br data-start="537" data-end="540">
✅ <strong data-start="542" data-end="586">Parallel &amp; distributed computing support</strong><br data-start="586" data-end="589">
✅ <strong data-start="591" data-end="631">Supports classification &amp; regression</strong></p>
<p data-start="635" data-end="841" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="638" data-end="654">Developed by</strong>: Tianqi Chen (2016)<br data-start="674" data-end="677">
🔹 <strong data-start="680" data-end="694">Base Model</strong>: Decision Trees<br data-start="710" data-end="713">
🔹 <strong data-start="716" data-end="739">Optimization Method</strong>: Gradient Descent + Regularization<br data-start="774" data-end="777">
🔹 <strong data-start="780" data-end="797">Primary Usage</strong>: Kaggle competitions, predictive modeling</p>
<hr data-start="843" data-end="846" class="">
<h1 data-start="848" data-end="875" class=""><strong data-start="850" data-end="875">📌 How XGBoost Works?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="876" data-end="1003" class="">XGBoost follows the principle of <strong data-start="909" data-end="930">Gradient Boosting</strong> but introduces <strong data-start="946" data-end="972">advanced optimizations</strong> to improve speed and accuracy.</p>
<h3 data-start="1005" data-end="1047" class=""><strong data-start="1009" data-end="1047">🔹 Step-by-Step Working of XGBoost</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1048" data-end="1074" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1052" data-end="1072">Initialize Model</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1078" data-end="1191">
<li data-start="1078" data-end="1191" class="">
<p data-start="1080" data-end="1191" class="">Starts with a simple prediction (like the mean of target values for regression or log odds for classification).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1193" data-end="1229" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1197" data-end="1227">Compute Residuals (Errors)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1233" data-end="1331">
<li data-start="1233" data-end="1278" class="">
<p data-start="1235" data-end="1278" class="">Residuals = <strong data-start="1247" data-end="1276">Actual - Predicted values</strong></p>
</li>
<li data-start="1282" data-end="1331" class="">
<p data-start="1284" data-end="1331" class="">The next tree tries to predict these residuals.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1333" data-end="1380" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1337" data-end="1378">Construct Decision Trees Sequentially</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1384" data-end="1513">
<li data-start="1384" data-end="1448" class="">
<p data-start="1386" data-end="1448" class="">Each tree learns from the <strong data-start="1412" data-end="1445">mistakes of the previous tree</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1452" data-end="1513" class="">
<p data-start="1454" data-end="1513" class="">Trees are built <strong data-start="1470" data-end="1497">depth-wise or leaf-wise</strong> for efficiency.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1515" data-end="1563" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1519" data-end="1561">Use Taylor Expansion for Approximation</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1567" data-end="1790">
<li data-start="1567" data-end="1699" class="">
<p data-start="1569" data-end="1699" class="">XGBoost <strong data-start="1577" data-end="1648">approximates loss functions using the second-order Taylor expansion</strong>, making it faster than normal Gradient Boosting.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1703" data-end="1790" class="">
<p data-start="1705" data-end="1790" class="">It uses <strong data-start="1713" data-end="1771">both first (gradient) and second (Hessian) derivatives</strong> to adjust weights.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1792" data-end="1832" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="1796" data-end="1830">Apply Regularization (L1 &amp; L2)</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1836" data-end="1981">
<li data-start="1836" data-end="1906" class="">
<p data-start="1838" data-end="1906" class="">L1 (Lasso) and L2 (Ridge) regularization help prevent overfitting.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1910" data-end="1981" class="">
<p data-start="1912" data-end="1981" class=""><strong data-start="1912" data-end="1942">L1 shrinks weights to zero</strong>, while <strong data-start="1950" data-end="1980">L2 penalizes large weights</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1983" data-end="2027" class="">6️⃣ <strong data-start="1987" data-end="2025">Use Shrinkage &amp; Column Subsampling</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2031" data-end="2131">
<li data-start="2031" data-end="2082" class="">
<p data-start="2033" data-end="2082" class="">Shrinkage (Learning Rate) prevents overfitting.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2086" data-end="2131" class="">
<p data-start="2088" data-end="2131" class=""><strong data-start="2088" data-end="2113">Column &amp; Row Sampling</strong> reduces variance.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2133" data-end="2159" class="">7️⃣ <strong data-start="2137" data-end="2157">Final Prediction</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2163" data-end="2224">
<li data-start="2163" data-end="2224" class="">
<p data-start="2165" data-end="2224" class="">The final model is a <strong data-start="2186" data-end="2223">weighted sum of all weak learners</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2226" data-end="2229" class="">
<h1 data-start="2231" data-end="2272" class=""><strong data-start="2233" data-end="2272">📌 How XGBoost Works on Regression?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="2273" data-end="2375" class="">XGBoost can efficiently handle <strong data-start="2304" data-end="2327">regression problems</strong> by optimizing the <strong data-start="2346" data-end="2374">Mean Squared Error (MSE)</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="2377" data-end="2416" class="">📌 <strong data-start="2380" data-end="2415">Steps for Regression in XGBoost</strong>:</p>
<ol data-start="2417" data-end="2761">
<li data-start="2417" data-end="2491" class="">
<p data-start="2420" data-end="2491" class=""><strong data-start="2420" data-end="2449">Initialize the base model</strong> with the <strong data-start="2459" data-end="2490">mean of the target variable</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2492" data-end="2545" class="">
<p data-start="2495" data-end="2545" class=""><strong data-start="2495" data-end="2516">Compute residuals</strong> as <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">r_i = y_i - F(x_i)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2546" data-end="2594" class="">
<p data-start="2549" data-end="2594" class=""><strong data-start="2549" data-end="2593">Train weak learners (trees) on residuals</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2595" data-end="2705" class="">
<p data-start="2598" data-end="2651" class=""><strong data-start="2598" data-end="2640">Update predictions using learning rate</strong> <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.06366em;">ν</span></span></span></span>:</p>

<li data-start="2706" data-end="2761" class="">
<p data-start="2709" data-end="2761" class=""><strong data-start="2709" data-end="2731">Repeat the process</strong> until the error is minimized.</p>

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> xgboost </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> XGBRegressor
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_regression
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> mean_squared_error

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Create dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = make_regression(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>, n_features=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">10</span></span><span>, noise=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train XGBoost Regressor</span></span><span>
xgb_reg = XGBRegressor(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, learning_rate=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.1</span></span><span>, max_depth=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">3</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
xgb_reg.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict &amp; Evaluate</span></span><span>
y_pred = xgb_reg.predict(X_test)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"MSE:"</span></span><span>, mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="3543" data-end="3644" class="">✅ <strong data-start="3545" data-end="3595">Results in a highly optimized regression model</strong> with reduced variance and better generalization.</p>
<hr data-start="3646" data-end="3649" class="">
<h1 data-start="3651" data-end="3696" class=""><strong data-start="3653" data-end="3696">📌 How XGBoost Works on Classification?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="3697" data-end="3791" class="">XGBoost works for <strong data-start="3715" data-end="3742">classification problems</strong> by optimizing <strong data-start="3757" data-end="3790">Log Loss (Cross-Entropy Loss)</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="3793" data-end="3836" class="">📌 <strong data-start="3796" data-end="3835">Steps for Classification in XGBoost</strong>:</p>
<ol data-start="3837" data-end="4215">
<li data-start="3837" data-end="3923" class="">
<p data-start="3840" data-end="3923" class=""><strong data-start="3840" data-end="3869">Initialize the base model</strong> with <strong data-start="3875" data-end="3922">log-odds (logarithm of class probabilities)</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3924" data-end="3993" class="">
<p data-start="3927" data-end="3993" class=""><strong data-start="3927" data-end="3992">Compute pseudo-residuals (negative gradient of loss function)</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3994" data-end="4049" class="">
<p data-start="3997" data-end="4049" class=""><strong data-start="3997" data-end="4048">Train weak learners (trees) on pseudo-residuals</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4050" data-end="4165" class="">
<p data-start="4053" data-end="4117" class=""><strong data-start="4053" data-end="4079">Use sigmoid activation</strong> to convert log-odds to probabilities:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P(y=1) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-F(x)}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1088em; vertical-align: -0.7873em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.296em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.814em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mopen mtight">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">x</span><span class="mclose mtight">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7873em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span>
</li>
<li data-start="4166" data-end="4215" class="">
<p data-start="4169" data-end="4215" class=""><strong data-start="4169" data-end="4196">Update model and repeat</strong> until convergence.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="4217" data-end="4268" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4220" data-end="4267">Loss Function for Classification (Log Loss)</strong>:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mo>∑</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">L(y, \hat{y}) = -\sum y_i \log (\hat{y}_i) + (1 - y_i) \log (1 - \hat{y}_i)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em;
