class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> XGBClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_classification
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> accuracy_score

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Create dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1000</span></span><span>, n_features=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">10</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train XGBoost Classifier</span></span><span>
xgb_clf = XGBClassifier(n_estimators=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, learning_rate=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.1</span></span><span>, max_depth=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">3</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)
xgb_clf.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict &amp; Evaluate</span></span><span>
y_pred = xgb_clf.predict(X_test)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Accuracy:"</span></span><span>, accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred))
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<p data-start="5038" data-end="5127" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5040" data-end="5083">Results in a highly accurate classifier</strong> that handles non-linear relationships well.</p>
<hr data-start="5129" data-end="5132" class="">
<h1 data-start="5134" data-end="5166" class=""><strong data-start="5136" data-end="5166">📌 Key Features of XGBoost</strong></h1>
<p data-start="5167" data-end="5416" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5169" data-end="5219">Gradient Boosting with Advanced Regularization</strong><br data-start="5219" data-end="5222">
✅ <strong data-start="5224" data-end="5262">Handles Missing Data Automatically</strong><br data-start="5262" data-end="5265">
✅ <strong data-start="5267" data-end="5315">Parallel Processing (Multithreading Support)</strong><br data-start="5315" data-end="5318">
✅ <strong data-start="5320" data-end="5368">Column Subsampling for Better Generalization</strong><br data-start="5368" data-end="5371">
✅ <strong data-start="5373" data-end="5414">Early Stopping to Prevent Overfitting</strong></p>
<hr data-start="5418" data-end="5421" class="">
<h1 data-start="5423" data-end="5458" class=""><strong data-start="5425" data-end="5458">📌 Hyperparameters in XGBoost</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5459" data-end="6017" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5459" data-end="5494"><tr data-start="5459" data-end="5494"><th data-start="5459" data-end="5479">Parameter</th><th data-start="5479" data-end="5494">Description</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5530" data-end="6017"><tr data-start="5530" data-end="5584"><td><code data-start="5532" data-end="5546">n_estimators</code></td><td>Number of trees (weak learners).</td></tr><tr data-start="5585" data-end="5643"><td><code data-start="5587" data-end="5602">learning_rate</code></td><td>Shrinkage factor to control updates.</td></tr><tr data-start="5644" data-end="5708"><td><code data-start="5646" data-end="5657">max_depth</code></td><td>Depth of each tree (prevents overfitting).</td></tr><tr data-start="5709" data-end="5765"><td><code data-start="5711" data-end="5722">subsample</code></td><td>Fraction of samples used per tree.</td></tr><tr data-start="5766" data-end="5826"><td><code data-start="5768" data-end="5786">colsample_bytree</code></td><td>Fraction of features used per tree.</td></tr><tr data-start="5827" data-end="5896"><td><code data-start="5829" data-end="5836">gamma</code></td><td>Minimum loss reduction to split nodes (regularization).</td></tr><tr data-start="5897" data-end="5956"><td><code data-start="5899" data-end="5910">reg_alpha</code></td><td>L1 regularization (prevents overfitting).</td></tr><tr data-start="5957" data-end="6017"><td><code data-start="5959" data-end="5971">reg_lambda</code></td><td>L2 regularization (prevents overfitting).</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="6019" data-end="6022" class="">
<h1 data-start="6024" data-end="6054" class=""><strong data-start="6026" data-end="6054">📌 Advantages of XGBoost</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6055" data-end="6299" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6057" data-end="6098">Faster than regular Gradient Boosting</strong><br data-start="6098" data-end="6101">
✅ <strong data-start="6103" data-end="6153">More accurate due to second-order optimization</strong><br data-start="6153" data-end="6156">
✅ <strong data-start="6158" data-end="6187">Can handle missing values</strong><br data-start="6187" data-end="6190">
✅ <strong data-start="6192" data-end="6239">Supports parallel and distributed computing</strong><br data-start="6239" data-end="6242">
✅ <strong data-start="6244" data-end="6297">Can be used for structured data, text, and images</strong></p>
<hr data-start="6301" data-end="6304" class="">
<h1 data-start="6306" data-end="6352" class=""><strong data-start="6308" data-end="6352">📌 XGBoost vs. Other Boosting Algorithms</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="6353" data-end="6797" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="6353" data-end="6433"><tr data-start="6353" data-end="6433"><th data-start="6353" data-end="6367">Algorithm</th><th data-start="6367" data-end="6382">Optimization</th><th data-start="6382" data-end="6399">Regularization</th><th data-start="6399" data-end="6407">Speed</th><th data-start="6407" data-end="6433">Handles Large Datasets</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="6510" data-end="6797"><tr data-start="6510" data-end="6576"><td><strong data-start="6512" data-end="6533">Gradient Boosting</strong></td><td>Gradient Descent</td><td>Partial</td><td>Slow</td><td>No</td></tr><tr data-start="6577" data-end="6670"><td><strong data-start="6579" data-end="6590">XGBoost</strong></td><td>Gradient Boosting + Second-Order Approximation</td><td>Yes (L1 &amp; L2)</td><td>Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="6671" data-end="6738"><td><strong data-start="6673" data-end="6685">LightGBM</strong></td><td>Histogram-based Learning</td><td>Yes</td><td>Very Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="6739" data-end="6797"><td><strong data-start="6741" data-end="6753">CatBoost</strong></td><td>Categorical Boosting</td><td>Yes</td><td>Fast</td><td>Yes</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p data-start="6799" data-end="6929" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6801" data-end="6868">Use XGBoost when you need a balance between speed and accuracy.</strong><br data-start="6868" data-end="6871">
✅ <strong data-start="6873" data-end="6927">For large datasets, consider LightGBM or CatBoost.</strong></p>
<hr data-start="6931" data-end="6934" class="">
<h1 data-start="6936" data-end="6955" class=""><strong data-start="6938" data-end="6955">📌 Conclusion</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6956" data-end="7204" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6958" data-end="7032">XGBoost is one of the most powerful ML algorithms for structured data.</strong><br data-start="7032" data-end="7035">
✅ <strong data-start="7037" data-end="7090">Uses second-order gradients for fast convergence.</strong><br data-start="7090" data-end="7093">
✅ <strong data-start="7095" data-end="7145">Regularization (L1 &amp; L2) prevents overfitting.</strong><br data-start="7145" data-end="7148">
✅ <strong data-start="7150" data-end="7202">Widely used in Kaggle and industry applications.</strong></p>

<p data-start="615" data-end="872" class="">🔹 The series represents <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> as an <strong data-start="657" data-end="688">infinite sum of polynomials</strong>.<br data-start="689" data-end="692">
🔹 Each term contains a <strong data-start="716" data-end="743">higher-order derivative</strong> of <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span>, divided by the factorial of the order.<br data-start="797" data-end="800">
🔹 The <strong data-start="807" data-end="839">closer <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span> is to <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></strong>, the better the approximation.</p>
<h3 data-start="874" data-end="900" class=""><strong data-start="878" data-end="900">📌 General Formula</strong></h3>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!} (x-a)^n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <ul data-start="971" data-end="1158">
<li data-start="971" data-end="1047" class="">
<p data-start="973" data-end="1047" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f^{(n)}(a)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.138em; <li data-start="1048" data-end="1094" class="">
<p data-start="1050" data-end="1094" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">!</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n!</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mclose">!</span></span></span></span> (n factorial) normalizes each term.</p>

<li data-start="1095" data-end="1158" class="">

</ul>
<hr data-start="1160" data-end="1163" class="">

<hr data-start="1822" data-end="1825" class="">
<h2 data-start="1827" data-end="1883" class=""><strong data-start="1830" data-end="1883">📌 How is Taylor Series Used in Machine Learning?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1884" data-end="1956" class="">Taylor series plays a key role in <strong data-start="1918" data-end="1955">machine learning and optimization</strong>:</p>
<h3 data-start="1958" data-end="1999" class=""><strong data-start="1962" data-end="1999">🔹 1. Gradient Boosting &amp; XGBoost</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2003" data-end="2547">
<li data-start="2003" data-end="2086" class="">
<p data-start="2005" data-end="2086" class=""><strong data-start="2005" data-end="2055">XGBoost uses the second-order Taylor expansion</strong> to approximate loss functions.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2090" data-end="2232" class="">
<p data-start="2092" data-end="2232" class="">The <strong data-start="2096" data-end="2127">first derivative (gradient)</strong> helps in <strong data-start="2137" data-end="2161">directional movement</strong>, while the <strong data-start="2173" data-end="2204">second derivative (Hessian)</strong> controls the <strong data-start="2218" data-end="2231">step size</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2236" data-end="2547" class="">
<p data-start="2238" data-end="2260" class="">XGBoost loss function:</p>

<hr data-start="3043" data-end="3046" class="">
<h2 data-start="3048" data-end="3089" class=""><strong data-start="3051" data-end="3089">📌 Why is Taylor Series Important?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3090" data-end="3325" class="">✔ <strong data-start="3092" data-end="3144">Approximates complex functions using polynomials</strong><br data-start="3144" data-end="3147">
✔ <strong data-start="3149" data-end="3203">Used in optimization techniques for model training</strong><br data-start="3203" data-end="3206">
✔ <strong data-start="3208" data-end="3276">Enhances gradient-based learning (like XGBoost, Newton’s Method)</strong><br data-start="3276" data-end="3279">
✔ <strong data-start="3281" data-end="3323">Speeds up convergence in ML algorithms</strong></p>
<hr data-start="3327" data-end="3330" class="">
<h1 data-start="3332" data-end="3348" class=""><strong data-start="3334" data-end="3348">📌 Summary</strong></h1>
<p data-start="3349" data-end="3649" class="">✅ <strong data-start="3351" data-end="3428">Taylor Series approximates functions using an infinite sum of derivatives</strong>.<br data-start="3429" data-end="3432">

✅ <strong data-start="3521" data-end="3578">Improves computational efficiency in machine learning</strong>.<br data-start="3579" data-end="3582">
✅ <strong data-start="3584" data-end="3646">Essential in loss function optimization and model training</strong>.</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="92" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="90">📌 Stacking and Blending Ensembles in Machine Learning (Regression &amp; Classification)</strong></h1>
<p data-start="94" data-end="395" class="">Stacking and Blending are <strong data-start="120" data-end="152">ensemble learning techniques</strong> that improve model performance by combining predictions from multiple base models. They are more sophisticated than Bagging (e.g., Random Forest) and Boosting (e.g., XGBoost) because they <strong data-start="341" data-end="394">learn how to combine base model outputs optimally</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="397" data-end="400" class="">
<h1 data-start="402" data-end="433" class=""><strong data-start="404" data-end="431">📌 1. What is Stacking?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="434" data-end="649" class="">📌 <strong data-start="437" data-end="474">Stacking (Stacked Generalization)</strong> is an ensemble learning method where multiple base models (Level-0 models) generate predictions, which are then passed to a meta-model (Level-1 model) for final prediction.</p>
<p data-start="651" data-end="924" class="">🔹 Unlike simple averaging or majority voting, Stacking <strong data-start="707" data-end="749">learns how to best combine base models</strong>.<br data-start="750" data-end="753">
🔹 It is used for <strong data-start="771" data-end="809">both classification and regression</strong> tasks.<br data-start="816" data-end="819">
🔹 The meta-model is trained on the <strong data-start="855" data-end="870">out-of-fold</strong> predictions of base models to prevent data leakage.</p>
<hr data-start="926" data-end="929" class="">
<h2 data-start="931" data-end="966" class=""><strong data-start="934" data-end="966">📌 1.1 Stacking Architecture</strong></h2>
<p data-start="967" data-end="1006" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="971" data-end="1004">Level-0 Models (Base Models):</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1010" data-end="1166">
<li data-start="1010" data-end="1101" class="">
<p data-start="1012" data-end="1101" class="">Multiple diverse models (e.g., Decision Tree, Random Forest, XGBoost, Neural Networks).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1105" data-end="1166" class="">
<p data-start="1107" data-end="1166" class="">These models learn independently and provide predictions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1168" data-end="1205" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1172" data-end="1203">Meta-Model (Level-1 Model):</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1209" data-end="1393">
<li data-start="1209" data-end="1329" class="">
<p data-start="1211" data-end="1329" class="">A higher-level model (e.g., Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting) that learns from the predictions of base models.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1333" data-end="1393" class="">
<p data-start="1335" data-end="1393" class="">Takes predictions from Level-0 models as input features.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1395" data-end="1398" class="">
<h2 data-start="1400" data-end="1432" class=""><strong data-start="1403" data-end="1432">📌 1.2 Stacking Algorithm</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1433" data-end="1452" class=""><strong data-start="1433" data-end="1452">For Regression:</strong></p>
<ol data-start="1453" data-end="1776">
<li data-start="1453" data-end="1502" class="">
<p data-start="1456" data-end="1502" class="">Split data into <strong data-start="1472" data-end="1483">K folds</strong> (e.g., <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K=5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span></span></span></span>).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1503" data-end="1596" class="">
<p data-start="1506" data-end="1596" class="">Train each base model on <strong data-start="1531" data-end="1538">K-1</strong> folds and generate predictions on the <strong data-start="1577" data-end="1595">remaining fold</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1597" data-end="1655" class="">
<p data-start="1600" data-end="1655" class="">Repeat for all folds and store out-of-fold predictions.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1656" data-end="1723" class="">
<p data-start="1659" data-end="1723" class="">Train the meta-model using the out-of-fold predictions as input.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1724" data-end="1776" class="">
<p data-start="1727" data-end="1776" class="">Use the trained meta-model for final predictions.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="1778" data-end="1947" class=""><strong data-start="1778" data-end="1801">For Classification:</strong><br data-start="1801" data-end="1804">
Instead of using direct predictions, base classifiers output <strong data-start="1865" data-end="1887">probability scores</strong> for each class, which are used as input for the meta-model.</p>
<hr data-start="1949" data-end="1952" class="">
<h2 data-start="1954" data-end="1986" class=""><strong data-start="1957" data-end="1984">📌 1.3 Stacking Formula</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1987" data-end="1991" class="">Let:</p>
<ul data-start="1992" data-end="2108">
<li data-start="1992" data-end="2038" class="">
<p data-start="1994" data-end="2038" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h_1, h_2, ..., h_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">...</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> be <strong data-start="2022" data-end="2037">base models</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2039" data-end="2074" class="">
<p data-start="2041" data-end="2074" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> be the <strong data-start="2059" data-end="2073">meta-model</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2075" data-end="2108" class="">
<p data-start="2077" data-end="2108" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span></span></span></span> be the <strong data-start="2092" data-end="2107">true output</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="2110" data-end="2134" class="">The final prediction is:</p>

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> KFold
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.ensemble </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> RandomForestRegressor, GradientBoostingRegressor
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.linear_model </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> LinearRegression
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> numpy </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> np

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Sample dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = np.random.rand(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>), np.random.rand(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Define base models</span></span><span>
base_models = [RandomForestRegressor(), GradientBoostingRegressor()]
meta_model = LinearRegression()

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Out-of-fold predictions</span></span><span>
kf = KFold(n_splits=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>)
meta_features = np.zeros((X.shape[</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>], </span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">len</span></span><span>(base_models)))

</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">for</span></span><span> i, model </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">in</span></span><span> </span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">enumerate</span></span><span>(base_models):
    </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">for</span></span><span> train_idx, test_idx </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">in</span></span><span> kf.split(X):
        model.fit(X[train_idx], y[train_idx])
        meta_features[test_idx, i] = model.predict(X[test_idx])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train meta-model</span></span><span>
meta_model.fit(meta_features, y)
final_predictions = meta_model.predict(meta_features)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="3043" data-end="3046" class="">
<h1 data-start="3048" data-end="3077" class=""><strong data-start="3050" data-end="3077">📌 2. What is Blending?</strong></h1>
<p data-start="3078" data-end="3364" class="">📌 <strong data-start="3081" data-end="3093">Blending</strong> is a simplified version of Stacking where:<br data-start="3136" data-end="3139">
🔹 The meta-model learns from the predictions of base models on a <strong data-start="3205" data-end="3231">holdout validation set</strong> (instead of using K-fold out-of-fold predictions).<br data-start="3282" data-end="3285">
🔹 It is <strong data-start="3294" data-end="3316">simpler and faster</strong> than Stacking but may not generalize as well.</p>
<hr data-start="3366" data-end="3369" class="">
<h2 data-start="3371" data-end="3406" class=""><strong data-start="3374" data-end="3406">📌 2.1 Blending Architecture</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3407" data-end="3661" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="3411" data-end="3432">Train base models</strong> on the <strong data-start="3440" data-end="3456">training set</strong>.<br data-start="3457" data-end="3460">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="3464" data-end="3488">Use a validation set</strong> (e.g., 10-20% of data) to get predictions from the base models.<br data-start="3552" data-end="3555">
3️⃣ Train the <strong data-start="3569" data-end="3583">meta-model</strong> on these predictions.<br data-start="3605" data-end="3608">
4️⃣ Use the trained meta-model for final predictions.</p>
<hr data-start="3663" data-end="3666" class="">
<h2 data-start="3668" data-end="3700" class=""><strong data-start="3671" data-end="3698">📌 2.2 Blending Formula</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3701" data-end="3705" class="">Let:</p>
<ul data-start="3706" data-end="3849">
<li data-start="3706" data-end="3752" class="">
<p data-start="3708" data-end="3752" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f_1, f_2, ..., f_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; </li>
<li data-start="3753" data-end="3788" class="">
<p data-start="3755" data-end="3788" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> be the <strong data-start="3773" data-end="3787">meta-model</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3789" data-end="3849" class="">
<p data-start="3791" data-end="3849" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> be the weight assigned to each base model.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="3851" data-end="3875" class="">The final prediction is:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mtext>blend</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y_{\text{blend}} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_i f_i(x)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; <p data-start="3935" data-end="3998" class="">where <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> are learned weights for optimal blending.</p>

class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> RandomForestClassifier, GradientBoostingClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.linear_model </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> LogisticRegression
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> numpy </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> np

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Sample dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = np.random.rand(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>), np.random.randint(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">2</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Split data</span></span><span>
X_train, X_val, y_train, y_val = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train base models</span></span><span>
rf = RandomForestClassifier().fit(X_train, y_train)
gb = GradientBoostingClassifier().fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Get predictions for validation set</span></span><span>
meta_features = np.column_stack([rf.predict_proba(X_val)[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>], gb.predict_proba(X_val)[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>]])

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train meta-model</span></span><span>
meta_model = LogisticRegression().fit(meta_features, y_val)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Final predictions</span></span><span>
final_predictions = meta_model.predict(meta_features)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="4845" data-end="4848" class="">
<h1 data-start="4850" data-end="4883" class=""><strong data-start="4852" data-end="4883">📌 3. Stacking vs. Blending</strong></h1>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="4884" data-end="5375" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="4884" data-end="4917"><tr data-start="4884" data-end="4917"><th data-start="4884" data-end="4894">Feature</th><th data-start="4894" data-end="4905">Stacking</th><th data-start="4905" data-end="4917">Blending</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="4950" data-end="5375"><tr data-start="4950" data-end="5049"><td><strong data-start="4952" data-end="4972">Meta-model Input</strong></td><td>Out-of-fold predictions from base models</td><td>Predictions on validation set</td></tr><tr data-start="5050" data-end="5154"><td><strong data-start="5052" data-end="5075">Training Data Usage</strong></td><td>Full training data used in base models</td><td>Requires a holdout validation set</td></tr><tr data-start="5155" data-end="5224"><td><strong data-start="5157" data-end="5179">Computational Cost</strong></td><td>Higher (K-fold cross-validation)</td><td>Lower</td></tr><tr data-start="5225" data-end="5316"><td><strong data-start="5227" data-end="5245">Generalization</strong></td><td>Better (less overfitting)</td><td>May overfit if validation set is small</td></tr><tr data-start="5317" data-end="5375"><td><strong data-start="5319" data-end="5333">Complexity</strong></td><td>High (needs careful tuning)</td><td>Simpler</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="5377" data-end="5380" class="">
<h1 data-start="5382" data-end="5429" class=""><strong data-start="5384" data-end="5429">📌 4. Applications of Stacking &amp; Blending</strong></h1>
<p data-start="5430" data-end="5685" class="">✔ Used in <strong data-start="5440" data-end="5463">Kaggle Competitions</strong> (top-performing teams often use Stacking/Blending).<br data-start="5515" data-end="5518">
✔ Used in <strong data-start="5528" data-end="5579">finance, healthcare, and recommendation systems</strong> for improved predictions.<br data-start="5605" data-end="5608">
✔ Helps <strong data-start="5616" data-end="5644">reduce bias and variance</strong>, leading to <strong data-start="5657" data-end="5682">better generalization</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="5687" data-end="5690" class="">
<h1 data-start="5692" data-end="5711" class=""><strong data-start="5694" data-end="5711">📌 5. Summary</strong></h1>
<p data-start="5712" data-end="6063" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5714" data-end="5726">Stacking</strong> combines multiple base models using an out-of-fold training approach.<br data-start="5796" data-end="5799">
✅ <strong data-start="5801" data-end="5813">Blending</strong> is a simpler version of Stacking that uses a holdout validation set.<br data-start="5882" data-end="5885">
✅ Both methods improve <strong data-start="5908" data-end="5945">model accuracy and generalization</strong> by leveraging multiple models.<br data-start="5976" data-end="5979">
✅ Used in <strong data-start="5989" data-end="6020">classification &amp; regression</strong> to achieve <strong data-start="6032" data-end="6060">state-of-the-art results</strong>.</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="77" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="75">📌 Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC) - In-Depth Explanation</strong></h1>
<p data-start="79" data-end="340" class="">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC) is a <strong data-start="128" data-end="162">bottom-up clustering algorithm</strong> that starts with each data point as an <strong data-start="202" data-end="224">individual cluster</strong> and then <strong data-start="234" data-end="265">merges the closest clusters</strong> iteratively until a single cluster remains or a stopping condition is met.</p>
<hr data-start="342" data-end="345" class="">
<h2 data-start="347" data-end="394" class=""><strong data-start="350" data-end="392">📌 1. What is Hierarchical Clustering?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="395" data-end="561" class="">Hierarchical Clustering builds a <strong data-start="428" data-end="441">hierarchy</strong> of clusters, unlike K-Means, which requires specifying the number of clusters beforehand.<br data-start="531" data-end="534">
There are two main types:</p>
<ol data-start="562" data-end="722">
<li data-start="562" data-end="642" class="">
<p data-start="565" data-end="642" class=""><strong data-start="565" data-end="594">Agglomerative (Bottom-Up)</strong> – Starts with <strong data-start="609" data-end="614">N</strong> clusters and merges them.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="643" data-end="722" class="">
<p data-start="646" data-end="722" class=""><strong data-start="646" data-end="669">Divisive (Top-Down)</strong> – Starts with <strong data-start="684" data-end="705">one large cluster</strong> and splits it.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p data-start="724" data-end="827" class="">Since <strong data-start="730" data-end="777">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC)</strong> is the more common approach, we will focus on it.</p>
<hr data-start="829" data-end="832" class="">
<h2 data-start="834" data-end="893" class=""><strong data-start="837" data-end="893">📌 2. Steps in Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering</strong></h2>
<p data-start="894" data-end="931" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="898" data-end="929">Compute the Distance Matrix</strong></p>
<ul data-start="935" data-end="1029">
<li data-start="935" data-end="1029" class="">
<p data-start="937" data-end="1029" class="">Calculate pairwise distances between all points using a metric (e.g., Euclidean distance).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1031" data-end="1075" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1035" data-end="1073">Initialize Each Point as a Cluster</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1079" data-end="1126">
<li data-start="1079" data-end="1126" class="">
<p data-start="1081" data-end="1126" class="">Every data point starts as its own cluster.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1128" data-end="1164" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1132" data-end="1162">Merge the Closest Clusters</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1168" data-end="1235">
<li data-start="1168" data-end="1235" class="">
<p data-start="1170" data-end="1235" class="">Find the <strong data-start="1179" data-end="1203">two closest clusters</strong> based on a linkage criterion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1237" data-end="1285" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1241" data-end="1283">Repeat Until Stopping Condition is Met</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1289" data-end="1494">
<li data-start="1289" data-end="1494" class="">
<p data-start="1291" data-end="1346" class="">Continue merging clusters until one of the following:</p>
<ul data-start="1352" data-end="1494">
<li data-start="1352" data-end="1381" class="">
<p data-start="1354" data-end="1381" class="">A single cluster remains.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1387" data-end="1434" class="">
<p data-start="1389" data-end="1434" class="">A predefined number of clusters is reached.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1440" data-end="1494" class="">
<p data-start="1442" data-end="1494" class="">The distance between clusters exceeds a threshold.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1496" data-end="1533" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="1500" data-end="1531">Visualize with a Dendrogram</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1537" data-end="1669">
<li data-start="1537" data-end="1669" class="">
<p data-start="1539" data-end="1669" class="">The hierarchical merging process can be visualized using a <strong data-start="1598" data-end="1612">dendrogram</strong>, which helps determine the optimal number of clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1671" data-end="1674" class="">
<h2 data-start="1676" data-end="1733" class=""><strong data-start="1679" data-end="1731">📌 3. Linkage Methods (Cluster Merging Criteria)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1734" data-end="1824" class="">The choice of <strong data-start="1748" data-end="1766">linkage method</strong> determines how the distance between clusters is computed:</p>
<h3 data-start="1826" data-end="1870" class=""><strong data-start="1830" data-end="1870">1. Single Linkage (Minimum Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="1871" data-end="2146">
<li data-start="1871" data-end="1977" class="">
<p data-start="1873" data-end="1977" class="">The distance between two clusters is the <strong data-start="1914" data-end="1926">shortest</strong> distance between any two points in the clusters.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1978" data-end="2064" class="">
<p data-start="1980" data-end="1990" class="">Formula:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D(C_i, C_j) = \min \{ d(x, y) \, | \, x \in C_i, y \in C_j \}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; </li>
<li data-start="2065" data-end="2146" class="">
<p data-start="2067" data-end="2146" class="">Produces <strong data-start="2076" data-end="2105">long, chain-like clusters</strong> (can lead to poor clustering results).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2148" data-end="2194" class=""><strong data-start="2152" data-end="2194">2. Complete Linkage (Maximum Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2195" data-end="2427">
<li data-start="2195" data-end="2284" class="">
<p data-start="2197" data-end="2284" class="">The distance between two clusters is the <strong data-start="2238" data-end="2249">largest</strong> distance between any two points.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2285" data-end="2371" class="">
<p data-start="2287" data-end="2297" class="">Formula:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>max</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D(C_i, C_j) = \max \{ d(x, y) \, | \, x \in C_i, y \in C_j \}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; </li>
<li data-start="2372" data-end="2427" class="">
<p data-start="2374" data-end="2427" class="">Tends to form <strong data-start="2388" data-end="2424">compact, well-separated clusters</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2429" data-end="2471" class=""><strong data-start="2433" data-end="2471">3. Average Linkage (Mean Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2472" data-end="2722">
<li data-start="2472" data-end="2551" class="">
<p data-start="2474" data-end="2551" class="">The distance between clusters is the <strong data-start="2511" data-end="2522">average</strong> of all pairwise distances.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2552" data-end="2654" class="">
<p data-start="2554" data-end="2564" class="">Formula:</p>

<li data-start="2655" data-end="2722" class="">
<p data-start="2657" data-end="2722" class="">Provides a balance between <strong data-start="2684" data-end="2694">single</strong> and <strong data-start="2699" data-end="2711">complete</strong> linkage.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2724" data-end="2751" class=""><strong data-start="2728" data-end="2751">4. Centroid Linkage</strong></h3>

<li data-start="2752" data-end="2834" class="">
<p data-start="2754" data-end="2834" class="">The distance between two clusters is the distance between their <strong data-start="2818" data-end="2831">centroids</strong>.</p>
</li>

<li data-start="2983" data-end="3049" class="">

<hr data-start="3914" data-end="3917" class="">
<h2 data-start="3919" data-end="3975" class=""><strong data-start="3922" data-end="3975">📌 5. Dendrogram and Finding the Optimal Clusters</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3976" data-end="4064" class="">A <strong data-start="3978" data-end="3992">dendrogram</strong> is a tree-like diagram that shows how clusters are merged at each step.</p>
<p data-start="4066" data-end="4340" class="">🔹 The <strong data-start="4073" data-end="4083">height</strong> of a vertical line represents the <strong data-start="4118" data-end="4130">distance</strong> between merged clusters.<br data-start="4155" data-end="4158">
🔹 <strong data-start="4161" data-end="4187">Cutting the dendrogram</strong> at an appropriate level determines the <strong data-start="4227" data-end="4257">optimal number of clusters</strong>.<br data-start="4258" data-end="4261">
🔹 The <strong data-start="4268" data-end="4284">Elbow method</strong> or <strong data-start="4288" data-end="4308">Silhouette Score</strong> can help find the best cut-off.</p>
<hr data-start="4342" data-end="4345" class="">

</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> seaborn </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> sns
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_blobs

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Generate synthetic data</span></span><span>
X, _ = make_blobs(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">100</span></span><span>, centers=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">3</span></span><span>, cluster_std=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1.0</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Compute linkage matrix</span></span><span>
linkage_matrix = linkage(X, method=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ward'</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot dendrogram</span></span><span>
plt.figure(figsize=(</span><span><span class="hljs-number">10</span></span><span>, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>))
dendrogram(linkage_matrix)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Dendrogram for Hierarchical Clustering"</span></span><span>)
plt.xlabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Data Points"</span></span><span>)
plt.ylabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Distance"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply Agglomerative Clustering</span></span><span>
agg_clustering = AgglomerativeClustering(n_clusters=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">3</span></span><span>, linkage=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ward'</span></span><span>)
labels = agg_clustering.fit_predict(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot clusters</span></span><span>
plt.scatter(X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>], X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>], c=labels, cmap=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'viridis'</span></span><span>)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="5283" data-end="5286" class="">
<h2 data-start="5288" data-end="5334" class=""><strong data-start="5291" data-end="5334">📌 7. Advantages &amp; Disadvantages of AHC</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5335" data-end="5538" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5337" data-end="5351">Advantages</strong>:
✔️ No need to specify the number of clusters beforehand.<br data-start="5409" data-end="5412">
✔️ Produces a <strong data-start="5426" data-end="5452">hierarchical structure</strong> useful for understanding data.<br data-start="5483" data-end="5486">
✔️ Works well with small to medium-sized datasets.</p>
<p data-start="5540" data-end="5796" class="">❌ <strong data-start="5542" data-end="5559">Disadvantages</strong>:
✖️ <strong data-start="5564" data-end="5593">Computationally expensive</strong> for large datasets (<strong data-start="5614" data-end="5646">Time Complexity = <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(n^3)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></strong>).<br data-start="5648" data-end="5651">
✖️ <strong data-start="5654" data-end="5687">Sensitive to noise &amp; outliers</strong>, which can affect merging decisions.<br data-start="5724" data-end="5727">
✖️ <strong data-start="5730" data-end="5752">Cannot undo merges</strong>, unlike partitional clustering (K-Means).</p>
<hr data-start="5798" data-end="5801" class="">
<h2 data-start="5803" data-end="5856" class=""><strong data-start="5806" data-end="5856">📌 8. Applications of Agglomerative Clustering</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5857" data-end="6247" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="5860" data-end="5885">Customer Segmentation</strong> – Grouping similar customers based on purchasing behavior.<br data-start="5944" data-end="5947">
🔹 <strong data-start="5950" data-end="5979">Bioinformatics &amp; Genomics</strong> – Identifying gene expression patterns.<br data-start="6019" data-end="6022">
🔹 <strong data-start="6025" data-end="6046">Anomaly Detection</strong> – Finding unusual behavior in financial transactions.<br data-start="6100" data-end="6103">
🔹 <strong data-start="6106" data-end="6136">Text &amp; Document Clustering</strong> – Grouping similar articles or news.<br data-start="6173" data-end="6176">
🔹 <strong data-start="6179" data-end="6201">Image Segmentation</strong> – Clustering pixels for object recognition.</p>
<hr data-start="6249" data-end="6252" class="">
<h2 data-start="6254" data-end="6302" class=""><strong data-start="6257" data-end="6302">📌 9. AHC vs. Other Clustering Techniques</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="6303" data-end="6589" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="6303" data-end="6339"><tr data-start="6303" data-end="6339"><th data-start="6303" data-end="6313">Feature</th><th data-start="6313" data-end="6319">AHC</th><th data-start="6319" data-end="6329">K-Means</th><th data-start="6329" data-end="6339">DBSCAN</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="6376" data-end="6589"><tr data-start="6376" data-end="6443"><td><strong data-start="6378" data-end="6400">Number of Clusters</strong></td><td>Not required</td><td>Required</td><td>Not required</td></tr><tr data-start="6444" data-end="6505"><td><strong data-start="6446" data-end="6461">Scalability</strong></td><td>Slow for large datasets</td><td>Fast</td><td>Medium</td></tr><tr data-start="6506" data-end="6543"><td><strong data-start="6508" data-end="6525">Handles Noise</strong></td><td>No</td><td>No</td><td>Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="6544" data-end="6589"><td><strong data-start="6546" data-end="6563">Cluster Shape</strong></td><td>Any</td><td>Spherical</td><td>Any</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="6591" data-end="6594" class="">
<h1 data-start="6596" data-end="6616" class=""><strong data-start="6598" data-end="6616">📌 10. Summary</strong></h1>
<p data-start="6617" data-end="7013" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6619" data-end="6660">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering</strong> is a <strong data-start="6666" data-end="6679">bottom-up</strong> clustering approach.<br data-start="6700" data-end="6703">
✅ Uses <strong data-start="6710" data-end="6729">linkage methods</strong> like <strong data-start="6735" data-end="6793">Single, Complete, Average, Centroid, and Ward’s method</strong>.<br data-start="6794" data-end="6797">
✅ Produces a <strong data-start="6810" data-end="6824">dendrogram</strong> to visualize clustering.<br data-start="6849" data-end="6852">
✅ Best suited for <strong data-start="6870" data-end="6898">small to medium datasets</strong> where hierarchical relationships are meaningful.<br data-start="6947" data-end="6950">
✅ <strong data-start="6952" data-end="6969">Ward’s Method</strong> is the most commonly used linkage method.</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="60" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="60">📌 K-Means Clustering Algorithm - In-Depth Explanation</strong></h1>
<p data-start="62" data-end="285" class="">K-Means is a <strong data-start="75" data-end="126">centroid-based, unsupervised learning algorithm</strong> used for <strong data-start="136" data-end="150">clustering</strong> data into <strong data-start="161" data-end="173">K groups</strong>. It iteratively assigns data points to clusters based on their similarity and minimizes intra-cluster variance.</p>
<hr data-start="287" data-end="290" class="">
<h2 data-start="292" data-end="332" class=""><strong data-start="295" data-end="332">📌 1. What is K-Means Clustering?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="333" data-end="424" class="">K-Means is an <strong data-start="347" data-end="370">iterative algorithm</strong> that partitions a dataset into <strong data-start="402" data-end="416">K clusters</strong>, where:</p>
<ul data-start="425" data-end="654">
<li data-start="425" data-end="510" class="">
<p data-start="427" data-end="510" class="">Each cluster is represented by a <strong data-start="460" data-end="472">centroid</strong> (mean of the points in that cluster).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="511" data-end="568" class="">
<p data-start="513" data-end="568" class="">Each data point is assigned to the <strong data-start="548" data-end="567">nearest cluster</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="569" data-end="654" class="">
<p data-start="571" data-end="654" class="">The algorithm updates centroids iteratively to minimize <strong data-start="627" data-end="653">intra-cluster variance</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="656" data-end="687" class=""><strong data-start="660" data-end="687">Mathematical Objective:</strong></h3>
<p data-start="688" data-end="764" class="">Minimize the <strong data-start="701" data-end="732">sum of squared errors (SSE)</strong>, also known as the <strong data-start="752" data-end="763">inertia</strong>:</p>

<li data-start="971" data-end="1059" class="">
<p data-start="973" data-end="1059" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">||x_j - \mu_i||^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord">∣∣</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> = Squared Euclidean distance between a point and its centroid.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1061" data-end="1064" class="">
<h2 data-start="1066" data-end="1111" class=""><strong data-start="1069" data-end="1111">📌 2. How K-Means Works (Step-by-Step)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1113" data-end="1160" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1117" data-end="1158">Choose the number of clusters <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></strong></p>
<ul data-start="1164" data-end="1217">
<li data-start="1164" data-end="1217" class="">
<p data-start="1166" data-end="1217" class="">The user defines <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span>, the number of clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1219" data-end="1266" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1223" data-end="1264">Initialize <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span> Centroids Randomly</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1270" data-end="1327">
<li data-start="1270" data-end="1327" class="">
<p data-start="1272" data-end="1327" class="">Select <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span> random data points as initial centroids.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1329" data-end="1385" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1333" data-end="1383">Assign Each Data Point to the Nearest Centroid</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1389" data-end="1520">
<li data-start="1389" data-end="1468" class="">
<p data-start="1391" data-end="1468" class="">Compute the <strong data-start="1403" data-end="1425">Euclidean distance</strong> between each data point and the centroids.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1472" data-end="1520" class="">
<p data-start="1474" data-end="1520" class="">Assign each point to the <strong data-start="1499" data-end="1510">nearest</strong> centroid.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1522" data-end="1548" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1526" data-end="1546">Update Centroids</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1552" data-end="1641">
<li data-start="1552" data-end="1641" class="">
<p data-start="1554" data-end="1641" class="">Recalculate the centroid of each cluster by taking the <strong data-start="1609" data-end="1617">mean</strong> of all assigned points:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow></mfrac><munder><mo>∑</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></munder><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu_i = \frac{1}{|C_i|} \sum_{x_j \in C_i} x_j</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; <p data-start="1706" data-end="1740" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="1710" data-end="1738">Repeat Until Convergence</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1744" data-end="1892">
<li data-start="1744" data-end="1892" class="">
<p data-start="1746" data-end="1783" class="">Steps <strong data-start="1752" data-end="1763">3 and 4</strong> are repeated until:</p>
<ul data-start="1789" data-end="1892">
<li data-start="1789" data-end="1838" class="">
<p data-start="1791" data-end="1838" class=""><strong data-start="1791" data-end="1818">Centroids stop changing</strong> (minimal movement).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1844" data-end="1892" class="">
<p data-start="1846" data-end="1892" class=""><strong data-start="1846" data-end="1891">A maximum number of iterations is reached</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1894" data-end="1897" class="">
<h2 data-start="1899" data-end="1953" class=""><strong data-start="1902" data-end="1953">📌 3. Choosing the Right Number of Clusters (K)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1954" data-end="2032" class="">Selecting <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span> is crucial for good clustering. Some common methods include:</p>
<h3 data-start="2034" data-end="2058" class=""><strong data-start="2038" data-end="2058">1️⃣ Elbow Method</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2059" data-end="2189">
<li data-start="2059" data-end="2094" class="">
<p data-start="2061" data-end="2094" class="">Plot <strong data-start="2066" data-end="2083">inertia (SSE)</strong> vs. <strong data-start="2088" data-end="2093">K</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2095" data-end="2189" class="">
<p data-start="2097" data-end="2189" class="">The <strong data-start="2101" data-end="2118">"elbow point"</strong> (where SSE stops decreasing significantly) suggests the optimal <strong data-start="2183" data-end="2188">K</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>K</mi></munderover><munder><mo>∑</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></munder><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">SSE = \sum_{i=1}^{K} \sum_{x_j \in C_i} ||x_j - \mu_i||^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">SSE</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 3.32em; <h3 data-start="2256" data-end="2284" class=""><strong data-start="2260" data-end="2284">2️⃣ Silhouette Score</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2285" data-end="2436">
<li data-start="2285" data-end="2366" class="">
<p data-start="2287" data-end="2366" class="">Measures <strong data-start="2296" data-end="2311">how similar</strong> a data point is to its own cluster vs. other clusters.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2367" data-end="2436" class="">
<p data-start="2369" data-end="2436" class="">Ranges from <strong data-start="2381" data-end="2405">-1 (poor clustering)</strong> to <strong data-start="2409" data-end="2435">1 (perfect clustering)</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>max</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S = \frac{b - a}{\max(a, b)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.3074em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop">max</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<p data-start="2474" data-end="2480" class="">where:</p>
<ul data-start="2481" data-end="2580">
<li data-start="2481" data-end="2527" class="">
<p data-start="2483" data-end="2527" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span> = Average distance within a cluster.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2528" data-end="2580" class="">
<p data-start="2530" data-end="2580" class=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">b</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span></span></span></span> = Average distance to the nearest cluster.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2582" data-end="2608" class=""><strong data-start="2586" data-end="2608">3️⃣ Gap Statistics</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2609" data-end="2717">
<li data-start="2609" data-end="2717" class="">
<p data-start="2611" data-end="2717" class="">Compares <strong data-start="2620" data-end="2631">inertia</strong> to a <strong data-start="2637" data-end="2659">randomized dataset</strong> and determines if clustering is better than random noise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2719" data-end="2722" class="">
<h2 data-start="2724" data-end="2769" class=""><strong data-start="2727" data-end="2769">📌 4. Distance Metrics Used in K-Means</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2770" data-end="2818" class="">By default, K-Means uses <strong data-start="2795" data-end="2817">Euclidean Distance</strong>:</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mo>∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(x, y) = \sqrt{\sum (x_i - y_i)^2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p data-start="2863" data-end="2894" class="">Other distance metrics include:</p>
<ul data-start="2895" data-end="3056">
<li data-start="2895" data-end="2953" class="">
<p data-start="2897" data-end="2953" class=""><strong data-start="2897" data-end="2919">Manhattan Distance</strong>: <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>∑</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(x, y) = \sum |x_i - y_i|</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em;
