<hr data-start="3739" data-end="3742" class="">
<h2 data-start="3744" data-end="3773" class=""><strong data-start="3747" data-end="3773">📌 6. K-Means Variants</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="3774" data-end="3821" class=""><strong data-start="3778" data-end="3821">1️⃣ K-Means++ (Improved Initialization)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="3822" data-end="3970">
<li data-start="3822" data-end="3891" class="">
<p data-start="3824" data-end="3891" class="">Instead of random initialization, selects <strong data-start="3866" data-end="3880">spread-out</strong> centroids.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3892" data-end="3932" class="">
<p data-start="3894" data-end="3932" class="">Reduces risk of <strong data-start="3910" data-end="3931">poor local minima</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3933" data-end="3970" class="">
<p data-start="3935" data-end="3970" class="">Used in <strong data-start="3943" data-end="3969">scikit-learn’s K-Means</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="3972" data-end="4002" class=""><strong data-start="3976" data-end="4002">2️⃣ Mini-Batch K-Means</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="4003" data-end="4095">
<li data-start="4003" data-end="4062" class="">
<p data-start="4005" data-end="4062" class="">Uses <strong data-start="4010" data-end="4033">random mini-batches</strong> instead of the full dataset.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="4063" data-end="4095" class="">
<p data-start="4065" data-end="4095" class="">Faster for <strong data-start="4076" data-end="4094">large datasets</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="4097" data-end="4137" class=""><strong data-start="4101" data-end="4137">3️⃣ Fuzzy C-Means (Soft K-Means)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="4138" data-end="4207">
<li data-start="4138" data-end="4207" class="">
<p data-start="4140" data-end="4207" class="">Instead of <strong data-start="4151" data-end="4171">hard assignments</strong>, assigns probabilities to clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="4209" data-end="4212" class="">
<h2 data-start="4214" data-end="4253" class=""><strong data-start="4217" data-end="4253">📌 7. Advantages &amp; Disadvantages</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4254" data-end="4435" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4256" data-end="4270">Advantages</strong>:
✔️ <strong data-start="4275" data-end="4297">Fast and efficient</strong> (scales well to large datasets).<br data-start="4330" data-end="4333">
✔️ <strong data-start="4336" data-end="4368">Simple and easy to implement</strong>.<br data-start="4369" data-end="4372">
✔️ <strong data-start="4375" data-end="4432">Works well when clusters are spherical &amp; evenly sized</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="4437" data-end="4745" class="">❌ <strong data-start="4439" data-end="4456">Disadvantages</strong>:
✖️ <strong data-start="4461" data-end="4492">Requires specifying <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></strong> beforehand.<br data-start="4504" data-end="4507">
✖️ <strong data-start="4510" data-end="4535">Sensitive to outliers</strong> (single outlier can shift centroid drastically).<br data-start="4584" data-end="4587">
✖️ <strong data-start="4590" data-end="4627">Fails with non-spherical clusters</strong> (e.g., moon-shaped clusters).<br data-start="4657" data-end="4660">
✖️ <strong data-start="4663" data-end="4698">May converge to a local minimum</strong> (random initialization can cause instability).</p>
<hr data-start="4747" data-end="4750" class="">
<h2 data-start="4752" data-end="4788" class=""><strong data-start="4755" data-end="4788">📌 8. Applications of K-Means</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4789" data-end="5123" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="4792" data-end="4817">Customer Segmentation</strong> – E-commerce &amp; marketing analysis.<br data-start="4852" data-end="4855">
🔹 <strong data-start="4858" data-end="4879">Image Compression</strong> – Reducing color space by grouping similar colors.<br data-start="4930" data-end="4933">
🔹 <strong data-start="4936" data-end="4957">Anomaly Detection</strong> – Identifying fraudulent transactions.<br data-start="4996" data-end="4999">
🔹 <strong data-start="5002" data-end="5025">Document Clustering</strong> – Organizing news articles into topics.<br data-start="5065" data-end="5068">
🔹 <strong data-start="5071" data-end="5083">Genomics</strong> – Grouping similar genetic sequences.</p>
<hr data-start="5125" data-end="5128" class="">
<h2 data-start="5130" data-end="5179" class=""><strong data-start="5133" data-end="5179">📌 9. K-Means vs. Other Clustering Methods</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5180" data-end="5492" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5180" data-end="5227"><tr data-start="5180" data-end="5227"><th data-start="5180" data-end="5191">Feature</th><th data-start="5191" data-end="5201">K-Means</th><th data-start="5201" data-end="5210">DBSCAN</th><th data-start="5210" data-end="5227">Agglomerative</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5274" data-end="5492"><tr data-start="5274" data-end="5327"><td><strong data-start="5276" data-end="5303">Need to specify <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="5328" data-end="5376"><td><strong data-start="5330" data-end="5352">Handles noise well</strong></td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="5377" data-end="5421"><td><strong data-start="5379" data-end="5394">Scalability</strong></td><td>✅ High</td><td>❌ Low</td><td>❌ Low</td></tr><tr data-start="5422" data-end="5492"><td><strong data-start="5424" data-end="5445">Shape of Clusters</strong></td><td>🔵 Spherical</td><td>🌀 Arbitrary</td><td>🔵 Spherical</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="5494" data-end="5497" class="">
<h2 data-start="5499" data-end="5520" class=""><strong data-start="5502" data-end="5520">📌 10. Summary</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5521" data-end="6013" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5523" data-end="5587">K-Means is an iterative, centroid-based clustering algorithm</strong> that assigns data points to clusters based on <strong data-start="5634" data-end="5670">minimum distance to the centroid</strong>.<br data-start="5671" data-end="5674">
✅ Uses the <strong data-start="5685" data-end="5716">sum of squared errors (SSE)</strong> as the optimization criterion.<br data-start="5747" data-end="5750">
✅ The <strong data-start="5756" data-end="5772">Elbow Method</strong> and <strong data-start="5777" data-end="5797">Silhouette Score</strong> help determine the <strong data-start="5817" data-end="5836">optimal <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></strong>.<br data-start="5837" data-end="5840">
✅ Works well for <strong data-start="5857" data-end="5921">spherical clusters but struggles with non-spherical clusters</strong>.<br data-start="5922" data-end="5925">
✅ <strong data-start="5927" data-end="5977">Variants like K-Means++ and Mini-Batch K-Means</strong> improve efficiency and stability.</p>
<p data-start="6015" data-end="6090" class="">🚀 <strong data-start="6018" data-end="6090" data-is-last-node="">Would you like a comparison with DBSCAN or other clustering dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="72" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="72">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC) - In-Depth Explanation</strong></h1>
<p data-start="74" data-end="325" class="">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC) is a <strong data-start="123" data-end="136">bottom-up</strong> approach to clustering that groups data points into a hierarchy of clusters based on their similarity. Unlike <strong data-start="247" data-end="258">K-Means</strong>, it does not require specifying the number of clusters beforehand.</p>
<hr data-start="327" data-end="330" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="332" data-end="397" class=""><strong data-start="335" data-end="397">📌 1. What is Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC)?</strong></h2>
<ul data-start="398" data-end="787">
<li data-start="398" data-end="595" class="" style="">
<p data-start="400" data-end="595" class="">AHC is a <strong data-start="409" data-end="436">hierarchical clustering</strong> algorithm that starts with each data point as its <strong data-start="487" data-end="502">own cluster</strong> and merges the <strong data-start="518" data-end="534">most similar</strong> clusters <strong data-start="544" data-end="559">iteratively</strong> until only <strong data-start="571" data-end="594">one cluster remains</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="596" data-end="691" class="" style="">
<p data-start="598" data-end="691" class="">The result is a <strong data-start="614" data-end="628">dendrogram</strong>, a tree-like structure representing the hierarchy of clusters.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="692" data-end="787" class="" style="">
<p data-start="694" data-end="787" class="">The final number of clusters can be <strong data-start="730" data-end="766">chosen by cutting the dendrogram</strong> at a specific level.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="789" data-end="792" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="794" data-end="840" class=""><strong data-start="797" data-end="840">📌 2. How Does AHC Work? (Step-by-Step)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="841" data-end="874" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="845" data-end="872">Compute Distance Matrix</strong></p>
<ul data-start="878" data-end="1002">
<li data-start="878" data-end="1002" class="" style="">
<p data-start="880" data-end="1002" class="">Calculate pairwise distances between all data points using a <strong data-start="941" data-end="960">distance metric</strong> (e.g., <strong data-start="968" data-end="1000">Euclidean, Manhattan, Cosine</strong>).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1004" data-end="1055" class="">2️⃣ <strong data-start="1008" data-end="1053">Assign Each Data Point to Its Own Cluster</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1059" data-end="1124">
<li data-start="1059" data-end="1124" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1061" data-end="1124" class="">Initially, every point is treated as an <strong data-start="1101" data-end="1123">individual cluster</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1126" data-end="1162" class="">3️⃣ <strong data-start="1130" data-end="1160">Merge the Closest Clusters</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1166" data-end="1309">
<li data-start="1166" data-end="1269" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1168" data-end="1269" class="">Find the <strong data-start="1177" data-end="1201">two closest clusters</strong> based on a <strong data-start="1213" data-end="1234">linkage criterion</strong> (single, complete, average, etc.).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1273" data-end="1309" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1275" data-end="1309" class="">Merge them into a <strong data-start="1293" data-end="1308">new cluster</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1311" data-end="1347" class="">4️⃣ <strong data-start="1315" data-end="1345">Update the Distance Matrix</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1351" data-end="1437">
<li data-start="1351" data-end="1437" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1353" data-end="1437" class="">Recompute distances between the <strong data-start="1385" data-end="1409">newly formed cluster</strong> and the remaining clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1439" data-end="1486" class="">5️⃣ <strong data-start="1443" data-end="1484">Repeat Until Only One Cluster Remains</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1490" data-end="1569">
<li data-start="1490" data-end="1569" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1492" data-end="1569" class="">Continue merging clusters <strong data-start="1518" data-end="1533">iteratively</strong> until a <strong data-start="1542" data-end="1568">single cluster is left</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1571" data-end="1636" class="">6️⃣ <strong data-start="1575" data-end="1634">Build the Dendrogram &amp; Determine the Number of Clusters</strong></p>
<ul data-start="1640" data-end="1725">
<li data-start="1640" data-end="1725" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1642" data-end="1725" class="">The dendrogram is <strong data-start="1660" data-end="1685">cut at a chosen level</strong> to form the desired number of clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1727" data-end="1730" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="1732" data-end="1796" class=""><strong data-start="1735" data-end="1796">📌 3. Types of Linkage Methods (Cluster Merging Criteria)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1797" data-end="1887" class="">The way we measure the "distance" between clusters depends on the <strong data-start="1863" data-end="1881">linkage method</strong> used:</p>
<h3 data-start="1889" data-end="1934" class=""><strong data-start="1893" data-end="1934">1️⃣ Single Linkage (Minimum Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="1935" data-end="2030">
<li data-start="1935" data-end="2030" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1937" data-end="2030" class="">Distance between two clusters = <strong data-start="1969" data-end="1981">smallest</strong> distance between any two points in the clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display" style=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>min</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">}</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">∀</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(A, B) = \min \{ d(x, y) \}, \quad \forall x \in A, y \in B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p data-start="2100" data-end="2213" class="">✅ Preserves the <strong data-start="2116" data-end="2138">original structure</strong> but can form <strong data-start="2152" data-end="2181">long, chain-like clusters</strong>.<br data-start="2182" data-end="2185">
❌ Sensitive to <strong data-start="2200" data-end="2212">outliers</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="2215" data-end="2218" class="" style="">
<h3 data-start="2220" data-end="2267" class=""><strong data-start="2224" data-end="2267">2️⃣ Complete Linkage (Maximum Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2268" data-end="2362">
<li data-start="2268" data-end="2362" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2270" data-end="2362" class="">Distance between two clusters = <strong data-start="2302" data-end="2313">largest</strong> distance between any two points in the clusters.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>max</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">}</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">∀</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(A, B) = \max \{ d(x, y) \}, \quad \forall x \in A, y \in B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p data-start="2432" data-end="2528" class="">✅ Results in <strong data-start="2445" data-end="2479">compact, evenly-sized clusters</strong>.<br data-start="2480" data-end="2483">
❌ Can be <strong data-start="2492" data-end="2527">sensitive to noise and outliers</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="2530" data-end="2533" class="" style="">
<h3 data-start="2535" data-end="2578" class=""><strong data-start="2539" data-end="2578">3️⃣ Average Linkage (Mean Distance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2579" data-end="2662">
<li data-start="2579" data-end="2662" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2581" data-end="2662" class="">Distance between two clusters = <strong data-start="2613" data-end="2633">average distance</strong> between all pairs of points.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display" style=""><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi>A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi>B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow></mfrac><munder><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></munder><munder><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></munder><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(A, B) = \frac{1}{|A||B|} \sum_{x \in A} \sum_{y \in B} d(x, y)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <p data-start="2736" data-end="2832" class="">✅ Produces <strong data-start="2747" data-end="2777">balanced, natural clusters</strong>.<br data-start="2778" data-end="2781">
❌ <strong data-start="2783" data-end="2812">Computationally expensive</strong> for large datasets.</p>
<hr data-start="2834" data-end="2837" class="" style="">
<h3 data-start="2839" data-end="2887" class=""><strong data-start="2843" data-end="2887">4️⃣ Centroid Linkage (Mean of Centroids)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2888" data-end="2976">
<li data-start="2888" data-end="2976" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2890" data-end="2976" class="">Distance between clusters = distance between their <strong data-start="2941" data-end="2954">centroids</strong> (mean of all points).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>A</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>B</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(A, B) = || \mu_A - \mu_B ||</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; ❌ Affected by <strong data-start="3073" data-end="3090">cluster shape</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="3093" data-end="3096" class="" style="">
<h3 data-start="3098" data-end="3146" class=""><strong data-start="3102" data-end="3146">5️⃣ Ward’s Linkage (Minimizing Variance)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="3147" data-end="3242">
<li data-start="3147" data-end="3227" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3149" data-end="3227" class="">Merges clusters that lead to the <strong data-start="3182" data-end="3226">least increase in intra-cluster variance</strong>.</p>

✅ Results in <strong data-start="3454" data-end="3490">compact, well-separated clusters</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="3495" data-end="3498" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="3500" data-end="3536" class=""><strong data-start="3503" data-end="3536">📌 4. Distance Metrics in AHC</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3537" data-end="3609" class="">AHC requires a distance metric to compute <strong data-start="3579" data-end="3593">similarity</strong> between points:</p>
<h3 data-start="3611" data-end="3643" class=""><strong data-start="3615" data-end="3643">Common Distance Metrics:</strong></h3>
<p data-start="3644" data-end="3681" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="3648" data-end="3670">Euclidean Distance</strong> (default):</p>
<span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mo>∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d(x, y) = \sqrt{\sum (x_i - y_i)^2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_blobs

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Generate synthetic dataset</span></span><span>

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Perform Hierarchical Clustering</span></span><span>
linked = linkage(X, method=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'ward'</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot the Dendrogram</span></span><span>

plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Dendrogram for Agglomerative Clustering"</span></span><span>)
plt.xlabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Data Points"</span></span><span>)
plt.ylabel(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Distance"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply Agglomerative Clustering with 4 clusters</span></span><span>
agglo = AgglomerativeClustering(n_clusters=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">4</span></span><span>, linkage=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"ward"</span></span><span>)
labels = agglo.fit_predict(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot the Clusters</span></span><span>
plt.scatter(X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>], X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>], c=labels, cmap=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'viridis'</span></span><span>, marker=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'o'</span></span><span>)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"Agglomerative Clustering"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="4866" data-end="4869" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="4871" data-end="4917" class=""><strong data-start="4874" data-end="4917">📌 6. Advantages &amp; Disadvantages of AHC</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4918" data-end="5107" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4920" data-end="4935">Advantages:</strong>
✔️ <strong data-start="4939" data-end="4969">No need to specify <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></strong> in advance.<br data-start="4981" data-end="4984">
✔️ <strong data-start="4987" data-end="5029">Works well with non-spherical clusters</strong> (unlike K-Means).<br data-start="5047" data-end="5050">
✔️ <strong data-start="5053" data-end="5077">Produces a hierarchy</strong> (useful for visualization).</p>
<p data-start="5109" data-end="5277" class="">❌ <strong data-start="5111" data-end="5129">Disadvantages:</strong>
✖️ <strong data-start="5133" data-end="5162">Computationally expensive</strong> for large datasets (<span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(n^2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span>).<br data-start="5197" data-end="5200">
✖️ <strong data-start="5203" data-end="5232">Not scalable for big data</strong>.<br data-start="5233" data-end="5236">
✖️ <strong data-start="5239" data-end="5274">Sensitive to noise and outliers</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="5279" data-end="5282" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="5284" data-end="5323" class=""><strong data-start="5287" data-end="5323">📌 7. AHC vs. K-Means vs. DBSCAN</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="5324" data-end="5679" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="5324" data-end="5382"><tr data-start="5324" data-end="5382"><th data-start="5324" data-end="5335">Feature</th><th data-start="5335" data-end="5362">Agglomerative Clustering</th><th data-start="5362" data-end="5372">K-Means</th><th data-start="5372" data-end="5382">DBSCAN</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="5442" data-end="5679"><tr data-start="5442" data-end="5500"><td><strong data-start="5444" data-end="5476">Requires <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span> beforehand?</strong></td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="5501" data-end="5580"><td><strong data-start="5503" data-end="5518">Scalability</strong></td><td>❌ Poor (<span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(n^2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span>)</td><td>✅ Fast</td><td>❌ Slow for high dimensions</td></tr><tr data-start="5581" data-end="5627"><td><strong data-start="5583" data-end="5603">Handles Outliers</strong></td><td>❌ No</td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="5628" data-end="5679"><td><strong data-start="5630" data-end="5647">Cluster Shape</strong></td><td>✅ Any</td><td>❌ Spherical</td><td>✅ Any</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="5681" data-end="5684" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="5686" data-end="5718" class=""><strong data-start="5689" data-end="5718">📌 8. Applications of AHC</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5719" data-end="5988" class="">📌 <strong data-start="5722" data-end="5745">Biological Taxonomy</strong> – Classifying species into a hierarchy.<br data-start="5785" data-end="5788">
📌 <strong data-start="5791" data-end="5814">Document Clustering</strong> – Organizing articles into topics.<br data-start="5849" data-end="5852">
📌 <strong data-start="5855" data-end="5877">Image Segmentation</strong> – Grouping similar pixel regions.<br data-start="5911" data-end="5914">
📌 <strong data-start="5917" data-end="5944">Social Network Analysis</strong> – Clustering users with similar behavior.</p>
<hr data-start="5990" data-end="5993" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="5995" data-end="6015" class=""><strong data-start="5998" data-end="6015">📌 9. Summary</strong></h2>
<p data-start="6016" data-end="6433" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6018" data-end="6065">Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC)</strong> is a <strong data-start="6071" data-end="6095">bottom-up clustering</strong> technique that iteratively merges the closest clusters.<br data-start="6151" data-end="6154">
✅ AHC uses different <strong data-start="6175" data-end="6194">linkage methods</strong> like <strong data-start="6200" data-end="6259">Single, Complete, Average, Centroid, and Ward's Linkage</strong>.<br data-start="6260" data-end="6263">
✅ The <strong data-start="6269" data-end="6283">Dendrogram</strong> helps determine the optimal number of clusters.<br data-start="6331" data-end="6334">
✅ <strong data-start="6336" data-end="6385">AHC is powerful but computationally expensive</strong>, making it unsuitable for <strong data-start="6412" data-end="6430">large datasets</strong>.</p>

dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="106" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="104">DBSCAN Clustering (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise) - A Complete Guide</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="108" data-end="143" class=""><strong data-start="111" data-end="143">📌 1. Introduction to DBSCAN</strong></h2>
<p data-start="144" data-end="336" class=""><strong data-start="144" data-end="216">DBSCAN (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise)</strong> is a clustering algorithm that groups together <strong data-start="264" data-end="281">dense regions</strong> of data points and identifies <strong data-start="312" data-end="324">outliers</strong> as noise.</p>
<p data-start="338" data-end="515" class="">Unlike <strong data-start="345" data-end="397">K-Means or Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering</strong>, DBSCAN does not require specifying the number of clusters beforehand and can find clusters of <strong data-start="493" data-end="512">arbitrary shape</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="517" data-end="702" class="">✅ <strong data-start="519" data-end="558">DBSCAN is particularly useful when:</strong><br data-start="558" data-end="561">
✔️ Clusters have <strong data-start="578" data-end="598">irregular shapes</strong>.<br data-start="599" data-end="602">
✔️ Data contains <strong data-start="619" data-end="640">noise or outliers</strong>.<br data-start="641" data-end="644">
✔️ You <strong data-start="651" data-end="665">don’t know</strong> the number of clusters in advance.</p>
<hr data-start="704" data-end="707" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="709" data-end="743" class=""><strong data-start="712" data-end="743">📌 2. How Does DBSCAN Work?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="744" data-end="852" class="">DBSCAN is based on <strong data-start="763" data-end="787">density reachability</strong> and <strong data-start="792" data-end="816">density connectivity</strong>. It relies on two key parameters:</p>
<p data-start="854" data-end="1068" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="858" data-end="873">ε (epsilon)</strong>: Defines the <strong data-start="887" data-end="897">radius</strong> within which points are considered <strong data-start="933" data-end="946">neighbors</strong>.<br data-start="947" data-end="950">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="954" data-end="981">MinPts (Minimum Points)</strong>: Minimum number of <strong data-start="1001" data-end="1011">points</strong> required to form a <strong data-start="1031" data-end="1047">dense region</strong> (i.e., a cluster).</p>
<h3 data-start="1070" data-end="1103" class=""><strong data-start="1074" data-end="1103">Steps of DBSCAN Algorithm</strong></h3>
<p data-start="1104" data-end="1439" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="1108" data-end="1143">Choose a random unvisited point</strong> and check its neighborhood within radius <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span>.<br data-start="1203" data-end="1206">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="1210" data-end="1258">If the number of neighbors <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≥</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\geq</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7719em; vertical-align: -0.136em;"></span><span class="mrel">≥</span></span></span></span> MinPts</strong>, a new cluster is formed.<br data-start="1284" data-end="1287">
3️⃣ <strong data-start="1291" data-end="1313">Expand the cluster</strong> by adding all density-reachable points.<br data-start="1353" data-end="1356">
4️⃣ <strong data-start="1360" data-end="1370">Repeat</strong> until all points are visited.<br data-start="1400" data-end="1403">
5️⃣ <strong data-start="1407" data-end="1436">Classify remaining points</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="1443" data-end="1712">
<li data-start="1443" data-end="1506" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1445" data-end="1506" class=""><strong data-start="1445" data-end="1460">Core Points</strong>: Points with at least <strong data-start="1483" data-end="1493">MinPts</strong> neighbors.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1510" data-end="1628" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1512" data-end="1628" class=""><strong data-start="1512" data-end="1529">Border Points</strong>: Points with <strong data-start="1543" data-end="1563">less than MinPts</strong> but inside the <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span>-neighborhood of a core point.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1632" data-end="1712" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1634" data-end="1712" class=""><strong data-start="1634" data-end="1661">Noise Points (Outliers)</strong>: Points that are neither core nor border points.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="1714" data-end="1717" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="1719" data-end="1754" class=""><strong data-start="1722" data-end="1754">📌 3. Key Concepts in DBSCAN</strong></h2>
<h3 data-start="1755" data-end="1778" class=""><strong data-start="1759" data-end="1778">1️⃣ Core Points</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="1782" data-end="1926">
<li data-start="1782" data-end="1887" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1784" data-end="1887" class="">A point <strong data-start="1792" data-end="1797">P</strong> is a <strong data-start="1803" data-end="1817">core point</strong> if it has at least <strong data-start="1837" data-end="1847">MinPts</strong> within its <strong data-start="1859" data-end="1871">ε-radius</strong> neighborhood.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1891" data-end="1926" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1893" data-end="1926" class="">Core points <strong data-start="1905" data-end="1925">form the cluster</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="1928" data-end="1953" class=""><strong data-start="1932" data-end="1953">2️⃣ Border Points</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="1957" data-end="2102">
<li data-start="1957" data-end="2102" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1959" data-end="2102" class="">A point <strong data-start="1967" data-end="1972">Q</strong> is a <strong data-start="1978" data-end="1994">border point</strong> if it has <strong data-start="2005" data-end="2026">fewer than MinPts</strong> within its <strong data-start="2038" data-end="2050">ε-radius</strong>, but it is <strong data-start="2062" data-end="2083">density-reachable</strong> from a core point.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2104" data-end="2132" class=""><strong data-start="2108" data-end="2132">3️⃣ Noise (Outliers)</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2136" data-end="2211">
<li data-start="2136" data-end="2211" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2138" data-end="2211" class="">Points that <strong data-start="2150" data-end="2182">do not belong to any cluster</strong> are classified as <strong data-start="2201" data-end="2210">noise</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2213" data-end="2245" class=""><strong data-start="2217" data-end="2245">4️⃣ Density Reachability</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2249" data-end="2353">
<li data-start="2249" data-end="2353" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2251" data-end="2353" class="">A point <strong data-start="2259" data-end="2264">Q</strong> is <strong data-start="2268" data-end="2289">density-reachable</strong> from <strong data-start="2295" data-end="2300">P</strong> if there is a <strong data-start="2315" data-end="2339">chain of core points</strong> leading to Q.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2355" data-end="2387" class=""><strong data-start="2359" data-end="2387">5️⃣ Density Connectivity</strong></h3>
<ul data-start="2391" data-end="2498">
<li data-start="2391" data-end="2498" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2393" data-end="2498" class="">Two points are <strong data-start="2408" data-end="2429">density-connected</strong> if they are <strong data-start="2442" data-end="2468">both density-reachable</strong> from a <strong data-start="2476" data-end="2497">common core point</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="2500" data-end="2503" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="2505" data-end="2545" class=""><strong data-start="2508" data-end="2545">📌 4. DBSCAN Algorithm Pseudocode</strong></h2>

Mark all points as unvisited.
2. For each unvisited point P:
   a) If P has at least MinPts neighbors within radius ε:
      - Mark P as a core point.
      - Create a new cluster and add all density-reachable points.
   b) Else, mark P as noise.
3. Repeat until all points are visited.
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="2854" data-end="2857" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="2859" data-end="2901" class=""><strong data-start="2862" data-end="2901">📌 5. Choosing the Right Parameters</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2902" data-end="2952" class=""><strong data-start="2902" data-end="2952">1️⃣ How to Select <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span> (Epsilon)?</strong></p>
<ul data-start="2953" data-end="3237">
<li data-start="2953" data-end="3237" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2955" data-end="3001" class="">Use the <strong data-start="2963" data-end="2983">k-distance graph</strong> (Elbow Method):</p>
<ol data-start="3004" data-end="3237">
<li data-start="3004" data-end="3105" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3007" data-end="3105" class="">Compute distances to the <strong data-start="3032" data-end="3057">k-th nearest neighbor</strong> for all points (typically, <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k = MinPts</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">M</span><span class="mord mathnormal">in</span><span class="mord mathnormal">Pt</span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span></span></span></span>).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3108" data-end="3153" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3111" data-end="3153" class="">Plot these distances in ascending order.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3156" data-end="3237" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3159" data-end="3237" class="">The <strong data-start="3163" data-end="3178">elbow point</strong> in the plot suggests a good value for <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="3239" data-end="3268" class=""><strong data-start="3239" data-end="3268">2️⃣ How to Select MinPts?</strong></p>
<ul data-start="3269" data-end="3421">
<li data-start="3269" data-end="3421" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3271" data-end="3287" class="">Rule of thumb:</p>
<ul data-start="3290" data-end="3421">
<li data-start="3290" data-end="3375" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3292" data-end="3375" class=""><strong data-start="3292" data-end="3334">MinPts = 2 * dimensions of the dataset</strong> (e.g., if features = 2, use MinPts ≈ 4).</p>
</li>
<li data-start="3378" data-end="3421" class="" style="">
<p data-start="3380" data-end="3421" class="">For small datasets, <strong data-start="3400" data-end="3420">MinPts ≈ 5 to 10</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<hr data-start="3423" data-end="3426" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="3428" data-end="3488" class=""><strong data-start="3431" data-end="3488">📌 6. DBSCAN vs. K-Means vs. Agglomerative Clustering</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="3489" data-end="3882" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="3489" data-end="3535"><tr data-start="3489" data-end="3535"><th data-start="3489" data-end="3500">Feature</th><th data-start="3500" data-end="3509">DBSCAN</th><th data-start="3509" data-end="3519">K-Means</th><th data-start="3519" data-end="3535">Hierarchical</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="3582" data-end="3882"><tr data-start="3582" data-end="3642"><td><strong data-start="3584" data-end="3618">Number of clusters predefined?</strong></td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="3643" data-end="3708"><td><strong data-start="3645" data-end="3683">Works with non-spherical clusters?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="3709" data-end="3764"><td><strong data-start="3711" data-end="3740">Handles noise (outliers)?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="3765" data-end="3825"><td><strong data-start="3767" data-end="3782">Scalability</strong></td><td>❌ Slow on large data</td><td>✅ Fast</td><td>❌ Slow</td></tr><tr data-start="3826" data-end="3882"><td><strong data-start="3828" data-end="3858">Handles varying densities?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>❌ No</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="3884" data-end="3887" class="" style="">

class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> np
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> matplotlib.pyplot </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">as</span></span><span> plt
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_moons
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.cluster </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> DBSCAN
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Generate synthetic dataset (moons dataset for non-linear clusters)</span></span><span>
X, _ = make_moons(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">300</span></span><span>, noise=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.05</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Standardize features (important for DBSCAN)</span></span><span>
X = StandardScaler().fit_transform(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Apply DBSCAN</span></span><span>
dbscan = DBSCAN(eps=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.3</span></span><span>, min_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>)
labels = dbscan.fit_predict(X)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Plot clusters</span></span><span>
plt.scatter(X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">0</span></span><span>], X[:, </span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>], c=labels, cmap=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'viridis'</span></span><span>, marker=</span><span><span class="hljs-string">'o'</span></span><span>)
plt.title(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"DBSCAN Clustering"</span></span><span>)
plt.show()
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="4554" data-end="4557" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="4559" data-end="4608" class=""><strong data-start="4562" data-end="4608">📌 8. Advantages &amp; Disadvantages of DBSCAN</strong></h2>
<p data-start="4609" data-end="4814" class="">✅ <strong data-start="4611" data-end="4626">Advantages:</strong>
✔️ <strong data-start="4630" data-end="4671">No need to specify <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span> beforehand</strong>.<br data-start="4672" data-end="4675">
✔️ <strong data-start="4678" data-end="4708">Detects outliers naturally</strong>.<br data-start="4709" data-end="4712">
✔️ <strong data-start="4715" data-end="4752">Finds arbitrarily shaped clusters</strong> (unlike K-Means).<br data-start="4770" data-end="4773">
✔️ <strong data-start="4776" data-end="4813">Works well with varying densities</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="4816" data-end="5046" class="">❌ <strong data-start="4818" data-end="4836">Disadvantages:</strong>
✖️ <strong data-start="4840" data-end="4896">Sensitive to parameters <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span> and MinPts</strong>.<br data-start="4897" data-end="4900">
✖️ <strong data-start="4903" data-end="4943">Struggles with high-dimensional data</strong> (curse of dimensionality).<br data-start="4970" data-end="4973">
✖️ <strong data-start="4976" data-end="5017">Not efficient for very large datasets</strong> (<span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">O(n^2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span> complexity).</p>
<hr data-start="5048" data-end="5051" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="5053" data-end="5088" class=""><strong data-start="5056" data-end="5088">📌 9. Applications of DBSCAN</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5089" data-end="5289" class="">📌 <strong data-start="5092" data-end="5113">Anomaly detection</strong> (fraud detection, network intrusion).<br data-start="5151" data-end="5154">
📌 <strong data-start="5157" data-end="5182">Spatial data analysis</strong> (geographical clustering).<br data-start="5209" data-end="5212">
📌 <strong data-start="5215" data-end="5237">Image segmentation</strong>.<br data-start="5238" data-end="5241">
📌 <strong data-start="5244" data-end="5257">Astronomy</strong> (grouping celestial objects).</p>
<hr data-start="5291" data-end="5294" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="5296" data-end="5317" class=""><strong data-start="5299" data-end="5317">📌 10. Summary</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5318" data-end="5693" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5320" data-end="5379">DBSCAN is a powerful density-based clustering algorithm</strong> that identifies clusters without requiring the number of clusters in advance.<br data-start="5457" data-end="5460">
✅ <strong data-start="5462" data-end="5481">Key parameters:</strong> <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span></span></span></span> (neighborhood radius) and <strong data-start="5526" data-end="5536">MinPts</strong> (minimum neighbors).<br data-start="5557" data-end="5560">
✅ <strong data-start="5562" data-end="5619">Works well with noisy and arbitrarily shaped clusters</strong>.<br data-start="5620" data-end="5623">
✅ <strong data-start="5625" data-end="5690">Not suitable for very high-dimensional or very large datasets</strong>.</p>

class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><h1 data-start="0" data-end="52" class=""><strong data-start="2" data-end="50">K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) - A Complete Guide</strong></h1>
<h2 data-start="54" data-end="108" class=""><strong data-start="57" data-end="108">📌 1. Introduction to K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)</strong></h2>
<p data-start="109" data-end="425" class=""><strong data-start="109" data-end="138">K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)</strong> is a <strong data-start="144" data-end="177">supervised learning algorithm</strong> used for <strong data-start="187" data-end="220">classification and regression</strong>. It is a <strong data-start="230" data-end="286">non-parametric and instance-based learning algorithm</strong>, meaning it does not make assumptions about the data distribution and memorizes the training data instead of learning explicit parameters.</p>
<p data-start="427" data-end="708" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="430" data-end="460">Key characteristics of KNN</strong>:<br data-start="461" data-end="464">
✔️ <strong data-start="467" data-end="484">Lazy learning</strong> (no training phase, only memorization).<br data-start="524" data-end="527">
✔️ <strong data-start="530" data-end="548">Non-parametric</strong> (does not assume any distribution).<br data-start="584" data-end="587">
✔️ <strong data-start="590" data-end="644">Works for both classification and regression tasks</strong>.<br data-start="645" data-end="648">
✔️ <strong data-start="651" data-end="705">Simple and effective but computationally expensive</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="710" data-end="713" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="715" data-end="746" class=""><strong data-start="718" data-end="746">📌 2. How Does KNN Work?</strong></h2>
<p data-start="747" data-end="933" class="">The KNN algorithm works by <strong data-start="774" data-end="809">finding the K nearest neighbors</strong> to a given data point and making predictions based on majority voting (for classification) or averaging (for regression).</p>
<h3 data-start="935" data-end="968" class=""><strong data-start="939" data-end="968">🔹 Steps of KNN Algorithm</strong></h3>
<p data-start="969" data-end="1318" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="973" data-end="1011">Choose the number of neighbors (K)</strong>.<br data-start="1012" data-end="1015">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="1019" data-end="1045">Calculate the distance</strong> between the test data and all training data points.<br data-start="1097" data-end="1100">
3️⃣ <strong data-start="1104" data-end="1126">Sort the distances</strong> and select the <strong data-start="1142" data-end="1155">K-nearest</strong> points.<br data-start="1163" data-end="1166">
4️⃣ <strong data-start="1170" data-end="1192">For Classification</strong>: Assign the most common class among K neighbors.<br data-start="1241" data-end="1244">
5️⃣ <strong data-start="1248" data-end="1266">For Regression</strong>: Compute the <strong data-start="1280" data-end="1291">average</strong> of the K nearest values.</p>
<hr data-start="1320" data-end="1323" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="1325" data-end="1363" class=""><strong data-start="1328" data-end="1363">📌 3. Choosing the Best K Value</strong></h2>
<p data-start="1364" data-end="1424" class="">The choice of <strong data-start="1378" data-end="1383">K</strong> significantly affects KNN’s performance.</p>
<ul data-start="1426" data-end="1581">
<li data-start="1426" data-end="1505" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1428" data-end="1505" class=""><strong data-start="1428" data-end="1456">Small K (e.g., K=1, K=3)</strong> → <strong data-start="1459" data-end="1486">More sensitive to noise</strong> and may overfit.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="1506" data-end="1581" class="" style="">
<p data-start="1508" data-end="1581" class=""><strong data-start="1508" data-end="1538">Large K (e.g., K=10, K=15)</strong> → <strong data-start="1541" data-end="1561">More generalized</strong> but may underfit.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p data-start="1583" data-end="1772" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="1586" data-end="1613">How to find the best K?</strong><br data-start="1613" data-end="1616">
✔️ Use <strong data-start="1623" data-end="1643">cross-validation</strong> to test different K values.<br data-start="1671" data-end="1674">

<hr data-start="1774" data-end="1777" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="1779" data-end="1815" class=""><strong data-start="1782" data-end="1815">📌 4. Distance Metrics in KNN</strong></h2>

<p data-start="2322" data-end="2364" class="">When <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">p = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span>, Minkowski = Manhattan.</p>
</li>
<li data-start="2365" data-end="2409" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2367" data-end="2409" class="">When <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">p = 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span>, Minkowski = Euclidean.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2411" data-end="2441" class=""><strong data-start="2415" data-end="2439">4️⃣ Hamming Distance</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2442" data-end="2512" class="">Used for <strong data-start="2451" data-end="2476">categorical variables</strong>, counting how many features differ.</p>
<h3 data-start="2514" data-end="2545" class=""><strong data-start="2518" data-end="2543">5️⃣ Cosine Similarity</strong></h3>
<p data-start="2546" data-end="2589" class="">Used in <strong data-start="2554" data-end="2588">text and high-dimensional data</strong>.</p>
<hr data-start="2591" data-end="2594" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="2596" data-end="2631" class=""><strong data-start="2599" data-end="2631">📌 5. KNN for Classification</strong></h2>
<p data-start="2632" data-end="2725" class="">KNN <strong data-start="2636" data-end="2666">classifies new data points</strong> based on the <strong data-start="2680" data-end="2697">majority vote</strong> of its nearest K neighbors.</p>
<p data-start="2727" data-end="2742" class="">🔹 <strong data-start="2730" data-end="2741">Example</strong>:</p>
<ul data-start="2743" data-end="2885">
<li data-start="2743" data-end="2885" class="" style="">
<p data-start="2745" data-end="2885" class="">If <strong data-start="2748" data-end="2755">K=3</strong>, and among the 3 nearest points, 2 belong to class <strong data-start="2807" data-end="2812">A</strong> and 1 belongs to class <strong data-start="2836" data-end="2841">B</strong>, then the new point is classified as <strong data-start="2879" data-end="2884">A</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h3 data-start="2887" data-end="2930" class=""><strong data-start="2891" data-end="2930">📌 Classification Example in Python</strong></h3>

class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> load_iris
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.preprocessing </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> StandardScaler
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.neighbors </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> KNeighborsClassifier
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> accuracy_score

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Load dataset</span></span><span>
iris = load_iris()
X, y = iris.data, iris.target

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Split dataset</span></span><span>
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Standardize features</span></span><span>
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_train = scaler.fit_transform(X_train)
X_test = scaler.transform(X_test)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train KNN model</span></span><span>
knn = KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>)
knn.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict</span></span><span>
y_pred = knn.predict(X_test)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Accuracy</span></span><span>
accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"KNN Accuracy:"</span></span><span>, accuracy)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>

<h2 data-start="3696" data-end="3727" class=""><strong data-start="3699" data-end="3727">📌 6. KNN for Regression</strong></h2>
<p data-start="3728" data-end="3856" class="">KNN can also be used for <strong data-start="3753" data-end="3767">regression</strong> tasks by predicting the target value as the <strong data-start="3812" data-end="3820">mean</strong> (or median) of K nearest neighbors.</p>

class="overflow-y-auto p-4" dir="ltr"><code class="!whitespace-pre language-python"><span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.neighbors </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> KNeighborsRegressor
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.datasets </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> make_regression
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.model_selection </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> train_test_split
</span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span></span><span> sklearn.metrics </span><span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span></span><span> mean_squared_error

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Generate synthetic regression dataset</span></span><span>
X, y = make_regression(n_samples=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">200</span></span><span>, n_features=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">1</span></span><span>, noise=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">10</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Split data</span></span><span>
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">0.2</span></span><span>, random_state=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">42</span></span><span>)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Train KNN Regressor</span></span><span>
knn_reg = KNeighborsRegressor(n_neighbors=</span><span><span class="hljs-number">5</span></span><span>)
knn_reg.fit(X_train, y_train)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Predict</span></span><span>
y_pred = knn_reg.predict(X_test)

</span><span><span class="hljs-comment"># Evaluate</span></span><span>
mse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred)
</span><span><span class="hljs-built_in">print</span></span><span>(</span><span><span class="hljs-string">"KNN Regression MSE:"</span></span><span>, mse)
</span></span></code></div></div></pre>
<hr data-start="4736" data-end="4739" class="" style="">
<h2 data-start="4741" data-end="4777" class=""><strong data-start="4744" data-end="4777">📌 7. KNN vs Other Algorithms</strong></h2>
<div class="overflow-x-auto contain-inline-size"><table data-start="4778" data-end="5269" node="[object Object]"><thead data-start="4778" data-end="4840"><tr data-start="4778" data-end="4840"><th data-start="4778" data-end="4789">Feature</th><th data-start="4789" data-end="4795">KNN</th><th data-start="4795" data-end="4811">Decision Tree</th><th data-start="4811" data-end="4817">SVM</th><th data-start="4817" data-end="4840">Logistic Regression</th></tr></thead><tbody data-start="4900" data-end="5269"><tr data-start="4900" data-end="4957"><td><strong data-start="4902" data-end="4919">Training Time</strong></td><td>⏳ Slow</td><td>⚡ Fast</td><td>⏳ Slow</td><td>⚡ Fast</td></tr><tr data-start="4958" data-end="5017"><td><strong data-start="4960" data-end="4979">Prediction Time</strong></td><td>⏳ Slow</td><td>⚡ Fast</td><td>⚡ Fast</td><td>⚡ Fast</td></tr><tr data-start="5018" data-end="5081"><td><strong data-start="5020" data-end="5048">Handles Non-Linear Data?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="5082" data-end="5147"><td><strong data-start="5084" data-end="5113">Works for Classification?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td></tr><tr data-start="5148" data-end="5207"><td><strong data-start="5150" data-end="5175">Works for Regression?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>❌ No</td></tr><tr data-start="5208" data-end="5269"><td><strong data-start="5210" data-end="5236">Sensitive to Outliers?</strong></td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>❌ No</td><td>✅ Yes</td><td>✅ Yes</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<hr data-start="5271" data-end="5274" class="">
<h2 data-start="5276" data-end="5322" class=""><strong data-start="5279" data-end="5322">📌 8. Advantages &amp; Disadvantages of KNN</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5323" data-end="5475" class="">✅ <strong data-start="5325" data-end="5339">Advantages</strong>:<br data-start="5340" data-end="5343">
✔️ <strong data-start="5346" data-end="5377">Simple &amp; easy to understand</strong>.<br data-start="5378" data-end="5381">
✔️ <strong data-start="5384" data-end="5418">Works well with small datasets</strong>.<br data-start="5419" data-end="5422">
✔️ <strong data-start="5425" data-end="5446">No training phase</strong> (useful for dynamic data).</p>
<p data-start="5477" data-end="5672" class="">❌ <strong data-start="5479" data-end="5496">Disadvantages</strong>:<br data-start="5497" data-end="5500">
✖️ <strong data-start="5503" data-end="5532">Computationally expensive</strong> (for large datasets).<br data-start="5554" data-end="5557">
✖️ <strong data-start="5560" data-end="5596">Sensitive to irrelevant features</strong>.<br data-start="5597" data-end="5600">
✖️ <strong data-start="5603" data-end="5643">Struggles with high-dimensional data</strong> (Curse of Dimensionality).</p>
<hr data-start="5674" data-end="5677" class="">
<h2 data-start="5679" data-end="5718" class=""><strong data-start="5682" data-end="5718">📌 9. Optimizing KNN Performance</strong></h2>
<p data-start="5719" data-end="6080" class="">1️⃣ <strong data-start="5723" data-end="5742">Feature Scaling</strong>: Normalize data using <strong data-start="5765" data-end="5799">StandardScaler or MinMaxScaler</strong>.<br data-start="5800" data-end="5803">
2️⃣ <strong data-start="5807" data-end="5835">Dimensionality Reduction</strong>: Use <strong data-start="5841" data-end="5848">PCA</strong> or <strong data-start="5852" data-end="5873">Feature Selection</strong> for high-dimensional data.<br data-start="5900" data-end="5903">
3️⃣ <strong data-start="5907" data-end="5945">Choosing the Right Distance Metric</strong>: Try different metrics (e.g., <strong data-start="5976" data-end="6008">Euclidean, Manhattan, Cosine</strong>).<br data-start="6010" data-end="6013">
4️⃣ <strong data-start="6017" data-end="6047">Using KD-Tree or Ball-Tree</strong>: Efficient for large datasets.</p>
<hr data-start="6082" data-end="6085" class="">
<h2 data-start="6087" data-end="6108" class=""><strong data-start="6090" data-end="6108">📌 10. Summary</strong></h2>
<p data-start="6109" data-end="6477" class="">✅ <strong data-start="6111" data-end="6194">K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) is a simple, instance-based, non-parametric algorithm</strong> that makes predictions based on proximity.<br data-start="6237" data-end="6240">
✅ <strong data-start="6242" data-end="6295">Used for both classification and regression tasks</strong>.<br data-start="6296" data-end="6299">
✅ <strong data-start="6301" data-end="6388">Sensitive to high-dimensional data and computationally expensive for large datasets</strong>.<br data-start="6389" data-end="6392">
✅ <strong data-start="6394" data-end="6474">Performance depends on the choice of K, distance metric, and feature scaling</strong>.</p>
<p data-start="6479" data-end="6564" class="">🔥 <strong data-start="6482" data-end="6561">Would you like a deeper dive into optimizing KNN for high-dimensional data?</strong>
